sentence:
Let 𝐝_i  = (d_0,i ,⋯ , d_n,i) ∈_+^n+1.
        For any element 𝐟∈_+^n+1, the operation
       β^i(𝐟) = 𝐟 + 𝐝_i is called a
       virtual i-move in _+^n+1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
given an n-simplex Δ^n and an (n-1)-face
    F^n-1 of Δ^n, we first do an (n-1)-dimensional bistellar
    0-move to F^n-1 on ∂Δ^n, the boundary
    of Δ^n becomes a PL (n-1)-sphere L^n-1. Then we
    add a new vertex v_0 in the interior of Δ^n and
    take v_0 *  L^n-1. The PL n-disk v_0 *  L^n-1
   is called a
   star subdivision of Δ^n along a face F^n-1 (see
   Figure <ref> for examples). .2cm
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: star subdivision of Δ^n along a face

sentence:
An n-simplex Δ^n in a combinatorial n-manifold with boundary
       (M^n,ξ) is
       called exposed if there exists some (n-1)-face of Δ^n lying
        on ∂ M^n.  Δ^n is called one-face-exposed
       if Δ^n ∩∂ M^n is exactly one (n-1)-face of Δ^n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
([7, Theorem 4]) The number of partitons of n
whose Frobenius symbol has no 0 on the top row equals the number
of partitions of n in which the smallest number that is not a
summand is odd.

sentence:
The loop Schur function associated to (λ,n) is defined by

    s_λ[n]:=∑_T∈ SSYT(λ,n)x^T.

sentence:
The loop power-sum functions are defined by

    p_k[n]:=∑_j( ∏_i=0^n-1x_i,j)^k.

sentence:
The l-shifted loop Schur function associated to (λ,n) is defined by

    s_λ^l[n]:=∑_T∈ SSYT(λ,n)x^T,l.

sentence:
(Irregular expressions) We say that a product

    e_a_mb_m⋯ e_a_1b_1∈𝐔(gl(m_0|m_1+n))

is an irregular expression whenever
  there exists a right subsequence

    e_a_i,b_i⋯ e_a_2,b_2 e_a_1,b_1,

i ≤ m and a
virtual symbol γ∈ A_0 ∪ A_1 such that

    #{j;  b_j = γ, j ≤ i }  >  #{j;  a_j = γ, j < i }.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(The ideal 𝐈𝐫𝐫) The  left ideal 𝐈𝐫𝐫  of 𝐔(gl(m_0|m_1+n)) is
the left ideal generated by the set of
irregular expressions.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
(The virtual algebra Virt(m_0+m_1,n))
The vector space Virt(m_0+m_1,n) = 𝐔(gl(0|n)) ⊕𝐈𝐫𝐫
is a subalgebra of 𝐔(gl(m_0|m_1+n)),  called the virtual subalgebra <cit.>,
and 𝐈𝐫𝐫 is a two sided ideal of Virt(m_0+m_1,n).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(The Capelli devirtualization epimorphism)
The Capelli epimorphism is the projection

    𝔭 : Virt(m_0+m_1,n) = 𝐔(gl(0|n)) ⊕𝐈𝐫𝐫↠𝐔(gl(0|n)) = 𝐔(gl(n))

with Ker(𝔭) = 𝐈𝐫𝐫.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Harish-Chandra isomorphism χ_n is the algebra isomorphism

    χ_n : ζ(n) ⟶Λ^*(n),      A ↦χ_n(A),

χ_n(A) being the shifted symmetric polynomial such that, for every highest weight module V_μ,
the evaluation χ_n(A)(μ_1, μ_2, … , μ_n) equals the eigenvalue of
A ∈ζ(n) in  V_μ (<cit.>, Proposition 2.1).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Fix f𝔽^n-1_2→𝔽_2.  
  Label the edge x_n-1… x_1 x_0 → x_n x_n-1… x_1 of
G_n by 1 if x_n = x_0 + f(x_n-1, …, x_1) and by y
otherwise.  Denote this weighted graph by G_n,f. For any in-tree
T ∈Λ_n define the weight of T , denoted by
y^(f;T), to be the product of the weights of edges.

Then
  
    (1+y)^2^n-1 -1· G(f;y) = ∑_T ∈Λ_n
    y^(f;T)

where G(f;y) is defined in
  (<ref>).

sentence: Given a graph G we say that Å⊂_r is well-distributed if, for each e∈ E(G), there are at least k_r/2 sets A⊂ V(G) ∖ V(e) for which |A|=r and, for each subset B⊂ V(e)∪ A with |B|=r, G[B]∈Å.

sentence:
Given a graph G and r ∈ℕ, a function π:E(G)→ is r-smooth if


  * for each edge xy∈ E(G), |π(xy)|≤ 1/10^4,

  * for each vertex x∈ V(G), ∑_y∈ N(x)|π(xy)|≤ n/10^4r, and 

  * ∑_xy∈ E(G)|π(xy)|≤ n^2/10^4r^2.

sentence: Given a unicycle (ρ,v) with directed cycle C=C(ρ), let ρ denote the configuration obtained from ρ by reversing the edges of C, and keeping all other rotors unchanged.  We say that C is reversible if (ρ, v)  (ρ, v).

sentence:
A loop-graph H is a bipartite swapping target if H^ is bipartite, where H^ is the auxiliary graph defined by taking V(H^) = V(H)  V(H) and an edge between (u,v) and (u',v') if and only if

    uu',vv' ∈ E(H)   and  {uv' ∉ E(H)  or  u'v ∉ E(H)}.

sentence:
The extended line graph H of a graph H has V( H) = E(H) and two edges e and f of H are adjacent in H if


  * e = f, or

  * e and f share a common vertex, or

  * e and f are opposite edges of a 4-cycle in G.

sentence:
For i∈ [k], if we have V_i = f_i,1∪…∪ f_i,m_i for some m_i≤ n_i with f_i,p≠∅ for all p∈ [m_i] and f_i,p∩ f_i,q = ∅ for all p≠ q, with p,q∈ [m_i], then we call the f_i,p's blocks of V_i.
Given a collection F = {f_1,1, …, f_1,m_1, f_2,1,…, f_2,m_2,…, f_k,1,…, f_k,m_k} of blocks partitioning every V_i, let S_F be the set of permutations of F such that no two consecutive elements of the permutation have the same first label. Note that S_F could be empty (we give a necessary and sufficient condition for S_F being non-empty in Section <ref>). Observe that if we take some π_F∈ S_F and unfold the blocks into sequences of individual vertices (in any order within each block), we obtain a permutation of V_𝐧 that induces π_F as its sequence of maximal blocks. Let ℱ be the set of all such collections of blocks partitioning every V_i, and note that for any F_1,F_2 ∈ℱ with F_1 ≠ F_2 we have S_F_1∩ S_F_2 = ∅.[Even if two collections F_1 and F_2 have the same number of blocks for each V_i, they are still considered different collections if the blocks have different constituent vertices: i.e., if there exist two u,v∈ V_i for some i∈ [k] such that u and v are in the same block in F_1 but are in different blocks in F_2. Hence, the S_F_1 and S_F_2 are disjoint in the sense that if we take some π_F_1∈ S_F_1 and some π_F_2∈ S_F_2, unfold them as described by substituting each block with its actual constituent vertices of G_𝐧 to obtain two permutations π_1 and π_2 of V_𝐧, then the two acyclic orientations induced are different.]

sentence:
A restricted system is a triple { A,b, } with
	
		
  * =X_1× X_2×⋯× X_m, where X_1,… ,X_m are subsets of G. 
		
  * A is a (k× m) integer matrix such that its
k-th determinantal d_k(A) satisfies (d_k(A),|G|)=1.

  * b is an element of G^k, and we usually refer to it as the independent vector.

A  solution of the restricted system
{ A,b, } is a vector x=(x_1,… ,x_m)∈ G^m such that
Ax=b and x_i∈ X_i, i=1,2,… ,m.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
An integer partition of p∈ is a k-tuple
(λ_1,...,λ_k)∈^k
 such that ∑_i=1^k λ_i =p and
λ_1 ≥ ...≥λ_k.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
A plane partition π of a positive
integer p∈, is a partition of p in which
the parts  have been arranged in a 2-dimensional
array,  weakly decreasing  across rows
and down columns. If the inequality is strict across rows (resp. columns), we say that the partition
is row-strict (resp column-strict ).


Different
configurations are regarded as different plane
partitions.


The norm of π is the sum 
n(π):=∑_i,jπ_i,j of all its parts.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
 Let D_r denote the set of all r-tuples 
 λ=(λ_1, ..., λ_r) of integers with 
 λ_1 ≥ ...≥λ_r. 
 

 For λ, μ∈ D_r, we write λ≥μ
 if λ_i ≥μ_i for all i=1,2,...,r. Let c,d arbitrary 
 integers and λ, μ∈ D_r, with λ≥μ. We call an array 
 ρ of integers of the form 
 
    ρ_1,μ_1+1   ρ_1,μ_1+2   ...    ...    ...    ρ_1,λ_1
       ρ_2,μ_2+1    ...    ...    ...    ...    ...   ρ_2,λ_2   
              ...    ...   ...    ...      
    ρ_r,μ_r+1    ...    ...   ρ_r,λ_r

a (c, d)-plane partition of shape λ/μ if 

    ρ_i,j≥ρ_i,j+1+c  for
      1≤ i≤ r, μ_i< j <λ_i,



    ρ_i,j≥ρ_i+1,j+d  for
      1≤ i≤ r-1, μ_i< j ≤λ_i+1.

In the case μ=0, we shortly say that ρ is of shape λ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let c,d be arbitrary integers and
λ be a partition 
with λ_r ≥ r. We call
“shifted (c,d)-plane
partition of 
shape λ” an array π of
integers of the form


    π_1,1   π_1,2   ...    ...    ...    ...    ...     ...    π_1,λ_1
       π_2,2    ...    ...    ...    ...    ...   π_2,λ_2   
           ...    ...    ...   ...    ...      
             π_r,r    ...    ...   π_r,λ_r


 and for which

    π_i,j≥π_i,j+1+c  for
      1≤ i≤ r,  i≤ j <λ_i,



    π_i,j≥π_i+1,j+d  for
      1≤ i≤ r-1,  i < j ≤λ_i+1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
The norm generating function for a class
C of (c,d)-plane partitions is 
    ∑_π∈ Cx^n(π).
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Bar Code  is a picture composed by segments, called bars , superimposed in horizontal rows, which satisfies conditions a.,b. below.
Denote by 

 
  * _j^(i) the j-th bar (from left to right) of the i-th row (from top to bottom), i.e. the j-th i-bar ;
 
  * μ(i) the number of bars of the i-th row
 
  * l_1(_j^(1)):=1, ∀ j ∈{1,2,...,μ(1)} the (1-)length of the 1-bars;
 
  * l_i(_j^(k)), 2≤ k ≤ n, 1 ≤ i ≤ k-1, 1≤ j ≤μ(k) the i-length of _j^(k), i.e. the number of i-bars lying over _j^(k)


 
  a. ∀ i,j, 1 ≤ i ≤ n-1, 1≤ j ≤μ(i), ∃ ! j∈{1,...,μ(i+1)} s.t. _j^(i+1) lies  under  _j^(i) 
 
  b. ∀ i_1, i_2 ∈{1,...,n}, ∑_j_1=1^μ(i_1) l_1(_j_1^(i_1))= ∑_j_2=1^μ(i_2) l_1(_j_2^(i_2)); we will then say that  all the rows have the same length .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: bars;j-th i-bar;length;length;all the rows have the same length

sentence:
The Bar Code diagram  associated to M (or, equivalently, to 
) is a 
n× m diagram, made by segments s.t. the i-th row of , 1≤ 
i≤ n  is constructed as follows:
       
        
  * take the i-th row of , i.e. ^[i]
        
  * consider all the sublists of repeated terms, i.e. [P_x_i(τ_j_1),P_x_i(τ_j_1 +1),...,P_x_i(τ_j_1 
+h)] s.t. 
        P_x_i(τ_j_1)= P_x_i(τ_j_1 
+1)=...=P_x_i(τ_j_1 +h), noticing that[Clearly if a term 
P_x_i(τ_j) is not 
        repeated in ^[i], the sublist containing it will be only  
[P_x_i(τ_j)], i.e. h=0.] 0 ≤ h<m 
        
  * underline each sublist with a segment
        
  * delete the terms of ^[i], leaving only the segments (i.e. 

the i-bars ).
       
 We usually label each 1-bar _j^(1), j ∈{1,...,μ(1)} with the 
term τ_j ∈.

sentence:
<cit.>
Let  M⊂𝒯 be a set of terms
 and  τ=x_1^γ_1⋯ x_n^γ_n
be an element of M.
A variable x_j is called multiplicative
for τ with respect to M if there is no term in
M of the form
τ'=x_1^δ_1⋯ x_j^δ_jx_j+1^γ_j+1⋯  
x_n^γ_n
with δ_j>γ_j.
 We will denote by _M(τ) the set of
multiplicative variables for τ with respect to M.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
With the previous notation, the cone of  τ with respect to M 
  is the set

    _M (τ):={τ x_1^λ_1⋯ x_n^λ_n | where λ_j≠ 0  only if  x_j  is 
    multiplicative for τ w.r.t.  M}.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.>
A set of terms M⊂𝒯 is called
complete if for every τ∈ M and
 x_j∉ mult_M(τ), there exists τ' ∈ M
such that x_j τ∈_M (τ').


 Moreover,  M is stably complete <cit.>   if it
 is complete and for every τ∈ M it holds
  _M(τ)={ x_i  |  x_i≤min(τ) }.


If a set M is stably complete and finite, then it is the Pommaret basis 
of I=(M).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
The minimal sum of a given list of 
positive integers [α_1,...,α_g] is the
integer

    ([α_1,...,α_g]):=∑_i=1^g α_i(α_i +1)/2.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A permutation π=π_1π_2…π_n∈ S_n is said to contain a permutation σ=σ_1σ_2…σ_k if there exist indices 1≤α_1<α_2< … <α_k ≤ n such that π_α_i < π_α_j if and only if σ_i <σ_j.  Otherwise, we say π avoids σ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A permutation class is a downset of permutations under the containment order.  Every permutation class can be specified by the set of minimal permutations which are not in the class called its basis .  For a set B of permutations, we denote by (B) the class of permutations which do not contain any element of B.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We will call each repetition of the algorithm used to sort a permutation a pass .  Further, the tier of a permutation σ will refer to the minimum number of times we need to restart the sorting; that is, the tier is one less than the minimal number of passes necessary to sort σ. We use t(σ) to denote the tier of the permutation σ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let σ∈ S_m and let i ∈{1, 2, ... ,n - 1}. We say that the integers (i + 1, i) are a separated pair in a permutation σ∈ S_n if there is a subsequence in σ of the form (i + 1, k, i) where k > i + 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An interval of a permutation π is a consecutive subsequence of π that contains consecutive values.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A permutation π is said to be plus-decomposable if π is the concatenation of two non-empty intervals ω and τ' where the values of ω are less than those of τ'.  Further, if we rescale the entries of τ' by subtracting the length of ω from each entry of τ' to get a permutation τ, we denote π = ω⊕τ.  If a permutation is not plus-decomposable, we say the permutation is plus-indecomposable .
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A permutation π is said to be minus-decomposable if π is the concatenation of two non-empty intervals ω' and τ where the values of ω' are greater than those of τ.  As before, if we rescale the entries of ω' by subtracting the length of τ from each entry of ω' to get a permutation ω, we denote π = ω⊖τ.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let G be a maximal outerplanar graph. For any edge v_1v_2 of the outerface of G, the vertices of G can be ordered v_1, …, v_n such that v_i (2 < i ≤ n) has exactly two neighbors, u and v, in G_i-1 = G[{v_1, …, v_i-1] and uv is and edge of G. We refer to such an order as an outerplanar-order .

sentence:
A linear L-system  is anchored if there exists A ∈ such
that t_L≤ A ≤ c_L for every L ∈. Note: we say that
 is anchored at A and refer to A as the anchor point of

sentence:
An I-order of a graph G with vertices v_1, …, v_n is an ordering
v_1 < v_2 < ⋯ < v_n such that: for every u<v<w, if uw ∈ E(G), then uv
∈ E(G).

sentence:
An MPT-order of a graph G with vertices v_1, …, v_n is an ordering
v_1 < v_2 < ⋯ < v_n such that: for every u<v<w<x, if uw,vx ∈ E(G),
then vw ∈ E(G).

sentence:
A graph G is a linear L contact graph when it has a linear L-system  such that no two L-shapes “cross-over” each other; i.e., for L-shapes L_u = (t_u,c_u,r_u), L_v = (t_v,c_v,r_v), if L_u ∩ L_v ≠∅ and c_u < c_v, then either c_u = t_v or r_u = c_v. 
Moreover, we say such an L contact system is equilateral when, for each L-shape, the vertical and horizontal segments have the same length.

sentence:
A graph G = (V,E) is a min point-tolerance (mPT) graph if each vertex
v of G can be mapped to a pointed-interval (I_v, p_v) where I_v
is an interval of  and p_v ∈ I_v such that uv is an edge of G
iff either p_u ∈ I_v or p_v ∈ I_u.

sentence:

say that H has a phase transition from f to g if
(H,g) < (H,f).


Given a function (n)→ 0,
we shall say that H has a -phase-transition at f if H has a phase transition from
f to f. If H has a -phase-transition at f for every
 tending to 0, then we shall say that G has a strong
  phase transition at f. Let _(n) =
2^-log^1- n.
If there exists an >0 for which H
has a _-phase-transition at f,
 then we shall say that H has a weak phase transition at f.[The strange function 2^log^1-n is somewhere
  “halfway” between log n and n^c.  ]

sentence:
Consider a continuous map ϕ X→. A topological Pach family for ϕ consists of sets P_i⊂ V_i
and a point p∈ M such that the ϕ-image of every d-simplex in P_1∗…∗ P_d+1 contains p. 
Let f_(n) be the least integer such that, for every continuous map ϕ X→, there is 
a topological Pach family all of whose sets are of size f_(n).

sentence:
Given a sequence of graphs =(H_1,…, H_k), denote by r^*(H_1,…,H_k) the maximum integer r^* such that there exists a colouring ξ: [r^*]≤ 2→ [k] such that
 	
 		
  *  the restriction of ξ to [r^*] 2 is (H_1,…,H_k)-homomorphic-free (that is, for each i∈[k] there is no edge-monochromatic  homomorphic copy of H_i in the i-th colour);
 		
  *  for every distinct i,j∈ [r^*] we have
 		ξ({i,j})≠ξ({i}), that is, we forbid a pair having the same colour as one of its points.
 	
 	For any r'≤ r^*, we will call a colouring ξ:[r']≤ 2→ [k] feasible (with respect to (H_1,…,H_k)) if it satisfies both (P<ref>) and (P<ref>). We say that (H_1,…,H_k) is nice if every feasible colouring ξ:[r^*(H_1,…,H_k)]≤ 2→ [k] assigns the same colour to all singletons.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For ξ:[t]≤ 2→ [k] and disjoint sets V_1,…,V_t, the blow-up colouring ξ(V_1,…,V_t): V_1∪…∪ V_t 2→ [k] is defined by

    ξ(V_1,…,V_t)(xy):=ξ(ij),     if xy∈ E(V_i,V_j),
    ξ(i),     if x,y∈ V_i.

	If |V_i|=N for every i∈[t], then we say that ξ(V_1,…,V_t) is an N-blow-up of ξ.

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex. A (finite, simplicial) homology
subdivision of Δ (over ) is a simplicial complex Δ' together
with a map σ: Δ' →Δ such that the following hold for every
F ∈Δ: (a) the set Δ'_F := σ^-1 (2^F) is a subcomplex of
Δ' which is a homology ball (over ) of dimension (F); and
(b) σ^-1 (F) consists of the interior faces of Δ'_F.

Such a map σ is said to be a topological subdivision if the complex
Δ'_F is homeomorphic to a ball of dimension (F) for every F ∈Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Δ', Δ be simplicial complexes and let σ: Δ' →Δ be a homology subdivision.
        
          
  (i) We say that σ is vertex-induced if for all faces
          E ∈Δ' and F ∈Δ the following condition holds: if every
          vertex of E is a vertex of Δ'_F, then E ∈Δ'_F.
          
  (ii) We say that σ is a flag subdivision if the
          restriction Δ'_F is a flag complex for every face F ∈Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let V be a set with d elements and let Γ be a homology subdivision
      of the simplex 2^V. The polynomial ℓ_V (Γ, x) = ℓ_0 + ℓ_1 x +
      ⋯ + ℓ_d x^d defined by
        
    ℓ_V (Γ, x)  = ∑_F ⊆ V (-1)^d - |F| 
              h (Γ_F, x)

      is the local h-polynomial of Γ (with respect to V). The
      sequence ℓ_V (Γ) = (ℓ_0, ℓ_1,…,ℓ_d) is the local
      h-vector of Γ (with respect to V).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let V be a set with d elements and let Γ be a homology subdivision
      of the simplex 2^V. The polynomial ξ_V (Γ, x) = ξ_0 + ξ_1 x +
      ⋯ + ξ_⌊ d/2 ⌋ x^⌊ d/2 ⌋ defined by
        
    ℓ_V (Γ, x)  =  (1+x)^d  ξ_V ( Γ, x/(1+x)^2)   =  ∑_i=0^⌊ d/2 ⌋ ξ_i x^i (1+x)^d-2i

      is the local γ-polynomial of Γ (with respect to V).
      The sequence ξ_V (Γ) = (ξ_0, ξ_1,…,ξ_⌊ d/2 ⌋)
      is the local γ-vector of Γ (with respect to V).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a semi–standard tableau T,
S_k=(y_1,y_2,…,y_k) is a k–string (or just string, for short, when there is no ambiguity) of T if
y_1<⋯< y_k and the rightmost box in row y_j is labeled with j; the corresponding strip, denoted by st(S_k), is the union of all rightmost boxes in rows y_j, for all j=1, … ,k.

We say that S_k=(y_1,y_2,…,y_k) ≤ S_t=(z_1,z_2,…,z_t)
if k ≥ t and y_j≤ z_j for all j=1 , … ,t.

1.5mm

We define in a recursive way (S_m_1, S_m_2, …  S_m_s) a complete sequence of strings of the tableau T having content (m_1,m_2,…,m_s)^' (note that we are writing the content in terms of its conjugate)
if S_m_1 is a string of T and (S_m_2, …  S_m_s) is a complete sequence of strings of the tableau T ∖ st(S_m_1) (when this set is not empty) having content (m_2,…,m_s)^'.

In other word, (S_m_1, S_m_2, …  S_m_s) is a complete sequence of strings of T if
S_m_j is a string for T∖{⋃_k=1^j-1 st(S_m_k)} for all j=1, … ,s.

sentence: A nice board B contains a nice board B' if B' can be obtained from B by deleting an equal number of rows and columns. Otherwise, we say that B avoids B'.

sentence: A chemical hypergraph is a pair Γ=(V,H) such that V={v_1,…,v_N} is a finite set of vertices and H is a set such that every element h in H is a pair of elements (V_h,W_h) (input and output, not necessarily disjoint) in 𝒫(V)∖{∅}. The elements of H are called the oriented hyperedges . Changing the orientation of a hyperedge h means exchanging its input and output, leading to the pair (W_h,V_h).

sentence: A catalyst in a hyperedge h is a vertex that is both an input and an output for h.

sentence: We say that two closed systems 𝒮=(V',H') and 𝒮=(V',H') are disjoint if H∩ H'=∅.

sentence:
Let Γ=(V,H) be a hypergraph with M hyperedges h_1,…,h_M and K closed systems of reactions 𝒮_1,…,𝒮_K. Let A=(a_ij)_ij be the K× M matrix such that
	
    a_ij:= 1    if h_j∈𝒮_i
     0    otherwise.
Therefore each row A_i of A represents a closed system 𝒮_i and each column A^j of A represents a hyperedge h_j. Given I⊆{1,…,K}, we say that the closed systems {𝒮_i}_i∈ I are linearly independent if the raws {A_i}_i∈ I of A are linearly independent.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Γ=(V,H) be a hypergraph with N vertices v_1,…,v_N and M hyperedges h_1,…,h_M. We define the N× M incidence matrix of Γ as ℐ:=(ℐ_ij)_ij, where
	
    ℐ_ij:= 1    if v_i is an input and not an output of h_j
     -1    if v_i is an output and not an input of h_j
     0    otherwise.
Therefore each row ℐ_i of ℐ represents a vertex v_i and each column ℐ^j of ℐ represents a hyperedge h_j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given J⊆{1,…,M}, we say that the hyperedges {h_j}_j∈ J are linearly independent if the corresponding columns in the incidence matrix are linearly independent, that is, if {ℐ^j}_j∈ J are linearly independent. Analogously, given I⊆{1,…,N}, we say that the vertices {v_i}_i∈ I are linearly independent if the corresponding rows in the incidence matrix are linearly independent, that is, if {ℐ_i}_i∈ I are linearly independent.

sentence: (Ag,g)/(g,g) is called the Rayleigh quotient of g.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: We say that a hypergraph Γ is bipartite if one can decompose the vertex set as a disjoint union V=V_1⊔ V_2 such that, for every hyperedge h of Γ, either h has all its inputs in V_1 and all its outputs in V_2, or vice versa.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒞 be a class of finite structures. We say that 𝒞 has the amalgamation property with automorphisms ( APA ) if for every A,  B_1,  B_2 ∈𝒞 such that A⊆ B_1, B_2 there exists C∈𝒞 which is an amalgamation of B_1 and B_2 over A, has B_1, B_2⊆ C and furthermore the following holds:

For every pair of automorphisms f_1∈( B_1), f_2∈( B_2) such that f_i(A) = A for i∈{1,2} and f_1|_A = f_2|_A, there is an automorphism g∈( C) such that g|_B_i = f_i for i∈{1,2}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that a class 𝒞⊆𝒢 has the
extension property for switching automorphisms if for every G∈𝒞 there exists H∈𝒞 containing G as an
induced subgraph such that every switching isomorphism of induced subgraphs of
G extends to a switching automorphism of H
and, moreover, every isomorphism of induced subgraphs of G extends to an automorphism of H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Coherent EPPA <cit.>]

A class 𝒞 of finite structures is said to have coherent EPPA if 𝒞 has EPPA and moreover the extension of partial automorphisms
is coherent. More precisely, for every A∈𝒞, there exists an EPPA-witness B∈𝒞 for A and a coherent map f ↦f̂ from the family of partial automorphisms of A to the group of automorphisms of B. In this case we also call B a coherent EPPA-witness of A.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
[APA]
Let 𝒞 be a class of finite structures. We say that 𝒞 has the amalgamation property with automorphisms ( APA ) if for every A,  B_1,  B_2 ∈𝒞 such that A⊆ B_1, B_2 there exists C∈𝒞 which is an amalgamation of B_1 and B_2 over A, has B_1, B_2⊆ C and furthermore the following holds:

For every pair of automorphisms f_1∈( B_1), f_2∈( B_2) such that f_i(A) = A for i∈{1,2} and f_1|_A = f_2|_A, there is an automorphism g∈( C) such that g|_B_i = f_i for i∈{1,2}.

sentence: An oriented 3–hypergraph H is said to be transitive , if whenever (u  v  z) and (z  v  w) ∈ O(H) then (u  v  w) ∈ O(H) (this implies also (u  w  z) ∈ O(H)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A non-oriented 3–hypergraph  is called a comparability 3–hypergraph if it admits a transitive orientation. 
[In  <cit.> the authors defined this class as “cyclic comparability 3-hypergraphs" however we believe that it should be simply called comparability 3-hypergraphs according to the classical concept of comparability graphs. ]
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A 3–hypergraph H is said to be even , if every four vertex subset of V(H) induces  an even number of edges.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For positive integers  q and r we define the winding permutation 3–hypergraph , W_q, r, as the 3–hypergraph with n=r(q-1)+1 vertices associated to the cyclic permutation [ϕ _q, r] defined as follows. For i∈{1,2,...,n} let: 



    ϕ_q, r(i) = {[                   1                    ; 2+(q-1)(r-j)+ i-j/r                     ].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X be a finite set, and C_n be a cyclic group of order n acting on X. Fix an isomorphism ω from C_n to the nth roots of unity. Furthermore, let f(q) be a polynomial in q. Then, the triple (X,f(q),C_n) is said to exhibit the cyclic sieving phenomenon (CSP) if
		
		
    f(ω(c))=|{x∈ X|c(x)=x}|,  for every  c∈ C_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let T be a coloured rooted tree and  𝐤=(k_s:s∈ V(T)) a tuple of positive integers indexed by the vertices of T. The branching of T^(𝐤) at a vertex s∈ V(T^(𝐤)) having colour (A_s,F_s,k_s) is the coloured rooted tree that


  (i) coincides with T^(𝐤) on vertices {t:s∉P(t)}=V(T)∖ B(s), and

  (ii) is such that p(s) now has k_s isomorphic copies of B(s) pendant from it instead of one, where isomorphisms here are colour-preserving, with the exception of the k_s copies of s, which are now each coloured (A_s,F_s,1) instead of the original colour (A_s,F_s,k_s).

The positive integer k_s is the branching multiplicity of vertex s.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
We say that a process X_v, v ∈ V(T_d) is a linear factor of the
i.i.d. process Z_v if there exist real numbers _0, _1, … such that

    X_v = ∑_u ∈ V(T_d)_ d(v,u)  Z_u =
    ∑_k=0^∞∑_u: d(v,u) = k_k Z_u ,

where d(v,u) denotes the distance between the vertices v and u in T_d.
Note that the infinite sum in (<ref>) converges almost surely
if and only if _0^2 + ∑_k=1^∞ d(d-1)^k-1_k^2 < ∞.

sentence:
We call a collection of random variables X_v, v ∈ V(T_d)
a Gaussian process on T_d if they are jointly Gaussian
and each X_v is centered.
(Random variables are said to be jointly Gaussian
if any finite linear combination of them is Gaussian.)

Furthermore, we say that a Gaussian process X_v is invariant if
it is (T_d)-invariant, that is, for arbitrary graph automorphism
Φ: V(T_d) → V(T_d) of T_d the joint distribution of
the Gaussian process X_Φ(v) is the same as that of the original process.

sentence:
We denote by K  L = (K∖ L) ∪ (L∖ K) the symmetric difference between two sets K, L, and by d(K,L) = |K L| the symmetric difference distance between these sets. (All the sets considered in this chapter are finite.) The symbols “+ and ⊂ stand for the disjoint union  and the proper inclusion of sets  respectively. A (knowledge) structure is a pair
(Q,) where Q is a non empty set and  is a family of subsets of Q containing   and Q=∪. The latter is called the  domain of (Q,). The elements of Q are called items and the sets in  are  (knowledge) states. Since Q =∪,  the set Q is implicitly defined  by  and we can without ambiguity call  a knowledge structure. A knowledge structure   is well–graded if for any two distinct states K and L with |K△ L| = n there exists a sequence
K_0=K,K_1,…, K_n= L 
such that d(K,L) = n and d(K_i, K_i+1)=1 for 0≤ i≤ n-1. 
We call such a sequence K_0=K,K_1,…, K_n= L a tight path from K to L. 
We say that  is a knowledge space if it is closed under union, or ∪-closed . 

A knowledge structure (Q,) is a learning space <cit.> if it satisfies the following two conditions: 


 
  [L1] Learning smoothness. For any two K,L∈, with K ⊂ L and |L∖ K| = n, there is a chain 
K_0=K ⊂  K_1⊂⋯⊂ K_n = L  
such that, for 0≤ i≤ n-1, we have K_i+1 = K_i + {q_i}∈ for some q_i∈ Q . 



  [L2] Learning consistency. If K ⊂ L are two sets in  such that K + {q}∈ for some q∈ Q, then  L ∪{q}∈.  
A learning space is also known in the combinatorics literature as an `antimatroid', a structure introduced independently by <cit.> with slightly different, but equivalent axioms <cit.>. Another name is `well–graded knowledge space' <cit.>; see our Lemma <ref>. 

A family   of subsets of a set Q is a partial knowledge structure if it contains the set Q=∪. We do not assume that ||≥ 2.  
We also call `states' the sets in .  A partial knowledge structure   is a partial learning space  if it satisfies Axioms [L1] and [L2]. Note that  {} is vacuously well-graded and vacuously  ∪-closed, with ∪{}=. Thus, it  a partial knowledge structure  and a partial learning space (cf. Lemma <ref>).

sentence:
Let (Q, ) be a partial knowledge structure  and take any non empty proper subset Q' of Q.  The family

    '= {W Q W = K∩ Q' for some K∈}

is called the projection of  on Q'.  We have thus
' 2^Q'. 
As shown by Example <ref>, the sets in ' may not be states of .  
For any
state K in  and with [K] as in Definition <ref>, we define  the family

    _[K]= {M  M= L∖∩[K] for some L∼ K}.

(If ∈, we have thus _[]=[].) 
The family  is called a Q'-child , or simply a child of  ( induced by Q' ). As shown by the example below, a child of  may take the form of the singleton {} and we may have _[K] = _[L] even when K≁L. The set {} is called the trivial child.

We recall that [K] is the equivalence class containing K in the partition of   induced by Q' (cf. Definition <ref>). For any non trivial child  of , we call ^+=∪{} a plus child of .

    _i(f,X) =
    |_X[f|X_i=1]-_X[f|X_i=0]|
 the effect of player
X_i in f with respect to X. For α∈, we say that

    _i(f,X) > α.

sentence:
Let f:{0,1}^n →{0,1} be a function, and let μ be a distribution on {0,1}^n.
The influence of the i'th player is

    I_i(f,μ) = _x ∼μ[  f(x) ≠ f(x ⊕ e_i) ] ,

where e_i is the vector with 1 at the i'th index and 0 elsewhere, and ⊕ is bitwise XOR.

a Borel probability measure P on ^∞ is called
q-exchangeable if P is quasi-invariant with respect to the
action of the
group _∞, with the multiplicative cocycle given by
(<ref>).

For n=1,2,…, the Mallows measure _n is the probability
measure on _n defined by


    _n()=q^()/[n]_q! ,    ∈_n.

sentence:
Given an arbitrary finite word v_1⋯ v_n, its q-shuffle
is the
random word w_1⋯ w_n obtained by a random permutation of the letters
v_1,…,v_n, determined by the following n-step algorithm (not
to be
confused with the notion of a-shuffle with integer parameter a; see
<cit.>).

Let ξ_1,…,ξ_n be independent random variables with ξ
_j having
distribution G_q,n-j+1.

At step 1, take for w_1 the ξ_1th letter from the word
v^(1):=v_1⋯
v_n. Then, remove the letter v_ξ_1 from v^(1) and denote by
v^(2)
the resulting word of length n-1. Iterate. So, at each following step
m=2,…,n, there is a word v^(m) which was derived from the
initial word
by deleting some m-1 letters, a new letter w_m=v^(m)_ξ_m is then
chosen and, if m<n, the word v^(m+1) is obtained by removing this letter
from v^(m).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let v=v_1v_2⋯∈^∞ be an arbitrary infinite word. The
infinite q-shuffle of v is the infinite random word
w=w_1w_2⋯
produced by the algorithm similar to that in Definition <ref>. The
only changes are: (i) the independent variables with varying truncated
geometric distributions should be replaced by the independent variables
ξ_1,ξ_2,… with the same geometric distribution G_q; (ii) the
number of steps becomes infinite.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The q-Pascal pyramid of dimension d, denoted (q,d),
is the
oriented graph with vertex set _+^d and directed edges
(,+e_a),
endowed with weights




    weight(,+e_a):=q^_a+1+⋯+_d,    
    a∈_d.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The weight of a standard path with endpoint λ is
defined as the
product of the weights of the edges comprising the path. Let us say
that a
probability measure on the path space of (q,d) is a Gibbs
measure
if, for every λ, the conditional measure of a standard path terminating
at λ is proportional to the weight of this path (in the
terminology of
Kerov and Vershik <cit.>, such a measure is called “central”).

sentence:
By a height function on ,
we mean a
map h→_+∪{+∞} which is weakly increasing [i.e.,
h(a)≤
h(b) for a<b] and satisfies lim_a→∞ h(a)=+∞. The
set of all
height functions on  will be denoted H().

sentence:
We will refer to 3 different types of normal vectors for the
boundaries between victory regions.

 
  * A Type 1 vector only satisfies the requirements necessary for the boundary between 2 particular victory regions.
 
  * A Type 2 vector satisfies the requirements for all of the boundaries to the victory region for a single candidate c_i.
 
  * A Type 3 vector satisfies the requirements for all of the boundaries between all of the victory regions defined by this election method.

sentence: Given a constant p ∈ [2/3,1), a p-separator (of order k) is a set X ⊂ V(G) such that |X| ≤ k and no component of G-X contains more than p|G-X| vertices.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Consider all of the a-sets in [b]. Define the colexicographic or colex ordering on the a-sets as follows: if x and y are distinct a-sets, then x < y when max(x-y) < max(y-x). This is a strict total order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A set X of a-sets in [b] is first if X consists of the first |X| a-sets in the colex ordering of all the a-sets in [b].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let X be a set of a-sets in [b]. For c ≤ a, the c-shadow of X is the set { x : |x| = c, and ∃ y ∈ X such that x ⊆ y}. That is, the c-shadow contains all c-sets that are contained within a-sets of X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If x is an a-set in [b], let the complement of x be the (b-a)-set y = [b]-x. If X is a set of a-sets on [b], then the complement of X is X := { y: y is the complement of some x ∈ X }. Note |X| = |X|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A lattice polytope 𝒫 is called reflexive if it contains the origin in its interior, and its dual 𝒫^* is a lattice polytope.

O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A lattice polytope 𝒫⊆^n has the integer decomposition property if, for every integer t ∈_>0 and for all p ∈ t𝒫∩^n, there exists p_1 , … , p_t ∈𝒫∩ such that p = p_1 + ⋯ + p_t.
We will frequently say that 𝒫 is IDP when 𝒫 possesses this property.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a lattice simplex 𝒫⊂^n-1 with vertices {v_i}_i ∈ [n], the fundamental parallelepiped of 𝒫 is the subset of 𝒫 defined by 

    Π_𝒫 := {∑_i=1^n λ_i (v_i, 1) | 0 ≤λ_i < 1  }  .

Further, |Π_𝒫∩^n| is equal to the determinant of the matrix whose ißth row is given by (v_i,1).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a connected graph G, the n-1 dimensional lattice simplex 
    T_G:= (L_B)^T⊆^n-1
 is called the Laplacian Simplex associated to the graph G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
To add a whisker at a vertex x ∈ V(G), one adds a new vertex y and the edge connecting x and y. 
Let W(G) denote the graph obtained by whiskering all vertices in G.
We call W(G) the whiskered graph of G . 
If V(G) = { x_1, …, x_n} and E(G) = E, then V(W(G)) = V(G) ∪{y_1, …, y_n} and E(W(G))=E ∪{{x_1, y_2}, …, {x_n, y_n }}.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let k ≥ 2, let 0<μ,p<1, and let H be a k-graph on n vertices.  We say that H is (p,μ)-dense
  if for any X_1, …, X_k ⊆ V(H) we have
  
    e(X_1,…,X_k) ≥ p |X_1| ⋯ |X_k| - μ n^k,

  where e(X_1,…,X_k) is the number of k-tuples (x_1,…,x_k) ∈ X_1 ×⋯× X_k such
  that {x_1,…,x_k}∈ H (note that if the sets X_i overlap an edge might be counted more than
  once). We say that H is an (n,p,μ) k-graph if H has n vertices and is (p,μ)-dense.
  Finally, for  0 < α < 1, an (n,p,μ,α) k-graph is an (n,p,μ) k-graph H 
  which also satisfies δ_1(H) ≥αnk-1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let M
be an ℓ× p matrix of integers and let b ∈ℕ^ℓ. The set of linear equations Mx=b has the removal property if for every δ >0 there is an
ϵ=ϵ(δ,M,b)>0 with the following property: if S
⊆ [n] is such that there are at most ϵ n^p-ℓ
vectors x ∈ S^p satisfying Mx=b, then one can remove from
S at most δ n elements to obtain an (M,b)-free set.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An ear on a graph G is a path whose endpoints are vertices of G, but which otherwise is vertex-disjoint from G. An ear is an open ear 
if the endpoints of the path are distinct. 
An (open) ear decomposition of a graph G is a partition
of the edge set of G into parts Q_0, Q_1,… Q_ℓ
such that Q_0 is a cycle and Q_i for 1 ≤ i ≤ℓ is an (open) ear on Q_0 ∪⋯∪ Q_i-1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a weighted graph R with weight d: E(R)→ (0,1] and Y⊆ X⊆ V(R), a γ-generalised clique of order t:=|X|+|Y|, denoted by Z_t, on (X,Y) is a clique on X with d(e)>1/2+γ for every e∈ E(R[Y]).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A permutation π∈ S_n has a descent at position i if π(i) > π(i+1), where i = 1, …, n-1, and the descent set of π, denoted Des(π) is the set of all descents of π. The descent number of π is defined as d(π) := | Des(π) | + 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A matching , also known as a fixed point free involution , is a permutation π∈ S_2n such that π^2 = 1 and π(i) ≠ i for all i = 1,…,2n.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a permutation π∈ S_n, the major index of π is the sum of the descent positions of π, i.e.

    maj(π) = ∑_i ∈ Des(π) i.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Young diagram is a collection of boxes arranged in left-justified rows, with a weakly decreasing number of boxes in each row. A Young tableau is a filling of a Young diagram that is

	
  * weakly increasing across each row, and
	
  * strictly increasing down each column.


Every Young diagram corresponds to a partition λ, and we define the shape of a Young tableau to be the partition that corresponds to the Young diagram.

Flipping a Young diagram λ over its main diagonal (from upper left to lower right) gives the conjugate diagram, denoted λ'.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Given a partition λ, an oscillating tableau T of length n and shape λ is a sequence of n+1 partitions

    T = [ ∅ = λ_0, λ_1, …, λ_n = λ]

such that λ_i differs from λ_i-1 by a single box. Equivalently, we can think of T as a walk on Young's lattice which starts at the empty partition, ends at λ, and has n steps.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The 
A-hypergeometric system with parameter β is
given by

    D· (I_A +  E-β).

The D-module D/H_A(β) is known as the A-hypergeometric
  D-module with parameter β .
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A family  of permutations of V(H) is pairwise suitable for a hypergraph H if, for every two disjoint edges e,f ∈ E(H), there exists a permutation σ∈  which separates e and f. The cardinality of a smallest family of permutations that is pairwise suitable for H is called the separation dimension of H and is denoted by (H).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let ℱ be a finite family of sets in a topological space X.
 We define the topological complexity TC_1() as the smallest number b such that for each ⊆ the intersection ⋂ has at most (b+1) path-connected components. If no such number exists, we put TC_1()=∞.

sentence:
[Constrained map]
 Let _ 2^X→ 2^X be a closure operator and P be a set of points in X.
 Let f G→ X be a continuous  map. We say that f is constrained by
  (_,Φ) if Φ is a map from V(G)∪ E(G) to 2^P that satisfies the following.


 
  * σ∩τ=∅⇒Φ(σ)∩Φ(τ)=∅
 
 
  * σ⊆τ⇒Φ(σ)⊆Φ(τ).

  * For σ∈(V(G)∪ E(G)), the image f(σ) is contained in _ℱΦ(σ).

  * For every vertex v∈ V(G), Φ(v) consists of one point only.

If there is some Φ such that the continuous map f G→ X is constrained by (_,Φ),
we say that f is constrained by (, P) .
If _ is clear from the context, we just say that f is constrained by Φ or P, respectively.

sentence:
A matroid is a pair of sets (E,I), where I⊆𝒫(E) is a collection of independent sets meeting the following requirements:
 i) ∅∈ I. 
 ii) if A⊆ B ∈ I, then A∈ I. 
 iii) If A,B∈ I and A≠ B, then there is an a∈ A∖ B such that {a}∪ B∈ I.

For any set function r:𝒫(E)→ℕ we may define I_r={A⊆ E: r(A)=|A|}. Any set function for which I_r satisfies the above axioms will be called a rank function , and we may define a matroid (E,r)=(E,I_r).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: The simplicial matroid[A chapter on matroids arising from simplicial complexes in this way was included in Combinatorial Geometries <cit.>, and has since been revived in a string of papers.] of the complex Δ is denoted by M(Δ)=(F,r), where r(X)=rank(∂_X), i.e. M(Δ) is just the vectorial matroid of the columns of ∂.

sentence: Let T⊆ F. We call T a forest if β_d(T)=0, it is maximal if β_d-1(T)=β_d-1(Δ). Additionally if β_d-1(T)=0 it is called a tree , and if β_d-1(T)=β_d-1(Δ)=0 it is a spanning tree .

sentence: φ∈{0,…, q-1}^|F| is called a q-flow of Δ if ∂φ^T≡ 0 q. It is nowhere-zero if φ∈{1,…,q-1}^|F|. The number of nowhere-zero q-flows is denoted Φ_Δ(q) and is called the flow quasipolynomial.

sentence: χ∈{0,…, k-1}^|R| is called a k-coloring of Δ. It is proper if χ∂· e_j≢0 k for all standard basis vectors e_j∈ℤ^|F|. The number of proper k-colorings is denoted X_Δ(k) and is called the chromatic quasipolynomial.

sentence:
[Boolean Operations Theorem] 
  (Corollary 3.7 in
  <cit.> ) Let m and ℓ be fixed integers,
  and let ϕ{0,1}^m→{0,1} be any Boolean function
  such that ϕ(0) = 0.
  
  
  Then there exists a constant s = s(ℓ, m) and
  a polynomial-time algorithm for the following problem.
  Given as input , in binary encoding,
  
  
  * the dimension n and
  
  * rational generating functions
    
    g(S_p; ξ) =  ∑_i ∈ I_pγ_piξ^ c_pi/  (1-ξ^ d_pi1) … (1-ξ^ d_pis) ,
 of m finite
    sets S_p⊆^n, represented by the rational numbers γ_pi,
    integer vectors c_pi and d_pij for p=1,…,m, i∈ I_p,
    j=1,…,ℓ_mp such that the numbers ℓ_mp of terms in the
    denominators are at most ℓ,
  
  output , in binary encoding,
  
  
  * rational numbers γ_i, integer vectors c_i, d_ij for
    i∈ I, j=1,…,s_i, where s_i ≤ s, such that
    
    g(S; ξ) =  ∑_i ∈ Iγ_i ξ^ c_i/  (1-ξ^ d_i1) … (1-ξ^ d_is_i)
 is a rational generating
    function of the finite set S that is the Boolean combination of
    S_1,…,S_p corresponding to the function ϕ.

sentence:
[Enumeration Theorem] 
  Let the dimension k and the maximum number ℓ of binomials in the
  denominator be fixed.  Then there exists a polynomial-space polynomial-delay
  enumeration algorithm for the following enumeration problem.
  Given as input , in binary encoding,
  
  
  * a number M∈_+;
  
  * rational numbers γ_i, integer vectors
    c_i, d_ij for i∈ I, j=1,…,ℓ_i, where ℓ_i
    ≤ℓ such that
    
    ∑_i ∈ Iγ_i  s_0^ c_i/(1- s_0^ d_i1)(1-
          z^ d_i2)… (1- s_0^ d_is)

    is a 
    rational generating function of a set V⊆^k of lattice
    points with V⊆[-M,M]^k;
  
  * an integer p with 1≤ p ≤ k
  
  output , in binary encoding,
  
  
  * all points in the projection of V onto the last p components,
    
    W = {  w∈^p: ∃ t∈^k-p such that  (
        t, w)∈ V  },

    in lexicographic order.

sentence:
[Integer Programming Game]
An integer programming game with n players is a noncooperative game where the S_i of actions for each player i is the set of lattice points inside a polytope; that is,

    S_i=P_i∩^d_i

where P_i = { x ∈^d_i:M_i x ≤ b_i} is a rational polytope.

Let I = {1,…,n} denote the set of players. The set S of action profiles s = ( s_1,…, s_n) is the Cartesian product of the S_i's:

    S=∏_i=1^n S_i ⊆^d

where d = d_1+⋯+d_n. The payoff functions are integer-valued of the form u_i:S→ for i ∈ I.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[DPLC payoffs]
An integer-valued payoff function u:S→ of a game is a difference of piecewise-linear convex functions or DPLC function if it can be expressed as:

    u( s) = max_k∈ K f_k( s) - max_l ∈ L g_l( s)

where the f_k and g_l are affine functions with integer coefficients and where K and L are finite index sets. We refer to the f_k as the “convex" pieces of u and the g_l as the “concave" pieces of u.

[Extended pure Nash equilibrium]
Let Ĝ = (Ŝ, û_1,…, u_n)
be an extended game.
An extended pure Nash equilibrium ŝ =( s; y) is an
extended action profile where if ŝ∈Ŝ_ k then there
does not exist ŝ_i^' = ( s_i^', y_i^') such that (ŝ_-i, ŝ_̂î^') ∈Ŝ_( k_-i, k_i^') and û_i(ŝ_-i,ŝ_̂î^') > û_i( s).

sentence:
We call the elements e_i^* in H^1(G,) coedges , to
  distinguish them from the edges e_i∈ C_1(G,). Thus, coedges
  are cocycles and edges are chains.

sentence:
An edge-minimizing metric , abbreviated to emm , of a graph
  G is a quadratic form q∈^2H_1(G) such that
  
  
  * q>0, i.e. q is positive definite.
  
  * q(e_i^*)=1 for each edge e_i which is not a bridge
    (i.e. for each e_i^*0).
  
  * q(v^*)≥1 for any v^*∈ H^1(G,)∖ 0.
  
  A strong edge-minimizing metric, in addition, satisfies the
  following: if q(v^*)=1 for some v^*∈ H^1(G,) then ± v^*
  is a coedge.

  In other words, q is a metric on the lattice H^1(G,) and the
  nonzero ± e_i^* are among the shortest 
  (resp. exactly the shortest) integral vectors in this metric.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A cycle 2-cover {c_k, k=1,⋯ N} of a graph is called
  positive if the quadratic form q=1/2∑_k=1^N c_k^2 is
  positive definite.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A cycle in a graph Γ will be called a (0,1)-cycle if
  all directed edges appear in it with coefficients in {+1, 0,
  -1}; that is, the cycle is a sum of simple cycles with disjoint
  edge supports.

sentence:
The generating function of cores , graphs with minimum degree at least 2, is

    (z,w) = ∑_m ≥ 0 (2m)! [x^2m] P(z e^x,w,-1) e^z (e^x-1-x)w^m/2^m m!.

sentence:
A graph G is a pair (V(G), E(G)),
where V(G) is the labelled set of vertices,
and E(G) is the set of edges.
Each edge is a set of two vertices from V(G).
The number of vertices (resp. of edges) is n(G) = |V(G)|
(resp. m(G) = |E(G)|).
The excess k(G) is defined as m(G) - n(G).

The generating function of a family  of graphs is

    F(z,w) =
      ∑_G ∈
      w^m(G)z^n(G)/n(G)!,

and F_k(z) denotes the generating function of multigraphs from  with excess k,

    F_k(z) = [y^k] F(z/y,y).

sentence:
A loop (resp. double edge ) of a multigraph G is a subgraph (V, E) 
( i.e. V ⊂ V(G) and E ⊂ E(G))
isomorphic to the following left multigraph (resp. to one of the following right multigraphs).



    < g r a p h i c s >



The set of loops and double edges of a multigraph G is denoted by (G),
and its cardinality by (G).

sentence:
A patchwork with p parts
P = {(V_1, E_1), …, (V_p, E_p)}
is a set of p pairs (vertices, edges) such that

    (P) = ( ∪_i=1^p V_i, ∪_i=1^p E_i )

is a multigraph, and each (V_i, E_i) 
is either a loop or a double edge of (P), i.e. P ⊂((P)).

The number of parts of the patchwork is |P|.
Its number of vertices n(P), edges m(P), and its excess k(P)
are the corresponding numbers for (P).
See Figure <ref>.

sentence:
For k ∈, let M_k⊆ M denote the submodule of M generated by all elements of degree k.
	M is called componentwise linear if M_k has a linear resolution for all k.

sentence:
[Good paths and good homothets]
Let P be an (open or closed) convex polygon, let 𝒮 be a finite set of points, 
let :=(P,𝒮), and let P' be a homothet of P.


  * Let xyz be a 2-path in  (i.e., a simple path of length two).
If Cl(P') does not contain x and z and y is in the interior of P', then we say that it separates the 2-path xyz.

  * A 2-path xyz is good , if there is no homothet of P that separates it such that the edges yx and yz cross
the same side of this homothet of P (see Figure <ref> for an example).

    
    < g r a p h i c s >

	Considering homothets of an axis-parallel square, xyz is a good 2-path whereas xyq is not
	since the square Q' separates it and both xy and qy cross the left side of Q'.
	


  * A 3-path xyzw in  is good if both xyz and yzw are good 2-paths.

  * P' is good if it contains a good 3-path or [P'] contains a cycle.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Universally good polygons]
We say that an (open or closed) convex polygon P is universally good with a constant c_g:=c_g(P)
if for any finite set of points 𝒮 such that 𝒮 is in very general position with respect to P and (P,𝒮) is nice,
every homothet of P that contains at least c_g points from 𝒮 is good.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.>
The filling T: D_α→ℤ_+ is a semistandard Young composition tableau (SSYCT) of shape α if it satisfies the following conditions:


  * Row entries are weakly increasing from left to right (i.e., T(i,j)≤ T(i+1,j) for all (i,j), (i+1,j) ∈ D_α).

  * The entries in the leftmost column are strictly increasing from bottom to top (i.e., T(1,j)<T(1,j+1) for all (1,j), (1,j+1) ∈ D_α).

  * (Young composition triple rule)
For all {i,j,k} such that 1≤ j<k ≤ℓ(α) and 1≤ i<max {α_j,α_k}, if T(i,k) ≤ T(i+1,j), then T(i+1,k)<  T(i+1,j)
under the assumption that the entry in any cell not contained in D_α is ∞.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Read the entries in the columns of a Young composition tableau T (or its augmentation T̅) from top to bottom, beginning with the rightmost column of T and working right to left.  This ordering of the cells is called the Young reading order .  When the entries of the cells are read in Young reading order, the resulting word is called the Young reading word of T, denoted rw_(T).  See Figure  <ref> for an example.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.>
A filling U: D_α→ℤ_+ is an immaculate tableau of shape α if it satisfies the following conditions:






  * Row entries are weakly increasing from left to right (i.e., U(i,j)≤ U(i+1,j) for all (i,j), (i+1,j) ∈ D_α).

  * The entries in the leftmost column are strictly increasing from bottom to top (i.e., U(1,j)<U(1,j+1) for all (1,j), (1,j+1) ∈ D_α).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Read the entries in the rows of an immaculate tableau U, from left to right,  beginning with the highest row of U and working top to bottom.  The resulting word is called the immaculate reading word of U, denoted rw_(U).  See Figure <ref> for an example.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let α be a composition.  The dual immaculate quasisymmetric function _α is given by 
    _α=∑_U x^U,
 where the sum is over all immaculate tableaux of shape α.  See Figure <ref> for an example.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Q be a filling of a diagram for β n with the integers {1,…, n}, each appearing exactly once.  A row strip of Q is a maximal sequence of consecutive integers, none of which are in the same column of Q.  The row strip shape of Q is the composition (α_1,α_2,…, α_ℓ) where α_i is the length of the row strip sequence which starts with the number α_1+α_2+… +α_i-1+1.

sentence:
Let Q be a  filling of a diagram D_α for α n with the integers {1,…, n}.
We say that Q satisfies the recording triple rule if whenever Q(i,j)>Q(i,) where j> then Q(i,j)>Q(i+1,).  (If cell (i+1,) is empty, we consider it to contain the entry infinity.)  This is equivalent to the statement that if a>b then a>c in the subarray pictured below.  (Here we assume that if the position immediately to the right of b is empty, then c=∞.)


a




b     c

sentence:
Let β be a composition of n.  A filling of a diagram of shape β with exactly {1,…, n} is a dual immaculate  recording tableau (DIRT)  if it has the following properties:


  * The rows increase from left to right.

  * The row strips start in the first (leftmost) column.

  * The first (leftmost) column increases from top to bottom.


  * The  recording triple rule is satisfied.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An entry T(i,j) in a Young composition tableau T is said to be virtuous if the following hold.


  * The entry T(i,j)  is greater than all entries below it in its column.

  * The entry T(i,j) is at the end of its row.

  * Any other element which is at the end of its row in column i is in a row above j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A planar X-labelled rooted tree is a planar rooted tree T with no internal vertices having exactly one child, and with a labelling of all vertices fulfilling the following restrictions: 

 
  - every internal vertex v with m children is labelled by an element x_v∈ X_m;
 
  - every leaf of T is labelled by a positive integer in such a way that the following two conditions are satisfied:
 
  
  * (labelling set condition) the leaf labels are in one-to-one correspondence with the set [l]={1,2,…,l} (where l is the number of leaves of T);
  
  * (local increasing condition) if we temporarily assign to each internal vertex v the smallest of the labels of leaves that are descendants of v in T  (thus every vertex of T, should it be an internal vertex or a leaf, has an integer assigned to it), then for each internal vertex i the integers assigned to its children increase from the left to the right.
 

Notation: for i≥ 0, l≥ 1 we denote by ℒ𝒯_i,l(X) the set of planar X-labelled rooted trees with i internal vertices and l leaves, 

    ℒ𝒯_l(X)=⋃_i≥ 0ℒ𝒯_i,l(X)

is the set of planar X-labelled rooted trees with l leaves, 

    ℒ𝒯(X)=⋃_i≥ 0, l≥ 1ℒ𝒯_i,l(X)

is the set of all planar X-labelled rooted trees. In particular, ℒ𝒯_0,l(X) is non-empty only for l=1 (and in that case it consists of exactly one element, a one-vertex tree with no edges), and ℒ𝒯_1(X)=ℒ𝒯_0,1(X) (since every internal vertex has at least two children, hence in the presence of an internal vertex we end up with at least two leaves).

sentence:
Let  be a set of patterns in ℒ𝒯(X). A tree T together with a collection of its subtrees T_1,…,T_k is said to be a k-cluster if the following two conditions hold:

 
  * For every i, the subtree T_i is an occurrence of a pattern from : (T_i)∈,
 
  * for every edge e of T that joins two internal vertices, it is an edge between the two internal vertices of some T_i.
 
By definition, the set of 0-clusters is the set of labels X.

sentence:
* A (non-symmetric) collection is a contravariant functor from the category  to the category . We shall refer to images of individual sets as components of our collection.

  * Let  and  be two non-symmetric collections. The shuffle composition product of  and  is the non-symmetric collection ∘_sh defined by the formula
 
    (∘_sh)(I):=⊕_k(k)⊗(⊕_f I↠[k](f^-1(1))⊗…⊗(f^-1(k))),

where the sum is taken over all shuffling surjections f, that is surjections for which min f^-1(i)<min f^-1(j) whenever i<j.

  * A shuffle operad is a monoid in the category of non-symmetric collections equipped with the shuffle composition product.

sentence: A set T ⊂𝒞(A) is called balanced if it is possible to divide the set of orbits of elements of T into disjoint sets S_1,S_2,…,S_|A| such that all orbits in S_i have the same size and each element of S_i overlaps with at least one other element of S_i. We will denote the size of the orbits in S_i by a_i.

sentence: Given a split set of cycles T ⊂ S_n, the cycle graph Cyc(T) is formed by associating each vertex with an element of N and drawing edges x_1x_2,x_2x_3,…,x_k-1x_k if (x_1  x_2  … x_k) is in T. Note that this involves arbitrarily choosing a “starting” and “ending” point for each cycle in T. When T consists of transpositions, Feng <cit.> refers to Cyc(T) as Tra(T).

sentence: Given a split set of cycles T, the degree of some t ∈ T is defined as the number of distinct points in its support that overlap with other cycles. If t has degree 1, we call it a leaf .

    mw=a_1^w_1a_2^w_2… a_m^w_ma_1^w_m+1a_2^w_m+2… a_m^w_2m….
 
Any word isomorphic to mw is called an m-cyclic w-word .

sentence:
A  weakly chordal graph G is said to be compact if every subgraph H of G either


  (i)  is a complete graph,  or 

  (ii) contains a 2-pair {x, y} such that N_H(x) ⊆ N_H(y), or

  (iii) contains a 2-pair {x, y} such that C_x ∪ S(x, y) induces a clique on at most three vertices.

sentence:
Node n_i is forward-connected to node-n_j if and only if there exists an additive combination of k_1th, k_2th, ⋯, k_pth and jth columns of 𝐀 such that  C^𝐀_k_1+C^𝐀_k_2+⋯+C^𝐀_k_p+C^𝐀_j=X_j^N-X_i^N where i<k_1<k_2<...<k_p<j.
	
		Necessity: n_i is forward connected to n_j. This means either n_i is forward-adjacent to n_j, i.e., C^𝐀_j=X_j^N-X_i^N, in which case the condition is proved; or there exists a sequence of forward-connected nodes in between n_i and n_j that creates the route R_i→ j. For the latter case, nodes n_k_1, n_k_2, ..., n_k_p exist with i<k_1<k_2<...<k_p<j such that
		
			
  * n_i is forward adjacent to n_k_1 ⇒ C^𝐀_k_1=X_k_1^N-X_i^N
			
  * each n_k_β is forward-adjacent to n_k_β+1 ∀  1<β<p-1   ⇒ C^𝐀_k_β+1=X_k_β+1^N-X_k_β^N
			
  * n_k_p is forward adjacent to n_j ⇒ C^𝐀_j=X_j^N-X_k_p^N
		
	(Note: k_1, k_2, ..., k_p are not necessarily consecutive integers.) Now, clearly the sum C^𝐀_k_1+C^𝐀_k_2+⋯+C^𝐀_k_p+C^𝐀_j is equal to X_j^N-X_i^N. Thus, the condition is necessary.
	
	Sufficiency: There exists an additive combination C^𝐀_k_1+C^𝐀_k_2+⋯+C^𝐀_k_p+C^𝐀_j with i<k_1<k_2<...<k_p<j such that the sum is X_j^N-X_i^N. It is required to prove that n_i is forward connected to n_j. Let, C^𝐀_k_1=X_k_1^N-X_k_1'^N, C^𝐀_k_2=X_k_2^N-X_k_2'^N, ..., C^𝐀_k_p=X_k_p^N-X_k_p'^N, C^𝐀_j=X_j^N-X_j'^N (this consideration is based on Lemma <ref>). Now,
	
    X_j^N-X_i^N    =    C^𝐀_k_1+C^𝐀_k_2+⋯+C^𝐀_k_p+C^𝐀_j
       =    (X_k_1^N-X_k_1'^N)+(X_k_2^N-X_k_2'^N)+...+(X_k_p^N-X_k_p'^N)+(X_j^N-X_j'^N)
       =    (X_k_1^N+X_k_2^N+...+X_k_p^N)+X_j^N-(X_k_1'^N+X_k_2'^N+...+X_k_p'^N+X_j'^N)
    ⇒ X_k_1'^N+X_k_2'^N+...+X_k_p'^N+X_j'^N    =    (X_k_1^N+X_k_2^N+...+X_k_p^N)+X_i^N

	In (<ref>), it is easily seen that both sides contain p+1 vectors and vectors in the right hand side are mutually independent. Thus, by Fact-III, each column in the left hand side should be equal to one in the right side.
	
	Now consider X_k_1'. C_k_1^𝐀=X_k_1-X_k_1' and therefore k_1'≠ k_1. If X_k_1'= X_k_β where β>1, this would imply k_1'=k_β>k_1 which is a contradiction since k_1<k_2<...<k_p. Therefore, we must have X_k_1'=X_i^N. Following the same logic, X_k_β'=X_k_β-1^N  ∀ β=2,...,p. For the last element, X_j'^N=X_k_p^N.
	
	Therefore, n_i is forward adjacent to n_k_1, n_k_β is forward adjacent to n_k_β+1 ∀ β=1,2,...,p-1 and n_k_p is forward adjacent to n_j. Thus, n_i is forward connected to n_j.

sentence: n_i is said to be forward-adjacent to n_k, if n_i is adjacent to n_k and i<k.

sentence:
n_i is said to be forward-connected to n_j if it is possible to go from n_i to n_j by strictly traveling forward . The route for traveling forward from n_i to n_j is denoted as R_i→ j.
	
		The node n_i is forward-adjacent to n_j is the simplest case of n_i being forward connected to n_j. It is obvious that if n_i is forward-connected but not forward-adjacent to n_j, there should exist one or more forward-adjacent nodes n_k_β where i<k_β<j. Mathematically, in such a case, there will exist nodes n_k_1, n_k_2, ..., n_k_p (1≤ p<j-i) [The inequality 1≤ p<j-i comes because n_i and n_j cannot have more than j-i-1 nodes in between them. Consider n_2 and n_5 for example. The intermediate nodes are n_3 and n_4, so 5-2-1=2. Of course, this number can be less than this. Consider n_10 and n_2 for instance. There are two intermediate nodes: n_3 and n_9 which is less than 10-2-1=7.] such that n_k_β is forward-adjacent to n_k_β+1 ∀ 1≤β≤ p-1. According to Definition <ref>, this implies i<k_1<k_2<...<k_p<j.

sentence:
Let G=(V_G,E_G) be a graph and consider an edge-colouring χ_G of E_G.
Given positive  and d, and positive integers ℓ, ℓ' and k, we say that G has an (,d)-regular (ℓ,ℓ',k)-cm-shape under χ_G if there exists a tree T on vertex set {x_1,…,x_ℓ,y_1,…,y_ℓ,z_1,…,z_ℓ'} containing a matching E_M={x_iy_i i=1,…,ℓ} with an 
even distance in T between any x_i and x_j for all 1≤ i<j≤ℓ, and there exists a partition {V_0,V_1,…,V_k} of V_G with |V_1|=…=|V_k|≥ (1-)|V_G|/k such that the spanning subgraph of G spanned by one of the colours is (ε,d)-regular on T.

sentence:
Let G be a simple graph with n vertices and let L be a list assignment for G.
For each v ∈ V(G), let L_v = {v}× L(v).
For each edge uv ∈ E(G), let M_uv be a matching (possibly empty) between the sets L_u and L_v, and let _L = {M_uv : uv ∈ E(G)}, called the matching assignment .
Let G_L be a graph that satisfies the following conditions:


  * V(G_L) = ∪_v ∈ V(G) L_v,

  * for each v ∈ V(G), the set L_v is a clique in G_L,

  * if uv ∈ E(G), then the edges between L_u and L_v are exactly those of M_uv, and

  * if uv ∉ E(G), then there are no edges between L_u and L_v.

We say that G has an _L-coloring if G_L contains an independent set of size n.
The graph G is DP-k-colorable if, for any list assignment L with |L(v)| = k for each v ∈ V(G), the graph is _L-colorable for every matching assignment _L.
The least k such that G is DP-k-colorable is the DP-chromatic number of G, denoted χ_DP(G).

sentence: We define a three-step layer-stripping operation to be a sequence of boundary edge deletion, isolated boundary vertex deletion, and boundary spike contraction (in that order).  Multiple edges or vertices are allowed to be removed at each step; however, if multiple boundary spikes are contracted, then they are not allowed to share any endpoints with each other.  We allow any one of the three steps to be trivial, and thus a simple layer-stripping operation can be considered a three-step layer-stripping operation.  We allow infinitely many vertices or edges to be removed if the ∂-graph is infinite.

sentence:
We say that (𝐰(n))_n ≥ 1 is regular , if it has the following 
properties.

  
  * [Weak convergence of weight] There is a distribution function
F:[0,∞)→ [0,1] such that for all x at which F is continuous
lim_n→∞F_n(x) = F(x).

  * [Convergence of average weight] Let W_n be a random variable with
distribution function F_n, and let W_F be a random variable with
distribution function F. Then lim_n→∞W_n = W_F < ∞.

  * [Non-degeneracy] There is a x_0 ∈ℝ^+ such that F_n(x) = 0 for all x ∈ [0,x_0) and  n ∈ℕ.

If M is a weak map image of N and further (M)⊂(N), we call M a quotient of N. Note that ≺ defines a partial order on the class of all matroids.

sentence: Let M be a matroid on E of rank r>1. The truncation of M is the (unique) matroid T of rank r-1 with (T)=_<r(M)∪ E. Thus, T ≺ M. A matroid N is an erection of M if the truncation of N is isomorphic to M. We further say M is the trivial erection of itself.

sentence: Let n ∈ℕ, and let ℱ be a family of non-empty 3-graphs. The Turán number ex(n, ℱ) of ℱ  is the largest number e=e(n) such that there exists an n-vertex 3-graph with at least e 3-edges and no member of ℱ as a subgraph.

sentence:
The Turán density of a family of non-empty 3-graphs ℱ is the limit

    π(ℱ)=lim_n →∞ex(n, ℱ)/n3.

sentence: Let n ∈ℕ and let ℱ be a family of non-empty 3-graphs. The codegree threshold of ℱ coex(n, ℱ)  is the largest number d=d(n) such that there exists an n-vertex 3-graph in which every pair of vertices is contained in at least d  3-edges but which contains no member of ℱ as a subgraph.

sentence:
Let P = p_1 p_2 ⋯ p_m+r and Q = q_1 q_2 ⋯ q_m+r be two lattice paths 
      from (0,0) to (m, r) with P never going above Q.
      Let { p_u_1, p_u_2, …, p_u_r} be the set of North steps of P, 
      with u_1 < u_2 < ⋯ < u_r;
      similarly, let { q_l_1, q_l_2, …, q_l_r} be the set of North steps of Q
      with l_1 < l_2 < ⋯ < l_r.
      Let N_i be the interval [l_i, u_i] of integers.
      Let M(P,Q) be the transversal matroid 
      that has ground set [m+r] and presentation { N_i: i ∈ [r] }.
      The pair (P,Q) is a lattice path presentation of M(P,Q).
      A lattice path matroid is a matroid M 
      that is isomorphic to M(P,Q) for some such pair of lattice paths P and Q.
      We will sometimes call a lattice path presentation of M simply a presentation of M
      when there is no danger of confusion and when doing so avoids awkward repetition.

sentence: A de Bruijn sequence of order n is a sequence of length 2^n of elements of 𝔽_2 in which all different n-tuples appear exactly once.

sentence: A modified de Bruijn sequence of order n is a sequence of length 2^n-1 obtained from a de Bruijn sequence of order n by removing one zero from the tuple of n consecutive zeros.

sentence:
Let x_1, …, x_t ∈ N=^2 be non-zero lattice points, and define x_0:=x_t, x_t+1 := x_1. 
We say {x_1, …, x_t} is the set of boundary lattice points P ∩ N of an l-reflexive loop P of length t if the following three conditions are satisfied for each i=1,…,t:


  * the lattice point x_i+1-x_i is primitive;

  * the determinant of the 2× 2-matrix A_i formed by x_i, x_i+1 equals ± l;

  * if x_i is a vertex (i.e. x_i ∉x_i-1,x_i+1) then it is primitive.

The length of P is defined as ∑_i=1^t (A_i)/l. The set of facets of P is naturally given as the set of line segments between successive vertices. Note that an l-reflexive loop may be a non-convex or self-intersecting polygonal loop (see Figure <ref>).

For i=1, …, t, let u_i be the primitive outer normal to the segment x_i,x_i+1. Then 

    ⋃_i=1^t u_i,u_i+1∩ M

is the set of boundary lattice points of the dual l-reflexive loop l P^ (see Figure <ref>). We leave it to the reader to check that this is well-defined and duality as in Proposition <ref> generalizes to this setting.
