plain_text_term: boundary lattice points;l-reflexive loop;of length t;vertex;length of P;facets;dual l-reflexive loop

sentence:
Let X be a finite T_0–space and let A⊆ X. We will say that A is a dbp–retract (resp. ubp–retract ) of X if A can be obtained from X by successively removing down beat points (resp. up beat points), that is, if there exist n∈_0 and a sequence X=X_0⊇ X_1⊇⋯⊇ X_n=A of subspaces of X such that, for all i∈{1,…,n}, the space X_i is obtained from X_i-1 by removing a single down beat point (resp. up beat point) of X_i-1.
	
	We will say that A is a bp–retract of X if A is either a dbp–retract or a ubp–retract of X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X and Y be finite T_0–spaces and let f X→ Y be a continuous function. The non-Hausdorff mapping cylinder of f is the space B(f) whose underlying set is X∐ Y and whose topology is induced by the following order in B(f):
	
		z≤z' in B(f) if and only if 
		
			z≤z' in X    if z,z'∈ X,

			f(z)≤z' in Y    if z∈ X and z'∈ Y, or

			z≤z' in Y    if z,z'∈ Y.
		  
	
	The canonical inclusion maps of X and Y into B(f) will be denoted by j_X and j_Y, respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a finite 3-free set A={a_0,…,a_n}⊂_0, the Stanley sequence generated by A is the infinite sequence S(A)={a_0,a_1,…} defined by the following recursion. If k≥ n and a_0<…<a_k have been defined, let a_k+1 be the smallest integer a>a_k such that {a_0,…, a_k}∪{a} is 3-free. Though formally one writes S({a_0,…,a_n}), we will frequently use the notation S(a_0,…,a_n) instead.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Stanley sequence S(A)=(a_n) is independent if there exists constants λ=λ(A) and κ=κ(A) such that for all k≥κ and 0≤ i<2^k, we have 


  * 
a_2^k+i=a_2^k+a_i


  * 
a_2^k=2a_2^k-1-λ+1.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A be a set of integers and z be an integer. We say that z is covered by A if there exist x,y∈ A such that x<y and 2y-x=z. We frequently say that z is covered by x and y.

Suppose that N is a positive integer. If x,y,z∈{0,…,N-1} and x y, we say they form an arithmetic progression modulo N, or a mod-AP if 2y-x≡ z N. 

Suppose again that N is a positive integer and A⊆{0,…,N-1}. Then, we say that z is covered by A modulo N , or mod-covered , if there exist x,y∈ A with x<y such that x,y,z form an arithmetic progression modulo N.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Fix a positive integer N≥ 1. Suppose the set A⊂{0,…,N-1} containing 0 is 3-free modulo N, and all x∈{0,…,N-1}\ A are covered by A modulo N. Then A is said to be a modular set modulo N and S(A) is said to be a modular Stanley sequence modulo N .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: modular set modulo N;modular Stanley sequence modulo N

sentence:
[Bessel kernel asymptotics at the hard edge, complex case]<cit.> Let m ≥ 1 be an integer, and let f ∈ L^∞(^m) be a symmetric function. Then the expression

    ∑_1 ≤ i_1 < … < i_m ≤ n f( 4n σ_i_1(M_n(_))^2, …, 4n σ_i_m(M_n(_F))^2 )

converges as n →∞ to the limit

    ∫_^n f(t_1,…,t_m) ( K_0(t_i,t_j) )_1 ≤ i,j ≤ m dt_1 … dt_m

where K_0 is the Bessel kernel

    K_0(x,y) := J_0(x^1/2) y^1/2 J_1(y^1/2) - J_1(y^1/2) x^1/2 J_0(x^1/2)/2(x-y),

where J_ν is the Bessel function

    J_ν(x) = 1/2π∫_-π^π e^-i(ν t - x sin t) dt.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a cyclic word W composed of the letters P, C, and E.  Then the toggling of W is W^T, the word formed by taking W and replacing every P by C and every C by P. The occurrences of E are unchanged.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be an undirected (weighted) graph.  Then a decomposition , D, is a subgraph consisting of disjoint edges and cycles.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A tuple (G_1, G_2, … G_k, H, H_1, H_2, … H_k) is a gluing of G_1 … G_k if


  * H is a connected graph

  * H_1, … H_k are subgraphs of H

  * H_i∼ G_i for all i ∈ [k]

  * ∪_i=1^k E(H_i)=E(H).

We occasionally refer to H itself as a gluing.  The tuple (H_1, … H_k) is a decomposition of H.  If there exists only one tuple H_1, … H_k such that (G_1, … G_k, H, H_1, … H_k) is a gluing, we say that (G_1, … G_k, H) is uniquely decomposable .  In this case, we say that H[S] is the unique subgraph of H induced by {H_i}_i ∈ S.  We occasionally say that H itself is uniquely decomposable, if G_1, … G_k are clear from context.  If there exists an H such that (G_1, … G_k, H) is uniquely decomposable, we say that {G_1, … G_k} is uniquely composable .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Given a graph H_S for each S ∈π, s_π(T)(G') is the number of ways G' may be split into { H_S}_ S ∈π(T).  If there exists some {H_S}_S ∈π such that s_π([k])(G') ≠ 0, say that G' is compatible with π.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Given A=⊔_i=1^k G_i and a uniquely decomposable gluing 
H with decomposition (H_1, … H_k), the structure graph of H, denoted by T(H), is the graph whose vertices are [k] and edges are pairs i,j such that H_i∩ H_j is non-empty.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given A=⊔_i=1^k G_i, a gluing H is tree-like if it is uniquely decomposable and its structure graph, T(H), is a tree.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given G_1 and G_2 and vertices v_1∈ V(G_1) and v_2∈ V(G_2), to glue v_1 and v_2 to create a new graph H_v is the natural identification: 
    V(H_v)=(V(G_1)∖{v_1})∪ (V(G_2)∖{v_2}) ∪{v}
 and 
    E(H_v)={{x,y} | {x,y}∈ E(G_1) ∪ E(G_2)}∪{{x,v} | {x,v_1}∈ E(G_1)}∪{{v,y} |{v_2,y}∈ E(G_2)}.
  Given G_1 and G_2 and edges {u_1, v_1}=e_1 ∈ G_1 and {u_2,v_2}=e_2 ∈ G_2, to glue e_1 and e_2 to create a new graph H_e is the natural identification: 
    V(H_e)=(V(G_1)∖{u_1,v_1})∪ (V(G_2)∖{u_2, v_2}) ∪{v}
 and

    E(H_v)={{x,y} | {x,y}∈ E(G_1) ∪ E(G_2)}∪{{x,u} | {x,u_1}∈ E(G_1)∪{{x,u} | {x,u_2}∈ E(G_2)
    
    ∪{{x,v} | {x,v_1}∈ E(G_1)}∪{{x,v_2,y} |{x, v_2}∈ E(G_2)}.

sentence:
For each hyperplane H, the set nonempty ℑ={V_1,…,V_n} of hyperplanes is a separating chain for H if


  * Each V_i∈ℑ separates H from U.

  * If V_i,V_j∈ℑ are separated by a hyperplane V, then V∈ℑ.

  * The hyperplanes in ℑ are pairwise non-crossing.

  * 𝔍 is not properly contained in a set of hyperplanes satisfying (1)-(3).

These properties ensure that the halfspaces of the V_i∈ℑ can be labeled 𝐀 or 𝐁 so that {𝐁(V_i)}_V_i∈ℑ is totally ordered by inclusion.  Let 𝕀(H) be the set of all separating chains for H.  The hyperplane-distance of H (with respect to U) is

    d(H)=min{|ℑ|:ℑ∈𝕀(H)}.

If C is a collection of hyperplanes (or a subgraph of Γ(𝐗)), we let D(C)=∑_H∈ Cd(H).

Note that the combinatorial distance d_G(𝐗)(N(H),N(U)) in G(𝐗)=𝐗^(1) between the carriers of H and U counts the hyperplanes that separate U from H, since carriers are convex, and that d(H) is bounded above by this quantity.  Note also that d(H)=0 if and only if H U.

sentence:
[Contact graph, crossing graph]
The contact graph Γ( X) of X is the graph whose vertex set is the set ℋ, with an edge joining the vertices H_1 and H_2 if H_1 H_2.  We use the same notation for a vertex of Γ( X) as for its corresponding hyperplane, and we use the notation H_1 H_2 for the (closed) edge of Γ( X) joining the contacting hyperplanes H_1 and H_2.

The crossing graph X is the subgraph of Γ( X) obtained by deleting each open edge corresponding to an osculating pair of hyperplanes, so that H_1 and H_2 are adjacent in X if and only if they cross.

Given hyperplanes U,V∈ℋ, we denote by ρ(U,V) the distance in Γ( X) from U to V.

sentence:
[Trigon, trigon along the boundary]
Let D→ X be a disc diagram with boundary path P.  If K_1,K_2,K_3 are distinct pairwise crossing dual curves in D, then they form a trigon of dual curves , as at left in Figure <ref>.

Let c_1 and c_2 be distinct 1-cubes of P, and let c_1Qc_2 be one of the paths on P subtended by c_1 and c_2.  For i∈{1,2}, let K_i be the dual curve in D emanating from c_i.  Suppose that K_1 and K_2 cross, and there exists a hyperplane H such that the image of c_1Qc_2 lies in N(H), with neither c_1 nor c_2 dual to H.  Then the pair K_1,K_2 forms a trigon along the boundary of D .  See the middle of Figure <ref>.

  
    < g r a p h i c s >


  At left is a trigon of dual curves, which is in general possible in a minimal-area diagram, but which cannot occur in two dimensions.  In the center is a trigon along the boundary, which is always disallowed by minimality of area in our diagrams.  At right is a grid.

[Hyperplane-distance]

For each hyperplane H, the set nonempty ℑ={V_1,…,V_n} of hyperplanes is a separating chain for H if


  * Each V_i∈ℑ separates H from U.

  * If V_i,V_j∈ℑ are separated by a hyperplane V, then V∈ℑ.

  * The hyperplanes in ℑ are pairwise non-crossing.

  * 𝔍 is not properly contained in a set of hyperplanes satisfying (1)-(3).

These properties ensure that the halfspaces of the V_i∈ℑ can be labeled 𝐀 or 𝐁 so that {𝐁(V_i)}_V_i∈ℑ is totally ordered by inclusion.  Let 𝕀(H) be the set of all separating chains for H.  The hyperplane-distance of H (with respect to U) is

    d(H)=min{|ℑ|:ℑ∈𝕀(H)}.

If C is a collection of hyperplanes (or a subgraph of Γ(𝐗)), we let D(C)=∑_H∈ Cd(H).

Note that the combinatorial distance d_G(𝐗)(N(H),N(U)) in G(𝐗)=𝐗^(1) between the carriers of H and U counts the hyperplanes that separate U from H, since carriers are convex, and that d(H) is bounded above by this quantity.  Note also that d(H)=0 if and only if H U.

sentence:
[Ball, sphere, cluster]
For each r≥ 0, the (full) ball B_r:=B_r(H_0) is the full (i.e., induced) subgraph of Γ( X) generated by the set of hyperplanes H with g(H)≤ r.  The (full) sphere S_r:=S_r(H_0) is the full subgraph of Γ( X) generated by the set of hyperplanes H with g(H)=r.

Let H,H'∈ S_r be hyperplanes.  Then H∼ H' if and only if there exists a path P in Γ( X) joining H to H' such that every vertex of P corresponds to a hyperplane of grade at least r.  This defines an equivalence relation on the grade-r hyperplanes.  An equivalence class of hyperplanes of grade r is called a grade-r cluster .

sentence:
[Realization, canonical path]
Let H_0 H_1 H_2 be a path in Γ.  An edge-realization of H_0 H_1 H_2 is a combinatorial geodesic P→ N(H_1) that joins N(H_0) to N(H_2).  If γ=H_0 H_1 H_2… H_r is an embedded path in Γ, then a realization of γ is a path (γ)=R_1R_2… R_r-1, where each R_i is a realization of the path H_i-1H_iH_i+1.

Let γ=H_0 H_1… H_r=H be a geodesic path in Γ( X).  The weight ||γ|| of γ is the ordered r-tuple (|R_r-1|,|R_r-2|,…,|R_1|), where (γ)=R_1R_2… R_r-1 is a realization such that the previous r-tuple is minimal in the lexicographic order as (γ) varies among realizations of γ.

A path γ(H)=H_0 H_1… H_r=H is a canonical path for H if ||γ(H)|| is minimal (in the lexicographic order) among all paths γ of Γ( X) joining H_0 to H.
The hyperplane
f^2(H)=H_r-2 is called  the grandfather of H (with respect to γ(H)).

sentence:
[Root class, incoming neighbour, outgoing neighbour]
The vertices of Υ(U) can be partitioned into subsets according to their roots: for each vertex b of U, let ℛ'_b be the set of hyperplanes H∈ℛ(U) such that b_H=b.  In other words, ℛ'_b is the set of hyperplanes H such that the iterated imprint IJ(H,U) is rooted at b.  The set ℛ'_b is the root class associated to the root b.

Let H∈ℛ'_b and let V=f(H) be its father.  The hyperplane H'∈ℛ(U) is an incoming neighbour of H if HH' is an edge of Υ(U) (and in particular H H'), and the iterated imprint IJ(H',U) contains b (and in particular H'≺ H).

More intuitively, H' is an incoming neighbour of H if HH' is an edge of Υ(U) and H'≺ H.  Denote by ℐ_b(H) the set of incoming neighbours of H.

By Lemma <ref>, for each H'∈ℐ_b(H), we have that f(H') contacts a potential father of H that crosses U.  If H' is adjacent to H in Υ(U) and H' is not an incoming neighbour, then by Lemma <ref>, H≺ H', and we call H' an outgoing neighbour of H.

sentence: For a subset S of a group G, define S to be a primitive subset of G, if S is not contained in a coset of a proper subgroup of G and S is not a union of cosets of a nontrivial subgroup in G. For a formally dual pair S and T in G, it is a primitive formally dual pair, if both S and T are primitive subsets.

sentence:
[Lattices, submodularity, consecutivity]

	Let E be a finite set, ℒ⊆ 2^E and ≼ be a partial order on ℒ. The pair (ℒ, ≼) is a lattice if for all S, T ∈ℒ the following conditions are fulfilled.
	
	 
  * {L ∈ℒ : L ≼ S, L ≼ T } has a unique maximum element S ∧ T, called meet .
	 
  * {U ∈ℒ : U ≽ S, U ≽ T } has a unique minimum element S ∨ T, called join .
	
	A function r : ℒ→ℝ is submodular if r(S ∧ T) + r(S ∨ T) ≤ r(S) + r(T) for all S, T ∈ℒ. It is supermodular , if r(S ∧ T) + r(S ∨ T) ≥ r(S) + r(T) for all S, T ∈ℒ.
 A lattice ℒ is submodular , if (S ∧ T) ∩ (S ∨ T) ⊆ S ∩ T  and  (S ∧ T) ∪ (S ∨ T) ⊆ S ∪ T for all S, T ∈ℒ.[Submodularity of lattices is connected to submodularity of functions in the following way: A lattice is sub­modular if and only if all functions of the type f(S) := ∑_e ∈ S x(e) for some vector x ∈ℝ_+^E are submodular.]  It is consecutive if S ∩ U ⊆ T for all S, T, U ∈ℒ with S ≼ T ≼ U.

sentence:
[Walk, path, cycle]
	An x-y-walk is a non-empty sequence of darts d_1, …, d_k such that (d_i) = (d_i+1) for i ∈{1, …, k - 1} and x = (d_1) and y = (d_k). If for all darts of an x-y-walk the underlying edges are pairwise distinct, then the walk is called x-y-path for x ≠ y or cycle if x = y. A path or cycle is called simple if the heads of all its darts are pairwise distinct.

 Let P, Q ∈𝒫. If Φ(δ_P - δ_Q) ≥ 0, we say that P is left of Q and write P  Q. If  Φ(δ_P - δ_Q) ≤ 0, we say that P is right of Q and write P  Q.

sentence: Let G be a graph and let 𝒫 = {G_1,…,G_t} be a packing of the graph G. We say that another packing 𝒫' of G is a repacking of 𝒫 if 𝒫' = {G'_1,…,G'_t} where for each i ∈{1,…,t} there is a permutation π_i of V(G) such that π_i(G_i)=G'_i and x and π_i(x) are twin for each x ∈ V(G).

sentence:
Let f:𝔽_q^d→𝔽_q be a given function.


  * We say that f is a strong expander if there exists an
ϵ>0 such that for all |A|≳ q^1-ϵ one has
that |f(A, …, A)|≥ q-k for a fixed constant k.

  * We say that f
is a moderate expander if there exists an ϵ>0 such
that for |A|≳ q^1-ϵ one has that |f(A, …,
A)|≳ q.

  * We say that f is a weak expander if there exist an
ϵ>0 and a δ < 1 such that for all |A|≳
q^1-ϵ  one has that |f(A, …, A)|≳
|A|^δq^1-δ.

sentence:
Let G be a finite group, and suppose that 𝒦 is a partition of G into unions of conjugacy classes and 𝒳 is a set of characters of G. We say that the pair (𝒦,𝒳) is a supercharacter theory of G if


  (SCT1) |𝒳|=|𝒦|,

  (SCT2) the characters χ∈𝒳 are constant on the blocks of 𝒦, and

  (SCT3) each irreducible character of G is a constituent of exactly one character in 𝒳.

The characters χ∈𝒳 are referred to as supercharacters and the blocks K ∈𝒦 are called superclasses.

sentence:
We say that a finite family of convex sets  is k-colored if each set K∈ is colored with (at least) one of k distinct colors. The k-coloring of  can be expressed by writing  as a union of k color classes _1∪_2∪…∪_k, where each class _i consists of the sets with color i∈ [k].
    We say that the k-colored family , with color classes _1,…,_k, has the Colorful Helly property, or (_1,…,_k) if every rainbow selection K_i∈_i, for 1≤ i≤ k, has non-empty intersection ⋂_i=1^kK_i≠∅.

sentence: The lattice-isomorphism between the power-set 𝒫(V) and the interval [B,G] realizes as a map W ↦ P_W such that P_W = U_W ⋊ L_W (Levi Decomposition) where U_W (called the unipotent subgroup) decomposes into a product of root subgroups (each of them being isomorphic to the additive group of the field 𝕂) where each element admits a unique decomposition, and L_W (called a Levi subgroup) is isomorphic to the direct product of the Chevalley groups (over 𝕂) corresponding to the connected components of X_W.

The following identities hold.

    T(G; k/b+1 ,kb+1)    =  ∑   (b+1)^(ϕ)     b^(ϕ),
    
    
     k^κ(G)  R(G;k+1,k,1/k,1)    = ∑ 2^(ϕ),
    
         k^κ(G)  b^r(G)   R(G;  (k+b)/b, bk, 1/k)       = ∑   (b+1)^(ϕ)     b^(ϕ),
    
    
    P(G;k)    =  #Admissible k-valuations of  G_m,
    
    
    P(G;k)    = ∑  (-1)^(ϕ),
    
    
    P(G;-k)    = (-1)^f(G)∑  2^(ϕ),
    
    
      Q(G; ( α, β , γ ), k)    = ∑   (α+β+γ)^(ϕ)α^(ϕ)β^(ϕ)γ^(ϕ).

Here the sums in (<ref>)–(<ref>) are over all k-valuations ϕ of G_m that contain no crossing configurations. An admissible k-valuation is one that contains no black configurations, and the sums in (<ref>) and (<ref>) are over all admissible k-valuations of G_m. The sum in (<ref>) is over all k-valuations ϕ of G_m. Furthermore,  in (<ref>) and (<ref>) G must be plane, and in (<ref>) the Petrie dual (defined in Section <ref>) of the geometric dual of G must be orientable for the identity to hold.

sentence: An edge-point ribbon graph is an object obtained from a ribbon graph G=(V,E) by contracting  each edge in some (possibly empty) subset B of E to a point. We call the points created by such a process singular points . The image of edges under the contraction that are not singular points are called edges . Its pinched-vertices are components of the images of vertices (including the singular points) under the contraction.

sentence:
Let k be a natural number, and G be an edge-point ribbon graph. 
A  k-valuation of G_m  is an edge k-colouring of G_m such that each vertex is incident to an even number (possibly zero) of edges of each colour, and all edges incident to a singular vertex are of the same colour.  

If G_m is canonically checkerboard coloured then the four possible configurations of colours about a vertex, are white , black , crossing , or total ,  as described in Figure <ref>. Singular vertices are always total. 
 We let (ϕ) denote the number of non-singular total vertices in a k-valuation ϕ.

sentence:
For a given subset G⊆^k we define its -hull
as the smallest set ⟨ G ⟩_⊇ G satisfying
the following recursive property:
If a∈⟨ G ⟩_∩(^j×^k-j) 
for some j=0,…,k-1, then so is the shift 
a-v_j+1∈⟨ G ⟩_.

Note that 
a-v_j+1∈^j×-ℓ_j+1×^k-j-1.
Hence, building ⟨ G ⟩_ out of G can be done 
by enlarging ⟨ G ⟩_ successively with increasing j.

A HERG  G(V,E,H), or simply G_H, 
is a ribbon graph G(V,E)  with a set H of HRs together with an incidence relation which associates each HR with a unique vertex. The ribbon graph G is called the underlying ribbon graph of G_H. There is an
underlying HEG (V,E,H), denoted _H, obtained from G_H by keeping its
vertex, edge and half-edge sets and their incidence relation.

sentence:
[Completed and pruned graphs]
Let  _h=(, ,h) be an HEG and h_0∈ h be one of its 
half-edges incident to a vertex v_0. 

 Completing h_0∈ h in _h is the operation which replaces h_0 by an edge e_0 by adding a new vertex v_1 in the vertex set of _h such that e_0 is incident to v_0 and v_1. 
 The completed graph =(∪_h, ∪ h), 
 with |_h|=|h|,  
is the graph obtained after  completing all half-edges in _h. 

Consider a leaf v_0∈ in a HEG _h and e_0∈ the edge
incide to v_0. 

Pruning e_0∈ in _h is the operation which replaces e_0 by
a half-edge h_0 by removing v_0 from the vertex set of _h. 
Let _0 be a subset of leaves in , and _0=_0(_0) be the set of all edges
incident to the leaves in _0. 
 The pruned HEG with respect to _0,  _ h'(_0)=(∖_0, ∖_0, h'(_0) = h∪_0), is the HEG obtained from _h by pruning all leaves in _0.

sentence:
[Closed and open faces]

Consider  a HERG G_H.
A closed face is a boundary  component of G_H  which never intersects any external segment of an HR.  The set of closed faces is denoted _.  An open  face  is a boundary arc between an external point of some HR and another external point  without intersecting any external segment of an HR.  
 The set of open faces is denoted  _. 
 The set of faces  of G_H is defined by 
_∪_. (See illustrations on Figure <ref>.)

sentence:
[Grafting and grafted graph]
The grafting operation on a cycle l ∈ L_h
circumventing a boundary circle c_l and incident to v^*, consists 
in  removing all edges of l and the vertices where these edges are incident except v^*, 
then inserting  |l| embedded edges e^*_l,k, k=1,…,|l|, 
respecting the cyclic ordering around v^* and keeping all remaining edges and vertices untouched.
The edges e^*_l,k are incident to v^* and to new vertices v_l,k on c_l.
 
The grafted graph _1;L_h=_1(_1,_1) with respect to L_h 
is the graph with vertex set 
 _1=^* ∖(L_h) ∪{v_l,k}_l ∈ L_h and edge 
_1 = ^* ∖ L_h ∪{e^*_l,k}_l ∈ L_h
obtained after  performing a sequence of grafting operations
 on ^*,  for all   l∈ L_h.

sentence:
The Hirota equations are the Plücker equations for
the embedding of the semi-infinite Grassmanian into the projectivized
wedge product PΛ^∞/2V. Solutions of the Hirota equations
(that is, semi-infinite planes) are called the
τ-functions of the KP hierarchy.

The form the Hirota equations acquire for logarithms of
τ-functions is called the
Kadomtsev–Petviashvili hierarchy .

sentence:
The Jucys–Murphy elements of the group algebra ℂ S_n
are the following sums of transpositions:

    X_1=0,  
    X_2=(1,2),  
    X_3=(1,3)+(2,3),  
    X_4=(1,4)+(2,4)+(3,4),  …,

i.e.,

    X_k=∑_i=1^k-1(i,k),    
    k=1,2,…,n.

by a substitution of the form

sentence:
Let D be a finite set. A map with the set of half-edges D
on an oriented surface is a triple of permutations α, φ, σ
of the set D possessing the following properties:

– α is an involution without fixed points;

– the product φασ is the identity permutation.

The group G=⟨α,φ,σ⟩ of permutations of the set D
generated by the permutations α, φ, σ,
is called the cartographic group of the map.
The map is said to be connected if its cartographic group acts
on the set D transitively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let C be column and I = { z_1 > … > z_k } the
set of 
unbarred letters z such that the pair (z,z) occurs in
C. The column C can be split when there exists a set of k
unbarred letters J = { t_1 > … > t_k }⊂ [n]
such that:

    
  * t_1 is the greatest letter in [n] satisfying: 
        t_1 < z_1, t_1∉C, and t_1∉C,
    
  * for i = 2, …, k, the letter t_i is the greatest
        one in [n] satisfying t_i < min(t_i-1, z_i), 
        t_i ∉C, and t_i∉C.


In this case we write:


    
  * rC for the column obtained by changing z_i
    into t_i in C for each letter z_i ∈ I, and by
    reordering if necessary,
    
  * lC for the column obtained by changing z_i into
        t_i in C for each letter z_i ∈ I, and by reordering if
        necessary.

The pair (lC,rC) will be called a split column , which we well
sometimes denote by lCrC.

[<cit.>]
	An  alcove path is a sequence of alcoves (A_0, A_1, …, A_m) such that
	A_j-1 and A_j are adjacent, for j=1,… m. We say that an alcove path 
	is reduced if it has minimal length among all alcove paths from A_0 to A_m.

    A_0=A_∘-β_1⟶ A_1
    		-β_2⟶…-β_m⟶ A_m=A_-λ

is a reduced alcove path.

sentence:
A subset J={ j_1 < j_2 < ⋯ < j_s }⊆ [m] (possibly empty)
 is an admissible subset if
we have the following path in the quantum Bruhat graph on W:

    1 β_j_1⟶ r_j_1β_j_2⟶ r_j_1r_j_2β_j_3⟶⋯β_j_s⟶ r_j_1r_j_2⋯ r_j_s .

We call Δ=Γ(J) an admissible folding .
We let =(λ) be the collection of 
admissible subsets.


	
	We continue Example <ref>.
	Let J =  { 1,2,3,5 }, then 
	Δ=Γ(J)={α_23,α_12, α_31, α_23, α_21,α_13}. The folded path is shown in Figure <ref>.
We have J^+={ 1,2}, J^-={ 3,5 }, 
μ(J)=-ε_3, and (J)=2.

In section <ref> 
we will describe an easy way to verify that J is admissible.

sentence:
Let M be an exchange mechanism on commodity
set {  1,…,m} and let G be the (directed, connected)
graph induced by the trading opportunities in M. If M satisfies
Anonymity , Aggregation , Invariance and
Non-dissipation , then M=M_G.

sentence:
We say that an edge ij of a graph G is collapsible if



  * i is an ordinary vertex


  * ji is not an edge of G


  * there is no vertex k such that ki and kj are both edges of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If G has no collapsible edges we will say G is rigid .

sentence:
Let i be an ordinary vertex of G with outgoing edge ij. We say that a
vertex k covers i, if one of the following holds:



  * the edges ki and kj belong to G


  * j=k and the edge ki belongs to G


If there is no such k then we say that i is an uncovered vertex.

sentence:
Let Y be a simplicial m-complex and let σ = v_0, …, v_m∈ S_m(Y).  The stellar subdivision of Y along σ, denoted by _σ Y, is the simplicial m-complex obtained from Y by creating a new vertex w and replacing σ with the m-simplexes

    τ_i = v_0, …, v_i-1, w, v_i+1, …, v_m

where i = 0, …, m.  For notational purposes, we denote the j-th face of τ_i by t_i,j := τ_i ∖v_j for i ≠ j, and t_i,i := τ_i ∖w.  If σ_1, …, σ_n ∈ S_m(Y), then we define the stellar subdivision of Y along the σ_i to be 

    _σ_1, …, σ_n Y := _σ_1_σ_2⋯_σ_n Y

sentence:
[Theorem 4.4 in <cit.>]
Fix b:E→{0,1} and t∈. Suppose that for every k=0,1,…,m-1 and every s_1,…, s_k∈$̋, the polynomials

    (f_s_1,…,s_k,s_k+1=r^(b,t)(x))_r∈

have positive leading coefficients, are real-rooted and have a common interlacing . Then, there existss_1,…, s_m∈$̋ such that the largest root of f_s_1,…, s_m^(b,t)(x) is at most the largest root of f_∅^(b,t)(x).

sentence:
We define the matching polynomial of a graph G on n vertices to be
 
    μ_G(x) := ∑_k=0^⌊ n/2⌋ (-1)^k m_k x^n-2k,

where m_k is the number of matchings of G with exactly k edges.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let there be n cars C_1,…,C_n
of sizes y_1,…,y_n, 
where y_1, …, y_n are positive integers.
Assume there are z-1 + ∑_i=1^n y_i spaces in a row,
where the trailer occupies the z-1 first spaces.
Furthermore, let car C_i have the preferred spot c_i.
Now let the cars
in the order C_1 through C_n
park according to the following rule:

Starting at position c_i,
car C_i
looks for the first empty spot j ≥ c_i.
If the spaces j through j+y_i-1 are empty, then car C_i
parks in these spots.
If any of the spots
j+1 through j+y_i-1 is already occupied,
then there will be a collision, and the result is not a parking sequence.


Iterate this rule for all the cars
C_1, C_2, …, C_n.
We call (c_1,…, c_n) a parking sequence
for y⃗=(y_1,…,y_n)
if all n cars can park without any collisions
and without leaving
the z-1 + ∑_i=1^n y_i parking spaces.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Δ be a (d-1)-dimensional Buchsbaum simplicial complex over a 
    field k. The complex Δ is called Buchsbaum* over k if 
    
    _k H_d-2(|Δ|-p;k) = 
                      _k H_d-2(|Δ|; k)
 
     holds for every p  ∈ |Δ|.

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex and let m be a nonnegative integer. 
     We call Δ m-Buchsbaum* over k if m = 0 and Δ is 
     Buchsbaum over k or m ≥ 1 and Δτ is Buchsbaum* over k 
     of the same dimension as Δ for every set τ  
     of vertices of Δ of cardinality less than m.

sentence:
A rightmost branch of a planar rooted tree  Γ∈𝒯 is a maximal connected
subgraph Ω⊂Γ, with the property that every edge of Ω is a rightmost edge of
Γ.
A rightmost branch is called non trivial if it has at least two vertices.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A local rightmost leaf is a  leaf lying on a non trivial rightmost branch.  
Given an internal vertex  v, we call m(v) the leaf lying on the rightmost
branch containing v.
We also denote by d(v) the distance between v and m(v), as defined in <cit.>.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A subroot  is the vertex  of a  non trivial rightmost branch which is nearest to the root. The set of subroots of a finite planar rooted tree Γ will be denoted by R(Γ).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let σ_Γ be any fixed top dimensional cone of the tropical moduli space ℳ^trop_h,r+s. Denote by σ^_Θ↦σ_Γ a  cone  in the moduli space ^trop_g,d(μ⃗) of combinatorial type Θ such that the base graph of Θ  is equal to Γ. The restriction of the tropical branch map is a surjective morphism of cones with integral structure of the same dimension, and consequently has a dilation factor which we denote d_Θ(br).

Refer to Definition <ref> for the precise definition of the  weight ω(Θ). Informally, this weight is a product of “local Hurwitz numbers”, expansion factors along bounded edges, and an automorphism factor. 


Then the  Hurwitz number is equal to: 

    h_g→ h,d(μ⃗) = ∑_σ^_Θ↦σ_Γω(Θ)· d_Θ(br^trop).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A generalized cone complex is an arbitrary finite colimit of cones σ_i and face morphisms ψ_i,

    Σ =  (σ_i,ψ_i).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An admissible cover π: D→ C of degree d is a finite morphism of pointed curves such that:


  * The map π restricted to the complement of the inverse image of the marked points and nodes is étale of constant degree d. 

  * All inverse images of marked points of C are marked in D.

  * The set of nodes of D is precisely the preimage under π of the set of nodes of C.





 



  * Over a node, étale locally, D, C and π are described by

    D   :    y_1y_2 = a
    
    C   :    x_1x_2 = a^ℓ
    π   :    x_1 = y_1^ℓ,   x_2 = y_2^ℓ.

for some positive integer ℓ≤ d.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The inclusion 𝒰↪𝒳 is a toroidal embedding of Deligne–Mumford stacks if, for every morphism from a scheme V→𝒳, the inclusion 𝒰_V↪ V is a toroidal embedding of schemes.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A Hurwitz cover of a tropical curve is a harmonic map of tropical curves that satisfies the local Riemann–Hurwitz equation at every point.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The image of p_X is the skeleton of X, denoted Σ(X). The map p_X is referred to as the retraction to the skeleton .
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A morphism φ: 𝒳→𝒴 of toroidal embeddings is said to be locally analytically toric if for every point x∈𝒳, there exist étale charts around x and ϕ(x) such ϕ is given by an equivariant toric morphism. That is, we have the following diagram

    𝒱_σd   𝒱_x dlr   𝒳d
    𝒱_τ   𝒱_φ(x)lr   𝒴,

where the top row is a local toric chart around x in 𝒳, and the bottom row is a local toric chart around φ(x) in 𝒴. The leftmost vertical arrow is torus equivariant.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Monodromy graphs project to the segment [0,s+1] and are constructed as follows:


  * Start with k small segments over 0, with weights μ^1_1,…, μ^1_k.

  * Over the point 1, create a trivalent vertex by either joining two strands or splitting two strands. When joining two strands, label the outgoing edge with the sum of the incoming weights. In case of a cut, label the two new strands in all possible positive ways of adding the weight of the split edge. Each choice of split produces a distinct monodromy graph.

  * Repeat this process for integers up to s.

  * Retain all connected graphs that terminate with ℓ points of weights μ^2_1,…,μ^2_ℓ over s+1.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let μ^1,μ^2 be partitions of d. Let Γ be a genus g, ℓ((μ^1)+ℓ(μ^2))-pointed tropical curve. A parametrized tropical curve of genus g and degree (μ^1,μ^2) in ^1 is a integral harmonic morphism θ: Γ→^1_trop, where Γ has genus g, such that 


  * The image of Γ without its infinite edges is inside .

  * The multiset of expansion factors over the +∞ segment is given by μ^1, and the multiset of expansion factors over the -∞ segment is given by μ^2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: parametrized tropical curve of genus g and degree (μ^1,μ^2) in ^1

sentence: The guaranteed rest time of a schedule for an asynchronous tournament is the maximum integer b such that in the schedule, any two games involving a team is separated by at least b games not involving that team.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The games-played difference index of a schedule for an asynchronous tournament is the minimum integer p such that at any point in the schedule, the difference between the number of games played by any two teams is at most p.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The rest difference index of a schedule for an asynchronous tournament is the minimum integer d such that for any game in the schedule, if one team has not played in i_1 consecutive games since its last game and the other team has not played in i_2 consecutive games since its last game, then |i_1-i_2|≤ d. (To handle the situation in which a team is playing its first game in the tournament, we will assume that all teams are involved in an imaginary game that takes place one slot before the first game of the schedule.)
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An order ideal of a poset 𝒫 is a set I ⊆𝒫 such that if p ∈ I and p' ≤ p, then p' ∈ I.  We write J(𝒫) for the set of all order ideals of 𝒫.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A partition λ = (λ_1, λ_2, …, λ_k) is a finite sequence of weakly decreasing positive integers.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let 𝒫 have n elements and let [n]={1,2,…,n}.  A linear extension of 𝒫 is a bijection ℒ: 𝒫→ [n] such that if p < p', then ℒ(p) < ℒ(p').  We call linear extensions of a skew Ferrers diagram Standard Young Tableaux (SYT) .  We write ℒ(𝒫) for the set of all linear extensions of 𝒫.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let ℒ be a linear extension of a poset 𝒫 and let ρ_i act on ℒ by switching i and i+1 if they are not the labels of two elements with a covering relation.  We define the promotion of ℒ to be (ℒ) = ρ_n-1ρ_n-2⋯ρ_1 (ℒ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[V. Reiner, D. Stanton, D. White] Let X be a finite set, X(q) a generating function for X, and C_n the cyclic group of order n acting on X.  Then the triple (X, X(q), C_n) exhibits the Cyclic Sieving Phenomenon (CSP) if for c ∈ C_n, 
	
    X(ω(c)) = | { x ∈ X : c(x) = x }|,

where ω: C_n →ℂ is an isomorphism of C_n with the nth roots of unity.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Π⊂ℝ^2 be the set of points in the integer span of (2,0) and (1,1).  A rowed-and-columned (rc) poset ℛ is a finite poset together with a map π: ℛ→Π, where if p_1,p_2 ∈ℛ, p_1 covers p_2, and π(p_1)=(i,j), then π(p_2)=(i+1,j-1) or π(p_2)=(i-1,j-1).  For p ∈ℛ, we call π(p) ∈Π the position of p.

sentence: We define the boundary path of an order ideal of a connected  of height one to be the path that separates the order ideal from the rest of the poset.  We encode boundary paths as binary words by writing a 1 for a northeast step and a 0 for a southeast step.

sentence: Let I∈ J([ℓ]×[m]×[n]).  We define its boundary path matrix B(I)={b_i,j} to be the ℓ× (m+n+ℓ-1) matrix with row i containing the boundary path of layer {i}×[m]×[n], preceded by i-1 zeros and succeeded by ℓ-i zeros.

sentence: An alternating sign matrix (ASM) of order n is an n× n matrix with entries 0, 1, or -1 whose rows and columns sum to 1 and whose nonzero entries in each row and column alternate in sign.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A height function of order n is an (n+1)× (n+1) matrix (h_i,j)_0≤ i,j ≤ n with h_0,k = h_k,0 = k and h_n,k = h_k,n = n-k for 0 ≤ k ≤ n, and such that adjacent entries in any row or column differ by 1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Consider the grid [n] × [n].  A fully-packed loop configuration (FPL) of order n is a set of paths that begin and end only at every second outward-pointing edge, such that each of the n^2 vertices within the grid lies on exactly one path.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Pairing up the boundary edges of each path reduces the FPL to a noncrossing matching on 2n vertices.  This matching is called the link pattern of the FPL.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: Given an FPL, its gyration is computed by first visiting all squares with lower left-hand corner (i,j) for which i+j is even, and then all squares for which i+j is odd, swapping the edges around a square if the edges are parallel and otherwise leaving them fixed.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A simplicial complex Δ is called weakly shellable if the facets of Δ admit a weak shelling order . A weak shelling order is a linear order, F_1,…,F_r of the facets of Δ such that if 1≤ i<j≤ r and F_i∪ F_j = V then there is a k with i k < j such that F_i∩ F_j⊆ F_k.

sentence:
An algebraic curve in ^2 is circular if it contains α and β.
For k≥ 2, an algebraic curve in ^2 is k-circular if it has singularities of multiplicity at least k at both α and β.

sentence:
Let C(p,r) be the circle with centre p = (x_p, y_p) ∈^2 and radius r>0. The circle inversion with respect to C(p,r) is the mapping 
I_p,r : ^2 ∖{p}→^2 ∖{p} 
defined by 

    I_p,r(x,y) = ( r^2(x-x_p)/(x-x_p)^2+(y-y_p)^2 + x_p, r^2(y-y_p)/(x-x_p)^2+(y-y_p)^2 + y_p )

for (x,y)  p.
We write I_p for I_p,1.
We call p the centre of the inversion I_p,r.

sentence:
For any algebraic curve γ there is an algebraic curve γ' such that 

    I_p,r(γ∖{p}) = γ'∖{p}.

We refer to γ' as the inverse of γ with respect to the circle C(p,r) , and abuse notation slightly by writing γ'=I_p,r(γ).
Also, since for different choices of radius r, I_p,r(γ) differs only by a dilatation in p, we will often only consider the inverse I_p(γ)=I_p,1(γ) and refer to it as the inverse of γ in the point p .

sentence:
The Rauzy graph of order n of (X,T) (also called graph of words of length n ), denoted by G_n(X) (or simply G_n), is the labelled directed graph (V(n),E(n)), where the set V(n) of vertices is nX and	there is an edge from u to v if there exist some letters a and b in A such that ub = av ∈n+1X; 
this edge is labelled[In the literature, there are different ways of labelling the edges. Indeed, the edges are sometimes labelled by the letter a, by the letter b, by the ordered pair (a,b) or by the word av.] by ub and is denoted by (u,(a,b),v).

-

sentence:
An infinite and labelled path p in  is valid if there is a minimal subshift with first difference of complexity bounded by 2 for which the sequence (γ_i_n)_n ∈ of Definition <ref> (and Remark <ref>) labels p. 

We extend the notion of validity to prefix and suffixes of p, i.e. , a path is a valid prefix (resp. valid suffix) if it is a prefix (resp. suffix) of a valid path. We also extend it to sequences of morphisms in ^*, i.e. , a sequence of morphisms is valid if it is the label of a valid path (or valid prefix or valid suffix).

sentence:
A [NEW stands for New .]  is a 0/1-filling of a Ferrers diagram, possibly with some empty bottom rows, satisfying the following conditions:
  
  
  *  Every column of  has a 1.
  
  *   No four cells of  that form the corners of a rectangle have 0s in two diagonally opposite corners and 1s in the other two.
  
The size of a  is the sum of its number of rows and number of columns.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A tree-tableau is a filling of a Ferrers diagram with the following properties:


  * The top left cell has a dot.

  * Every other cell has a dot above it (in the same column) or left of it (in the same row), but not both.

  * Every column and every row has a dot.

The size of a tree-tableau is one less than the sum of its number of rows and number of columns.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G=G(F) be a Ferrers graph, and <_E a total order on its edges or, equivalently, on the cells of F. We say that <_E is F-compatible if it is increasing in every row from left to right, and every column from top to bottom, in F.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A row R in a tableau  dominates a row S in  if S
lies above R and there is no column in  where R has a 0 and S has a 1.  A tableau  is domination-free if no row of  dominates another.

sentence: A tableau  is top-justified if all the 1s in each column are at the top, that is, no 1 has a 0 above it in the same column.

[ P(a←)    or P(a←);       ]


if P has no placement in column a, or to either of


[ P(→ b)     or P(→ b);        ]


if P has no placement in column b, is called a generalized Knuth transformation .

a separating set is called an identifying code of G.

sentence:
Let k ∈ and P ⊆ B_ℓ(A). For w ∈ A^k and p ∈ P, define the function
wp : A^k+ℓ→ A^k+ℓ by

    wp(uv) = {[     uv  u ≠ w; u p(v)  u = w ].

where u ∈ A^k, v ∈ A^ℓ.
The functions wp, and more generally their rewirings π_α∘wp∘π_α^-1 for
α∈ S_k+ℓ,
are called k-controlled P-permutations ,
and we denote this set of functions by CP(k,P) ⊆ B_k+ℓ(A).
We refer to CP(P) = ⋃_k CP(k,P) as controlled P-permutations .

sentence:
Let C be a . We say that a set of permutations P ⊆ B_ℓ(A) is n-control-universal
for C if CP(n-ℓ, P) = C ∩ B_n(A). More generally, a set P ⊆ B(A) that may contain gates of
different arities, is n-control-universal for C if

    ⋃_ℓ⋃_f∈ B_ℓ(A)∩ P CP(n-ℓ, P) = C ∩ B_n(A).

If P is n-control-universal
for all large enough n, we say it is control-universal for C.

sentence:
Let |A| > 1 and let ∼ be a sequence of equivalence relations, so that for all n, ∼_n is an equivalence relation on A^n. If

    u ∼_n v  ua ∼_n+1 va

then we say ∼ is compatible , and if

    u ∼_n v π(u) ∼_n π(v)

for all wire permutations π, then we say ∼ is permutable . We say ∼ is a generalized conserved quantity if it is both compatible and permutable. If for all m ∈, there exists n such that ∼_n has at least m equivalence classes with more than one word, we say ∼ is infinite-dimensional .

sentence:
Let h ∈() be any finite isomorphism of . We say that h is correctly orbitally incomparable if and only if it is orbitally incomparable and the relation ≼ on orbits of h given by the condition

    [x] ≼ [y]   if and only if   x' ≤ y',  for some  x' ∈ [x]  and  y' ∈ [y]
 is a partial order.

sentence:
For a pair of colour sets p,q, the damage of (p,q) with respect to L and P is written
_L,P(p,q) and defined by 

    _L,P(p,q)=S_L(P) -   S_pq(P).

sentence:
We say that an internal path P blocks a pair (p,q) if
  _L,P(p,q) > S_L(P) - 2V(P), i.e., if we cannot extend the
  partial colouring ϕ(u) = p, ϕ(v) = q to all of P.

sentence:
Let  be a semigroup and A ⊆ S.


  * A is (right) syndetic if there exist s_1, …, s_k ∈ S such that S = s_1^-1· A ∪⋯∪ s_k^-1· A.

  * A is (left) thick if for all F ∈ S, there exists x ∈ S for which F · x ⊆ A.

  * A is (right) piecewise syndetic if there exist s_1, …, s_k ∈ S such that the set s_1^-1· A ∪⋯∪ s_k^-1· A is (left) thick.

Denote by , , and  the collections of all syndetic, thick, and piecewise syndetic subsets of the semigroup . When the semigroup is apparent or unimportant, we refer to these classes simply as , , and .

sentence: Let ⊆ S be a collection of subsets of a set S. The dual class ^* ⊆ S is the collection of subsets of S having non-empty intersection with every member of ; in other words, A ∈^* if and only if for all B ∈, A ∩ B ≠∅.

sentence: A semigroup  is left cancellative if for all x,y,z ∈ S, x  y = x  z implies that y=z. Right cancellativity is defined analogously. We say  is cancellative if it is both left and right cancellative.

sentence: A semigroup  is left amenable if the space of bounded, complex-valued functions on S with the supremum norm admits a left translation invariant mean , that is, a positive linear functional λ of norm 1 which is left translation invariant: for all bounded f: S →ℂ and all s ∈ S, λ( x ↦ f(s· x) ) = λ ( f ).

sentence:
Let  be a semigroup and A ⊆ S. The (left) density of A is

    d_S^*(A) = sup{α≥ 0  |  ∀ F ∈ S,  ∃ s ∈ S,  |(F  s) ∩ A| ≥α |F| }.

When  is cancellative and left amenable, this density coincides with the upper Banach density (see Lemma <ref> <ref>) and we denote by  the collection of all subsets of  with positive density. (Throughout this paper, when referring to the class , we shall implicitly assume that  is cancellative and left amenable.)

sentence: Let an ideal I of the ring A = k[x_1, …, x_t] be generated only by monomials of the form x_j^a. Then we call the ring S = A/I a pure power ring and the survival complex Σ(S) a pure power survival complex.

sentence: Let Σ (R) be the survival complex of R = k[x_1, …, x_n]/I. We say that a monomial m ∈Σ (R) is truly isolated if for all 1 ≤ i ≤ n, x_im =0.

sentence: Let Σ (R) be the survival complex of R = k[x_1, …, x_n]/I. We say that a variable x_t ∈Σ (R) is quasi-isolated if for all 1 ≤ i ≤ n with i ≠ t, x_ix_t =0, but x_t^2 ≠ 0 and x_t^3 = 0.

sentence: A trivially connected component is a connected component consisting of only one point.

sentence: A quasi-trivially connected component is a connected component consisting of a quasi-isolated point of the form x_t.

 m(W,w) of oriented spanning trees 𝐚 rooted at w such that ψ(𝐚)=W.

sentence:
For an integer d ≥ 0, a function P: ^n → is said to be a
nonclassical polynomial of degree ≤ d (or simply a
polynomial of degree ≤ d) if for all y_1,
…, y_d+1, x ∈^n, it holds that

    (D_y_1⋯ D_y_d+1 P)(x) = 0.

The degree of P is the smallest d for which the above holds.
A function P : ^n → is said to be a classical polynomial of degree
≤ d if it is a nonclassical polynomial of degree ≤ d
whose image is contained in 1/q/.

Denote by (^n→), _d(^n→) and _≤ d(^n→), the set of all nonclassical polynomials over ^n, all nonclassical polynomials of degree d and all nonclassical polynomials of degree ≤ d respectively.

sentence:
Let =_q be a finite field, d >0.
Given a function f: ^n →, the Gowers norm of order d for f is given by

    f_U^d := |_y_1,…,y_d,x ∈^n[(Δ_y_1Δ_y_2⋯Δ_y_df)(x)]|^1/2^d 
    = |_y_1,…,y_d,x ∈^n[∏_S ⊆ [d]𝒞^d-|S| f(x + ∑_i ∈ S y_i) ]|^1/2^d,

where 𝒞 is the conjugation operator 𝒞(z)=z and Δ_y f(x)= f(x+y) f(x) is the multiplicative derivative of f at direction y.

sentence:
A collection ' of polynomials is called a refinement of ={P_1,...,P_m}, and
denoted ' ≽, if the
induced partition by ' is a combinatorial refinement of the partition
induced by . In other words, if for every x,y∈^n,
'(x)='(y) implies (x)=(y).

partition of X into finitely many pieces called atoms .

sentence:
A graph G is said to be mock threshold[With apologies to the Mock Turtle.] if there is a vertex ordering v_1, …, v_n such that for every i (1 ≤ i ≤ n) the degree of v_i in G:{v_1, …, v_i} is 0,1,i-2, or i-1. 
We write  for the class of mock threshold graphs.

sentence:
We define an S-vertex-polytope as the convex hull of points x_1,x_2,…,x_k∈ S in convex position such that no other point of S is in (x_1,…,x_k). 

Similarly, an S-face-polytope is defined as the intersection of semi-spaces H_1,H_2,…,H_k such that ⋂_i H_i has k faces and contains exactly k points of S, one contained in the relative interior of each face.

sentence:
For a property  as above, the Helly number h=h()∈ is defined as the smallest number satisfying the following.

    ∀ i_1,…,i_h ∈ [m] : (F_i_1∩⋯∩ F_i_h)       ⟹      (F_1 ∩⋯∩ F_m)

for all m ∈ and convex sets F_1, …, F_m. If no such h exists, then h():=∞.

sentence:
We say that property  is:


  1. Helly if the corresponding Helly number h() is finite.

  2. Monotone if K⊂ K' and (K) is true implies that (K') is true too.

  3. Orderable if for any finite family  of convex sets there is a direction v such that:


  * For every K∈ where (K) is true, there is a containment-minimal v-semispace (i.e., a half-space of the form {x:v^T x≥ 0}) H such that (K∩ H) is true.

  * There is a unique minimal K'⊂ K∩ H with (K') true.


  4. N-colorable if for any given finite families _1,…_N of closed convex sets in ^d (each a colored family), such that (⋂) is true for every rainbow subfamily  (i.e. a family with ∩_i=1 for every i), then (⋂_i) is true for some family _i.

sentence: [Polygonal Dissections] A polygonal dissection of a convex n-gon is the union of the polygon and any nonintersecting subset of its diagonals. A d-dissection (respectively, a (d_1,d_2,...,d_r)-dissection ) is a polygonal dissection such that the regions formed by the dissection are all convex (d+1)-gons (respectively, each region is a (d+1)-gon, where d∈{d_1,d_2,...,d_r}).
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: [Type of a Polygonal Dissection] Let λ be a partition of n with k_j parts of size j. We say a dissection of an (n+2)-gon consisting of k_j (j+2)-gons is a polygonal dissection of type λ , and denote the set of all such polygonal dissections as P_λ,n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: [Rooted Trees and Downdegree Sequences] A rooted plane tree is a tree T with a distinguished vertex called the root . The downdegree sequence r=(r_0,r_1,r_2,....,r_n) of a rooted tree counts the number of vertices r_j with j neighbors further away from the root than the vertex itself.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A colored polygonal dissection is a polygonal dissection where each (d+1)-gon appearing in the dissection can be assigned b_d possible colors for d≥ 2.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given an integer n≥ 1 and a graph G, we say that G is a half-graph of height n if there is a partition {a_1,…,a_n}∪{b_1,…,b_n} of the vertices of G such that the edge e(a_i,b_j) occurs if and only if i≥ j. 
The unique bipartite half-graph of height n is denoted H_n.

sentence:
Let G be a graph.


  * Given b_1,…,b_n∈ V(G), we say that (b_1,…,b_n) is a nested complexity sequence for G if for each 1≤ k≤ n-1 there is a_k∈ V(G) such that b_1,…,b_k∈ N[a_k]∌b_k+1.

  * The nested complexity length of G , denoted (G), is given by

    (G):=sup{ n  |  (b_1,…,b_n)  is a nested complexity sequence for  G}.

plain_text_term: nested complexity sequence;nested complexity length of G

sentence:
Let G be a graph.


  * If |G|=n>1 the density of G is

    δ(G)=|E(G)|/n 2 .


  * If G is infinite the upper density of G is

    δ(G) = lim sup_H⊆ G, |H|→∞δ(H) .

sentence:
[Approximate groups]
Let K ≥ 1. A finite subset A of an ambient group G is called K-approximate subgroup of G if the following properties hold:


  * the set A is symmetric in the sense that 𝕀∈ A and a^-1∈ A if a ∈ A;

  * there is a symmetric subset X ⊆ A^3 with |X| ≤ K
such that A · A ⊆ X · A.

  some graph G∈. Let GB be the graph obtained from
  G by adding a new vertex α adjacent to each vertex in
  B. Then B is an -boundary of G if GB is
  also in .

sentence:
A set of hyperplanes {H_1,…,H_k} in V is complete if ∩_i=1^k H_i =0.
Note that k may be greater
than the dimension of V in this definition.

sentence:
[Configurations] 
A configuration W is a subspace of a based vector space[A generalized configuration is a linear map φ from a vector space W to a based vector space.
In particular, for every generalized configuration φ, the image φ(W) is a (nongeneralized) configuration in
the based vector space.
The results in this paper extend to generalized configurations.
We do not need this generality, so we refer the interested reader to <cit.>].

sentence:
A spanning forest is a forest whose components are spanning trees for
the components of the graph.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A quasi-spanning forest is a spanning forest of G with one edge
removed.
The complement of a quasi-spanning forest is a
cut set .[The terms in the literature 
that define quasi-spanning forest and cut set are not 
consistent, for example see <cit.>, <cit.>, <cit.>, <cit.>.
In some cases, cut sets are called minimal cut sets to indicate that
removing more edges would create more components. In other cases,
cut sets are simply required to disconnect the graph, and the
complement does not even need to be a forest.
Similarly, quasi-spanning forests are often defined only for
connected graphs, in which case they are often named two-trees or
spanning two-trees.
We believe the use of two in this term refers to the number of components,
which will not be two in the generality of disconnected graphs.]
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A momentum of G is an element of

    K^V,0 = { p∈ K^V | ∑_v∈ V(G_α) p_v = 0  for all connected components G_α of G}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The momentum associated to the quasi-spanning forest F (or
to the corresponding cut set C=G-F) is the following function
from the momentum K^V(G),0 to K:

    s_F(p) = s_C(p) = m_T_1(p)^2 = m_T_2(p)^2.

plain_text_term: momentum associated to the quasi-spanning forest F

sentence:
For a nonzero momentum p, 
define the (first) homology of G relative to p to be
H_1(G,p) = ∂^-1(Kp)=H_1(G)⊕ Kq.
That is, it is the relative homology group for Kp considered as a chain complex concentrated in degree zero
included in the chain complex for the graph G.

sentence:
[Order of Singularity Ideal]
Let X be a projective variety defined by a homogeneous ideal I 
in K[A_1,…, A_n].
The first order singularity ideal , S(I) or S(X), is the ideal generated by the set

    {∂ f/∂ A_i |  f∈ I  and  i=1,…, n }.

The k-th order singularity ideal is S^(k)(X)=S^(k)(I)=S(S^(k-1)(I)).
The locus of order at least k singularities of X,
_≥ k X, is the
scheme defined by S^(k)(I).

plain_text_term: first order singularity ideal;k-th order singularity ideal;locus of order at least k singularities

sentence: Given a permutation σ of size n, we say that there is a descent (resp. ascent ) at position i, 1 ≤ i ≤ n-1, if σ_i > σ_i+1 (resp. σ_i < σ_i+1 ). We indicate the number of descents of the permutation σ by desc(σ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A permutation π∈ S_k is a pattern of a permutation σ∈ S_n if there is a subsequence of σ which is order-isomorphic to π; i.e., if there is a subsequence σ_i_1σ_i_2…σ_i_k of σ (with 1 ≤ i_1 < i_2 <…<i_k ≤ n) such that σ_i_ℓ < σ_i_m whenever π_ℓ < π_m. 

We also say that π is involved in σ and call σ_i_1σ_i_2…σ_i_k an occurrence of π in σ.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
Let r be a positive integer. Let U_r(v,G) be the ball with 
radius r around v∈ V in G (i.e. the induced subgraph 
on all vertices in V whose distance from v is ≤ r). 
Let 

    ℓχ_r(G)=max_v∈ Vχ(U_r(v,G))

denote the r-local chromatic number of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
For a subgraph F=(V_F, E_F) ⊆ U_r(v,G), let 

    L_i(v, F) = { u ∈ V_F  : d(u,v) = i }

denote the i-th level (with respect to v in F). 
Moreover, define 

    L_≥ i(v,F) = ⋃_j=i^r L_j (v, F)  L_≤
    i(v,F) = ⋃_j=0^i L_j (v, F)

sentence:
Let F ⊆ U_r(v,G).


  * An i-path in F is a simple path in L_≥ i(v,
F) whose endpoints belong to L_i (v,F).

  * An i-cycle in F is a simple cycle in
L_≥ i(v,F) with at least one vertex in L_i (v,F).

  * An i-horseshoe in F is a path of the form

    u w_1 … w_k z

 where u,z ∈ L_i-1(v, F), k ≥ 1, u w_1, w_k z ∈ R and w_1 … w_k is an i-path in F.
Specifically in the case k=1 we also require u ≠ z.

  * An i-sub-horseshoe in F is a path of the form

    u' w_1 … w_k z'

where u',z' ∈ L_i-1(v,F), k ≥ 1, u'w_1, w_k z' ∈ F 
and w_1 … w_k is included in the interior of some i-horseshoe.
Specifically in the case k=1 we also require u' ≠ z'.

sentence: Consider a network G consisting of n nodes each operating independently with probability p∈[0,1].  The node reliability of G, denoted (G;p), is the probability that at least one node is operational and that the operating nodes can all communicate in the induced subgraph that they generate.

sentence:
Given a map f: Y→ Y, with Y⊆ X, the (local) interaction graph of f at x ∈ Y is the finite labelled directed graph G_f(x) with vertex set {1, …, n},
  and an edge from j to i,
  with label s = s_1 ((f_i(x + s_1 ^j) - f_i(x)), for s_1 ∈{-1, 1} and x + s_1 ^j ∈ Y, whenever s ≠ 0.
  We will call s, s_1 and j the sign , variation and direction of the edge, respectively.

  The global interaction graph G_f of f is the graph with vertex set {1,…,n}
  and an edge from j to i with sign s if, for some x∈ Y, the graph G_f(x)
  has an edge from j to i with sign s.

sentence:
The non-usual local interaction graph _f(x,y) of the map f→ at a state x∈
  with variations in direction of y is the graph with vertex set {1, …, n},
  and an edge from a vertex j to a vertex i of sign s, with i, j ∈ I(x,y),
  whenever x + ϵ_j^j ∈ and s = ϵ_j (f_i(x + ϵ_j^j) - f_i(x))≠ 0,
  with ϵ_k = (y_k - x_k) for all k ∈ I(x,y), and, in addition,
  
    min{f_i(x),f_i(x + ϵ_j^j)} < x_i + ϵ_i/2 < max{f_i(x),f_i(x + ϵ_j^j)}.

sentence:
A partial lattice is a structure (P,≤,⋁,⋀), where
(P,≤) is a poset and ⋁, ⋀ are partial functions from
P to P satisfying the following properties:


  * for all a∈ P and all X∈ P , the relation a=⋁ X implies that P a=⋂_x∈ X(P x);


  * for all a∈ P and all X∈ P , the relation a=⋀ X implies that P a=⋂_x∈ X(P x).

If P and Q are partial lattices, a homomorphism of partial lattices from P to Q is an isotone map
f P→ Q such that a=⋁ X
(resp., a=⋀ X) implies that f(a)=⋁ f[X] (resp., f(a)=⋀ f[X]),
for all a∈ P and all X∈ P. We say that a homomorphism f of partial lattices is an
embedding if it is an order-embedding, that is, f(a)≤ f(b) implies that a≤ b, for all
a,b∈ P.

 is γ close to

sentence:
Let C be a polytopal complex. Let S denote a subset of mutually disjoint faces of C. We extend this order to an irreflexive partial order ≺ on C as follows: Let σ be any face of C, and let τ⊊σ be any strict face of σ. 
[∙]

  * If τ is the minimal face of σ under ≺, then τ ≺ σ.

  * If τ is any other face of σ, then σ ≺ τ.

The transitive closure of the relation ≺ gives an irreflexive partial order on the faces of C. 

Note that by the correspondence of faces of C to the vertices of C, it gives an irreflexive partial order on _0(  C). Any total order that extends the latter order is a derived order of _0(  C) induced by ≺.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
[Star-shaped sets]
A subset X ⊂^d is star-shaped if there exists a point x in X, a star-center of X, such that for each y in X, the segment [x,y] lies in X. 
Similarly, a subset X ⊂ S^d is star-shaped if X lies in a closed hemisphere of S^d and there exists a star-center x of X, in the interior of the hemisphere containing X, such that for each y in X, the segment from x to y lies in X. With abuse of notation, a polytopal complex C (in ^d or in S^d) is star-shaped if its underlying space is star-shaped.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
[Derived order]
Let C be a polytopal complex. Let S denote a subset of mutually disjoint faces of C. We extend this order to an irreflexive partial order ≺ on C as follows: Let σ be any face of C, and let τ⊊σ be any strict face of σ. 
[∙]

  * If τ is the minimal face of σ under ≺, then τ ≺ σ.

  * If τ is any other face of σ, then σ ≺ τ.

The transitive closure of the relation ≺ gives an irreflexive partial order on the faces of C. 

Note that by the correspondence of faces of C to the vertices of C, it gives an irreflexive partial order on _0(  C). Any total order that extends the latter order is a derived order of _0(  C) induced by ≺.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
[H-splitting derived subdivisions]
Let C be a polytopal complex in ℝ^d, and let H be a hyperplane of ℝ^d. An H-splitting derived subdivision of C is a derived subdivision, with vertices chosen so that the following property holds: for any face τ of C that intersects the hyperplane H in the relative interior, the vertex of C that corresponds to τ in C lies on the hyperplane H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Split link and Lower link]
Let C be a simplicial complex in ^d. Let v be a vertex of C, and let H_+ be a closed halfspace in ^d with outer normal ν at v∈ H:=∂H_+. The split link (of C at v with respect to ν), denoted by (v, C), is the intersection of (v,  C) with the hemisphere _v^1 H_+, that is, 
    (v, C):= {σ∩_v^1 H_+: σ∈(v,C)}.

The lower link (v,C) of C at v with respect to the direction ν is the restriction ((v,C), _v^1 H_+) of (v,C) to _v^1 H_+. 

The complex (v, C) is naturally a subcomplex of (v,C): we have as an alternative definition of the lower link the identity 
    (v,C)=((v,C), _v^1 H_+).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A orthogonal matrix, S, has real entries and satisfies 

    S^⊤S = SS^⊤ = ω I_n
 
where I_n is the n × n identity matrix, and ω, the weight , is a constant real number. For computationally discovered cases
we will say it is orthogonal to (say) five decimal places.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Cretan]  
A Cretan matrix, S = (s_ij), of order n, with τ levels, written as Cretan(n;τ ) or CM(n;τ;ω), is a τ-variable orthogonal matrix, which has had the variables  replaced by real numbers with modulus ≤ 1, and CM(n;τ;ω ) and has a least one 1 in each row and column. A CM(n;τ), S,  satisfies the orthogonality equation


    S^⊤S = SS^⊤ = ω I_n,

 
here ω, called the weight , is a  real constant.  

A Cretan matrix is either precisely orthogonal or orthogonal  to (say) 5 decimal places.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Levels]
The  entries of the τ-variable orthogonal matrix of order n, S, are called variables . When the variables are replaced by real numbers/values/entries with modulus ≤ 1, and there is at least one 1 in each row and column we have a Cretan(n;τ;ω ) or CM(n;τ;ω) which has τ levels.

That is the number of different real numbers, counting plus entries separately from  minus entries, is the number of levels of S.

The level x = 1 is pre-defined for all Cretan matrices.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Orthogonality equation, radius equation(s), characteristic equation(s), weight]
Consider the matrix S= (s_ij) comprising  the variables x and y.

The matrix orthogonality equation 
  
    S^⊤S = SS^⊤ = ω I_n

yields two types of equations: the n equations which arise from taking the inner product of each row/column with itself (which leads to the diagonal elements of ω I_n being ω) are called radius equation(s) , g(x,y)=ω, and the n^2 -n equations, f(x,y)=0, which arise from taking inner products of distinct rows of S (which leads to the zero off diagonal elements of ω I_n)  are called characteristic equation(s) . The orthogonality equation is ∑_j=1^n s_ij^2 =  ω. ω is called the weight of S.

plain_text_term: matrix orthogonality equation;radius equation(s);characteristic equation(s);orthogonality equation;weight

sentence:
[Incidence Matrix] 
For the purposes of this paper we will consider an SBIBD(v, k, λ), B, to be a v × v matrix, with entries 0 and 1, k ones per row and column, and the inner product of distinct pairs of rows and/or columns to be λ. This is called the incidence matrix of the SBIBD. For these matrices λ(v-1) = k(k-1).

sentence:
[regular pairs, fully-regular pairs, super-regular pairs]

The pair (X,Y) is called (,d,p)_G-regular if for every X'⊆ X and Y'⊆ Y with |X'|≥|X| and |Y'|≥ |Y| we have  d_G,p(X',Y') ≥ d-. It is called (,d,p)_G-regular if there is some d'≥ d such that for every X'⊆ X and Y'⊆ Y with |X'|≥|X| and |Y'|≥ |Y| we have  |d_G,p(X',Y')-d'| ≤.

If (X,Y) is (,d,p)_G-regular, and in addition we have

    |N_G(x,Y)|    ≥ (d-)max(p|Y|,_Γ(x,Y)/2)  and
    
     |N_G(y,X)|    ≥ (d-)max(p|X|,_Γ(y,X)/2)

for every x ∈ X and y ∈ Y, then the pair (X,Y) is called (,d,p)_G-super-regular .

sentence:
[Restriction pair]
 
 Let ,d>0, p ∈ [0,1], and let R be a graph on r vertices. Furthermore, let G be a (not necessarily spanning) subgraph of Γ = G(n,p) and let H be a graph given with vertex partitions = {V_i}_i∈[r] and = {W_i}_i∈[r], respectively, such that (G,) and (H,) are size-compatible R-partitions.
  Let ={I_x}_x∈ V(H) be a collection of subsets of V(G), called
  image restrictions , and ={J_x}_x∈ V(H) be a collection of
  subsets of V(Γ)∖ V(G), called restricting vertices .
   For each i∈ [r] we define R_i⊆ W_i to be the set of all vertices x ∈ W_i for which I_x ≠ V_i. 
  We say that  and  are a
  (ρ,ζ,Δ,Δ_J)-restriction pair if the
  following properties hold for each i∈[r] and x∈ W_i.
  
    
  *  We have |R_i|≤ρ|W_i|.
    
  *  If x∈ R_i, then I_x⊆⋂_u∈ J_x N_Γ(u, V_i) is of size at least ζ(dp)^|J_x||V_i|.
    
  *  If x∈ R_i, then |J_x|+_H(x)≤Δ and 
    if x∈ W_i∖ R_i, then J_x=∅.
    
  *  Each vertex in V(G) appears in at most Δ_J of the sets of .
    
  *  We have
    |⋂_u∈ J_x N_Γ(u, V_i)| = (p± p)^|J_x||V_i|.
    
  *  If x∈ R_i, for each xy∈ E(H) with y∈ W_j, 
    
    the pair   ( V_i ∩⋂_u∈ J_xN_Γ(u), V_j ∩⋂_v∈ J_yN_Γ(v))   is
        (,d,p)_G-regular.

sentence:
[(ϑ, R')-buffer, regularity inheritance]

Let R and R' be graphs on vertex set [r] with R'⊂ R.
Suppose that (H,) is an R-partition and that
(G,) is a size-compatible (,d,p)_G-regular partition with reduced
graph R. We say
that the family ={_i}_i∈[r] of subsets _i⊆ W_i is an (ϑ,R')-buffer for H if
 
  
  * |_i|≥ϑ |W_i| for all i∈[r],  and 
  
  * for each i∈[r] and each x∈_i, the first and second neighbourhood of x go along R', i.e.,  for each {x,y},{y,z}∈ E(H) with y∈ W_j and z∈ W_k we have {i,j}∈ E(R') and {j,k}∈ E(R').
 
 We say (G,) has one-sided inheritance on R' if for
every {i,j}, {j,k}∈ E(R') and every v∈ V_i the pair
(N_Γ(v, V_j),V_k) is (,d,p)_G-regular.
We say (G,) has two-sided inheritance on R' for  if
for each i,j,k ∈ V(R') such that there is a
triangle x_ix_jx_k in H with x_i∈_i, x_j∈ W_j, and
   x_k∈ W_k the following holds.
For every v∈ V_i the pair (N_Γ(v, V_j),N_Γ(v, V_k)) is
(,d,p)_G-regular.

sentence:
[Zero-free colouring]
 Let H be a (k+1)-colourable graph on n vertices and let  be a labelling of its vertex set of bandwidth at most β n. A proper (k+1)- colouring σ:V(H) →{0,…,k} of its vertex set is said to be (z,β)-zero-free with respect to  if any z consecutive blocks contain at most one block with colour zero, where a block is defined as a set of the form {(t-1)4kβ n +1, …, t4kβ n} with t ∈ [1/(4kβ)].

sentence:
Let S = be a numerical monoid with n ∈ S.  Suppose z_1 = (x_1,…, x_k) and z_2 = (y_1,… ,y_k) are both in 𝖹(n) and set 

    z_1 ∧ z_2 = (min(x_1,y_1), …, min(x_n,y_n)).

The distance between the two factorizations z_1 and z_2 of n is given by

    (z_1, z_2) = max{|z_1|, |z_2|} - |z_1 ∧ z_2|.

sentence:
Let S = be a numerical monoid and n ∈ S.  A sequence of factorizations

    z_0, z_1, … , z_t

where each z_i ∈𝖹(n) is called a chain of factorizations of n.  For each i∈{1,…,t}, set 𝔡_i = (z_i-1, z_i) which we refer to as the length of the i-th link of the chain.

sentence:
Let S = be a numerical monoid and n ∈ S.  The catenary degree of n is defined as 

    c(n) = min{ N :  N z_1, z_2∈𝖹(n) }.

We define the catenary degree of S to be

    c(S) = sup{c(n) : n ∈ S }.

sentence:
Let S = be a numerical monoid with n ∈ S.


  * For each i with n - n_i ∈ S, denote by t(n, n_i) the minimum t such that for every z ∈Z(n), there exists a factorization z^'∈𝖹(n) with z^' = (y_1,… ,y_n) where y_i ≠ 0 and (z,z^')≤ t.  If n - n_i ∉ S, then define t(n, n_i) = 0.

  * The tame degree of n is t(n) = max{t(n, n_i) : 1 ≤ i ≤ k}.

  * The tame degree of S is t(S) = sup{t(n) : n ∈ S}.

sentence: Let S = be a numerical monoid. We call n a Betti element of S if the Betti graph of n is not connected.  Denote by Betti(S) the set of Betti elements of S.

(X_1,…,X_m) in _v.

sentence:
i) An arrangement of pseudolines is a finite set 𝒜 of n ≥ 3 smooth closed curves in ℙ^2(ℝ) such that the following conditions are satisfied: 
 
  * Curves in 𝒜 do not intersect themselves.
 
  * Different curves in 𝒜 meet each other transversally in precisely one point.
 
  * We have ⋂_ℓ∈𝒜ℓ = {}, i.e. 𝒜 is not a pencil arrangement.  
 
Any arrangement 𝒜 induces a cell decomposition of the real projective plane. We denote by 𝒦(𝒜) the set of 2-cells in said decomposition. These are usually called chambers . Similarly, the 1-cells are called edges or segments while the 0-cells are called vertices . We write f^𝒜_0, f^𝒜_1, f^𝒜_2 for the number of vertices, edges, chambers of 𝒜 respectively. Two arrangements 𝒜, 𝒜^' are called isomorphic , if the corresponding cell decompositions are isomorphic; in this case, if 𝒜 is an arrangement of straight lines, then 𝒜^' is called stretchable . 
 
ii) Let 𝒜 be an arrangement of pseudolines in ℙ^2(ℝ). Then 𝒜 is called simplicial if every C ∈𝒦(𝒜) is bounded by precisely three lines ℓ_1, ℓ_2, ℓ_3 ∈𝒜.  

iii) Let n:=|𝒜| and choose a labelling 𝒜={ℓ_1, ℓ_2, ..., ℓ_n } for the lines of 𝒜. We will associate with 𝒜 a geometric lattice L:=L_𝒜. For this, define sets L_0, L_1, L_2, L_3  as follows: 
 
  * L_0 consists of the single element {}.
 
  * L_1 consists of the elements { i } for 1 ≤ i ≤ n.
 
  * For each v ∈ℙ^2(ℝ) we set I_v:={ i | 1 ≤ i ≤ n,v ∈ℓ_i }. Now we define L_2:= { I_v | v ∈ℙ^2(ℝ), |I_v| ≥ 2 }  
 
  * L_3 consists of the single element { 1,2, ..., n }.

Now define L:=L_0 ∪ L_1 ∪ L_2 ∪ L_3. It is immediate that L is a poset via setwise inclusion. We have a natural rank function r on L, which is described as follows: r(X)=i if and only if X ∈ L_i. Together with this rank function, the poset L becomes a geometric lattice. It is clear that different labellings for the lines of 𝒜 will lead to isomorphic lattices. Therefore, we may define the characteristic polynomial of 𝒜 as the characteristic polynomial of L, i.e. we set χ(𝒜,t):=∑_X ∈ Lμ({}, X) t^3-(X), where μ denotes the Möbius Function of L.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒜 be an arrangement of pseudolines in ℙ^2(ℝ). 

i) For each v ∈ℙ^2(ℝ) we define w_𝒜(v):=|{ℓ∈𝒜| v ∈ℓ}| ∈ℕ_≥ 0 and call it the weight of v (with respect to 𝒜). Points v ∈ℙ^2(ℝ) such that w_𝒜(v)=2 are sometimes called double points (of 𝒜). Similarly, points v with w_𝒜(v)=3 are called triple points (of 𝒜). Let C ∈𝒦(𝒜) be a chamber. We associate with C a graph Γ^C defined as follows: the vertices of Γ^C are given by the lines of 𝒜 which bound C and two vertices ℓ, ℓ^' are connected by an edge with weight w_𝒜(ℓ∩ℓ^') if and only if w_𝒜(ℓ∩ℓ^') ≥ 3.  
 
ii)  For 2 ≤ i ≤ |𝒜| we define t^𝒜_i :=| { v ∈ℙ^2(ℝ) | w_𝒜(v)=i }|. This means that t^𝒜_i is the number of points in ℙ^2(ℝ) contained in precisely i lines of 𝒜. The vector t^𝒜∈ℤ^|𝒜|-1 whose i-1-th component is given by t^𝒜_i is called the t-vector of 𝒜. Moreover, if j is maximal with the property t^𝒜_j>0, then we say that the multiplicity of 𝒜 is j and we write m(𝒜):=j.    

iii) Assume that n:=|𝒜| ≥ 3. If 𝒜 is an arrangement such that t^𝒜_2=n-1 and t^𝒜_n-1=1 then 𝒜 is called a near pencil (arrangement) . Near pencil arrangements are usually considered trivial.

sentence:
Let D be a good drawing of K_n, F∈ℱ(D) and v∈ V with v incident to F. 
	Furthermore, let S_v = (u_0,…,u_k) with u_i∈ V∖{v} be a sequence of distinct vertices.
	If u_0 is incident to F and vertex u_i is incident to a face containing F in subdrawing D-{u_0,…, u_i-1} for all 1≤ i ≤ k, then we call S_v simple sequence of v.
