sentence:
[Seq-Shellability]
	Let D be a good drawing of K_n. We call D k-seq-shellable for k≥ 0 if there exists a face F∈ℱ(D) and a sequence of distinct vertices a_0,…,a_k such that a_0 is incident to F and
	
		
  * for each i∈{1,…,k}, vertex a_i is incident to the face containing F in drawing D-{a_0,…,a_i-1} and
		
  * for each i∈{0,…,k}, vertex a_i has a simple sequence S_i=(u_0,…,u_k-i) with u_j∈ V∖{a_0,…,a_i} for 0≤ j ≤ k-i in drawing D-{a_0,…,a_i-1}.

sentence:
Let L be an even lattice of rank n. A subset {_1, …, _n} is called a 4-frame of L if (_i, _j)=4δ_i,j for all i,j.
By abuse of notation, we sometimes call the sublattice ⊕_i=1^n_i a 4-frame, also.

(<cit.>)
  A simple VOA (V,) is said to be framed
  if there exists a set {e^1, …,e^r} of Ising vectors of V such that
  =e^1+ +e^r is an orthogonal decomposition.
  The full subVOA  T_r generated by e^1,…,e^r is called
  an Virasoro frame or simply  a frame of V.
  By abuse of notation, we sometimes call the set of Ising vectors
  { e^1,…, e^r} a frame, also.

sentence:
[<cit.>] Let Ω be a partition of a finite
set of U. A multimatroid Z over (U,Ω), described by its
independent sets, is a triple (U,Ω,ℐ), where ℐ
⊆𝒮(Ω) is such that:



  * for each T ∈𝒯(Ω), (T,ℐ∩2^T) is a
matroid (described by its independent sets) and


  * for any I ∈ℐ and any skew pair p = {x,y} of some
ω∈Ω with ω∩ I = ∅, I ∪{x}∈ℐ or I ∪{y}∈ℐ.

sentence:
A sheltering matroid is a tuple Q = (M,Ω) where M is a matroid
over some ground set U and Ω is a partition of U such that for any
independent set I ∈𝒮(Ω) of M and for any skew pair p =
{x,y} of ω∈Ω with ω∩ I = ∅, I ∪{x}
or I ∪{y} is an independent set of M.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Q = (M,Ω) be a 3-sheltering matroid. Then Q is called
t-regular if, for every T ∈𝒯(Ω), Q - T is
t-regular whenever Q-T is tight.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F be a 4-regular graph, and P a partition of the edge-set
of F into edge-disjoint circuits. The touch-graph Tch(P) is the
graph with a vertex for each circuit of P and an edge for each vertex of
F, the edge corresponding to v incident on the vertex or vertices
corresponding to circuits of P that are incident at v.

    (Z) = {P ∈Π_k   :   PZP^T = Z}.

sentence:
Let (Ω, ≤) be a partially ordered set. A non-empty subset A ⊂Ω is called increasing if

    ω∈ A   and  ω≤ω' ⇒ ω' ∈ A.

Given two probability measures μ_1, μ_2 on (Ω, ℱ),
we say that μ_1 is stochastically smaller than μ_2, denoted by μ_1 ≼μ_2, if

    μ_1(A) ≤μ_2(A)   for all increasing events A.

sentence:
An n × n-matrix A = (a_ij) with integer entries is called a generalized Cartan matrix if
  
    
  * a_ii = 2,
    
  * a_ij < 0 for i ≠ j,
    
  * A is symmetrizable, i.e., there exists a diagonal matrix D with positive entries such that DA is symmetric.
  
  A generalized Cartan matrix is called of finite type if DA is positive definite, and of affine type if DA is positive semi-definite.

sentence:
[Theorem 7.4 of <cit.>]
If 𝒜 is a cluster algebra (i) of geometric type, or (ii) has nondegenerate exchange matrix, and (𝐱,B), (𝐱',B') are two seeds for 𝒜, such that cluster 𝐱' is simply the permutation σ of cluster 𝐱, then the exchange matrices B' and B must also be the same, up to simultaneous permutation of its rows and columns by the same σ.  In particular, the cluster determines the seed in the above cases.

sentence:
[Theorem 1.5 of <cit.>] 
The following three conditions about a cluster algebra 𝒜 = 𝒜(𝐱_0,B_0) are equivalent:



  * Cluster algebra 𝒜 is of finite type.

  * In every seed (𝐱,B) that is mutation-equivalent to (𝐱_0,B_0), the exchange matrix B satisfies |b_ij b_ji| ≤ 3 for all pairs 1 ≤ i, j ≤ n.

  * There exists a mutation-equivalent seed (𝐱_1,B_1) such that the exchange matrix B_1 is a skew-symmetric version of a Cartan matrix of a finite-dimensional Lie algebra[
Given a Cartan matrix A, we make a skew-symmetric B_A by replacing the 2's on the diagonal with 0's, and picking a bipartite coloring of the Dynkin diagram associated to A so that b_ij = |a_ij| if directed edge v_i → v_j would go from white to black, and b_ij = - |a_ij| otherwise, see Section <ref>.].

In particular, cluster algebras of finite type are given by the same Cartan-Killing classification as that describing Lie algebras via Dynkin diagrams: 
    A_n,  B_n,  C_n,  D_n,  E_6,  E_7,  E_8,  F_4, and  G_2.

sentence:
[Theorem 6.1 of <cit.>]
The following two conditions about a cluster algebra 𝒜 = 𝒜(𝐱_0,B_0) with skew-symmetric B_0 are equivalent:

 
  * 𝒜 is of finite mutation type,
 
  * 𝒜 has one of the following properties:
  
   
  * 𝒜 is of rank 2,
   
  * 𝒜 is associated to a cluster algebra corresponding to a surface , or
   
  * 𝒜 is one of 11 exceptional types E_6, E_7, E_8, affine Ẽ_6, Ẽ_7, Ẽ_8, elliptic Ẽ_6^(1), Ẽ_7^(1), Ẽ_8^(1), or one of two other types X_6 and X_7, which were found by Derksen and Owen <cit.>.

sentence:
[Theorems 2.8 and 5.13 of <cit.>]
The following three conditions about a cluster algebra 𝒜 = 𝒜(𝐱_0,B_0) with skew-symmetrizable B_0 are equivalent:

 
  * 𝒜 is of finite mutation type,
 
  * In every seed (𝐱,B) that is mutation-equivalent to (𝐱_0,B_0), the exchange matrix B satisfies |b_ij b_ji| ≤ 4 for all pairs 1 ≤ i, j ≤ n.
 
  * 𝒜 has one of the following properties:
  
   
  * 𝒜 is of rank 2,
   
  * 𝒜 is decomposable into blocks , as described in <cit.>, or
   
  * 𝒜 is one of the 11 exceptional types in Theorem <ref> or one of the 7 exceptional types G̃_2, F_4, F̃_4, V_4, W_4, Y_4, and Z_6.

[Theorem 1.9 of <cit.>]
  Let 𝒜 be a Cluster algebra of finite type and let Φ_≥ -1 = Φ^+ ∪ -Δ be the set of almost positive roots of the root system of the associated Cartan type given by the positive roots together with the simple negative roots. There exists a unique bijection between almost positive roots and the cluster variables for 𝒜 for which the simple negative root -α is mapped to x_α and, for positive roots,
  
    ∑_α∈Δn_αα↦P_α/∏ x_α^n_α,

  with P_α having nonzero constant term. Here, x_α_i stands for x_i for an appropriate ordering Δ = {α_0, …, α_n-1}.

sentence:
[Skew-symmetrizable matrices]
  An n-by-n matrix B is called skew-symmetrizable if there exists a diagonal integer matrix D with strictly positive entries on the diagonal such that DB is skew-symmetric.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Labeled Seed for a cluster algebra]
A labeled seed for a cluster algebra 𝒜 = 𝒜(𝐱,𝐲,B) is a triple (𝐱, 𝐲, B) where


 
  * 𝐱 = {x_0,x_1,…, x_n-1} is a cluster of n algebraically independent elements of ambient field ℱ,

 
  * 𝐲 = {y_0,y_1,…, y_n-1} is an n-tuple of coefficients, elements of the semifield ℙ, and 

 
  * B is an n-by-n matrix that is skew-symmetrizable.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Cluster Algebras of Geometric Type]
A cluster algebra of geometric type is one where the coefficient semifield ℙ is a special choice which leads to a great simplification of the above formulas.  In this case,

    ℙ= Trop(u_0,u_1,u_2,…, u_m-1)

where the addition ⊕ in Trop(u_0,u_1,u_2,…, u_m-1) is defined as 
    ∏_j u_j^a_j⊕∏_j u_j^b_j = ∏_j u_j^min(a_j,b_j).
  In particular, note that if y_i = ∏_j u_j^a_j where all a_j ≥ 0, then y_i ⊕ 1 = 1.  With ℙ given as this tropical semifield, the group ring ℤℙ is simply the ring of Laurent polynomials ℤ[u_0^± 1, u_1^± 1, …, u_m-1^± 1].

sentence:
[Principal coefficients]
An important cluster algebra of geometric type is one with principal coefficients .  In this case, the initial exchange matrix B is 2n-by-n and where the last n rows of this matrix is a rank n identity matrix.

sentence: A quiver Q is a directed graph.  We will only work with quivers on a finite number of vertices and which contains no loops (1-cycles) or 2-cycles.  However, we do allow our quivers to have multiple edges between a pair of vertices, but since there are no 2-cycles, this means that all edges between two vertices must have the same direction.  In general there is no restriction against oriented cycles on ≥ 3 vertices.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Constructing a pair-weighted quiver from an exchange matrix]
To get a quiver Q_B from an (m+n)-by-n exchange matrix B is the reverse of the above construction, however, there are two nuances to emphasize.




  * For a cluster algebra seed to correspond to a quiver, the corresponding matrix B must satisfy b_ij = - b_ji for all pairs 0 ≤ i,j≤ n-1.  In other words, the top n-by-n portion of B must be skew-symmetric, not just skew-symmetrizable.  Since cluster algebras for non-skew-symmetric seeds are also quite prevalent in the literature, our package works with a slight generalization of quivers, which we call pair-weighted quivers .  

We do not allow parallel edges in such quivers, and instead, we label each directed edge as an ordered pair [b_ij, b_ji] such that the associated edge is oriented from v_i to v_j.  Consequently, the first entry of each such pair is necessarily positive and the second is negative, but the direction of the edge must also be recorded.  In the case that b_ji = -b_ij, i.e. the case of parallel edges, this label is simplified to be simply the positive number b_ij.  We also omit the label b_ij=1 when displaying graphics to make pictures easier to view.  

Note, that this notation differs from that in places such as <cit.> or <cit.>, but is necessarily for precise computations.  Our notation is inspired by Dlab-Ringel <cit.> and Dupont-Pérotin <cit.>.


  * If m > 0, i.e. the matrix has more rows than columns, and for any b_ij where i ≥ n, there is no b_ji in the matrix and so we do not have to worry about checking skew-symmetry for such entries.  However, such vertices v_i correspond to a frozen variable and so we designate these vertices accordingly as “frozen vertices” to remind the user not to mutate or apply exchanges at such vertices.

sentence:
[Mutation-equivalence]
   Two quivers Q_1, Q_2 are said to be mutation-equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by a finite sequence of mutations, i.e., if there exists a finite sequence i_1,…,i_k such that μ_i_k∘…∘μ_i_1(Q_1) = Q_2. The collection of all quivers mutation-equivalent to a given quiver Q is called mutation class of Q.

sentence:
We use Σ_0 = (𝐱_0, B) to denote an initial bipartite seed and let μ_+ (resp. μ_-) denote the concatenation of all mutations at sources (sinks) of the quiver Q(B)[Since sources and sinks are not adjacent, the factors of μ_+ (resp. μ_-) commute with one another, hence why μ_+ and μ_- are well-defined.].  Observe that μ_+(B) = μ_-(B) = -B. 

Define the associated bipartite belt to be the seeds Σ_m = (𝐱_𝐦, (-1)^m B) for m ∈ℤ, defined recursively by 

    Σ_r = μ_+ (Σ_r-1)     if r is odd
    μ_- (Σ_r-1)     if r is even.

sentence:
[Generalized Cartan matrix]
  An n × n-matrix A = (a_ij) with integer entries is called a generalized Cartan matrix if
  
    
  * a_ii = 2,
    
  * a_ij < 0 for i ≠ j,
    
  * A is symmetrizable, i.e., there exists a diagonal matrix D with positive entries such that DA is symmetric.
  
  A generalized Cartan matrix is called of finite type if DA is positive definite, and of affine type if DA is positive semi-definite.

sentence: A Dyck prefix of length n is a sequence A=(A_1,…,A_n) of u's and d's such that for each i≤ n, there are at least as many u's as d's in A_1,…,A_i. If A and A' are two Dyck prefixes of the same length, we say A≥ A' if A_1,…,A_i has at least as many u's as A'_1,…,A'_i for each i≤ n.

A valid hook configuration is reduced if every point in the plot of the permutation is
either a hook endpoint (both southwest and northeast endpoints count) or a descent bottom. A decomposition  into k colors is r-admissible if 

 
  * d_(i)(v) ≤ r for each v ∈ V(K_n) and 1≤ i ≤ k,

  * If C is a connected component of (i), then C contains a vertex of degree at most r-2 in (i) or at least two vertices of degree at most r-1 in (i).

For every v∈ V define the balance of v as
  
    (v):=8(n-_B(v))/^2(1-)(3+)-4_M(v)(2-_M(v)).

Consider the game at an arbitrary point of time.

  a function that is analytic in a neighborhood of 0.
  The m-th (s-variate) Todd polynomial is the coefficient of x^m
  in the Taylor expansion

sentence:
Let n be any integer greater than 1.  A d-tupling function f is said to be base-n perfect if and only if, for all non-negative integers x_1, x_2, …, x_d and k,

    _n(x_1)≤ k  _n(x_2)≤ k  ⋯  _n(x_d)≤ k

implies

    _n(f(x_1,x_2,…,x_d))≤ dk.

In the special case where n=2, any such function is said to be binary perfect .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let a and b be any positive integers, and let n be any integer greater than 1.  A pairing function f is said to be base-n proportional with constants of proportionality a and b if and only if, for all non-negative integers x, y, and k,

    (_n(x)≤ ak  _n(y)≤ bk)  implies  _n(f(x,y))≤ ak+bk.

In the special case where n=2, any such function is said to be binary proportional .

sentence:
Let n be any integer greater than 1.  A function fℕ^2→ℕ is said to be a base-n discrete space-filling curve if and only if there exist permutations τ, σ_0, σ_1, …, σ_n^2-1 in S_n^2 such that the following three conditions hold.


  (a) τ(0)=0 and σ_0(0)=0.

  (b) f(0,0)=0.

  (c) For all non-negative integers x, y, and z such that (x,y)(0,0), f(x,y)=z if and only if

    σ_0^-(m-1)∘τ(nx_m-1+y_m-1)   =z_m-1,
    σ_z_m-1∘σ_0^-(m-1)∘τ(nx_m-2+y_m-2)   =z_m-2,
    σ_z_m-2∘σ_z_m-1∘σ_0^-(m-1)∘τ(nx_m-3+y_m-3)   =z_m-3,
         ⋮
    σ_z_1∘⋯∘σ_z_m-2∘σ_z_m-1∘σ_0^-(m-1)∘τ(nx_0+y_0)   =z_0,

where m=max(_n(x),_n(y)), where

    x   =x_m-1n^m-1+x_m-2n^m-2+⋯+x_0n^0,
    
    y   =y_m-1n^m-1+y_m-2n^m-2+⋯+y_0n^0

are base-n expansions of x and y, and where

    z=z_m-1(n^2)^m-1+z_m-2(n^2)^m-2+⋯+z_0(n^2)^0

is a base-n^2 expansion of z.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let n be any integer greater than 1.  A function fℕ^3→ℕ is said to be a 3-dimensional base-n discrete space-filling curve if and only if there exist permutations τ, σ_0, σ_1, …, σ_n^3-1 in S_n^3 such that the following three conditions hold.


  (a) τ(0)=0 and σ_0(0)=0.

  (b) f(0,0,0)=0.

  (c) For all non-negative integers w, x, y, and z such that (w,x,y)(0,0,0), f(w,x,y)=z if and only if

    σ_0^-(m-1)∘τ(n^2w_m-1+nx_m-1+y_m-1)   =z_m-1,
    σ_z_m-1∘σ_0^-(m-1)∘τ(n^2w_m-2+nx_m-2+y_m-2)   =z_m-2,
    σ_z_m-2∘σ_z_m-1∘σ_0^-(m-1)∘τ(n^2w_m-3+nx_m-3+y_m-3)   =z_m-3,
         ⋮
    σ_z_1∘⋯∘σ_z_m-2∘σ_z_m-1∘σ_0^-(m-1)∘τ(n^2w_0+nx_0+y_0)   =z_0,

where m=max(_n(w),_n(x),_n(y)), where

    w   =w_m-1n^m-1+w_m-2n^m-2+⋯+w_0n^0,
    
    x   =x_m-1n^m-1+x_m-2n^m-2+⋯+x_0n^0,
    
    y   =y_m-1n^m-1+y_m-2n^m-2+⋯+y_0n^0

are base-n expansions of w, x and y, and where

    z=z_m-1(n^3)^m-1+z_m-2(n^3)^m-2+⋯+z_0(n^3)^0

is a base-n^3 expansion of z.

sentence:
A sequence {a_i}_i=0^n of nonnegative real numbers is said to be unimodal if
there exists an index 0≤ m ≤ n, called the mode of the sequence, such that
a_0≤ a_1 ≤⋯≤ a_m-1≤ a_m ≥ a_m+1≥⋯≥ a_n. The sequence
is said to be logarithmically concave (or log-concave for short) if

    a_i^2≥ a_i-1a_i+1,       1≤ i ≤ n-1.

sentence:
A m × n parallelogram polyomino is a pair of (m+n)-tuples (r, g), where r = (r_1,…,r_m+n), g = (g_1,…,g_m+n) are such that
	
	
		
  * r_i, g_i ∈{0,1} for all i,
		
  * if 1 ≤ i < m+n, then g_1 + … + g_i < r_1 + … + r_i,
		
  * g_1 + … + g_m+n = r_1 + … + r_m+n = n.

sentence: A rise of a parallelogram polyomino is a pair of consecutive letters in its area word such that the former is barred, and the latter is its successor in the alphabet (e.g. 1̅2, 2̅3, …).

  * if 1 ≤ i ≤ m+n, then g_1 + … + g_i ≤ r_1 + … + r_i,
		
  * g_1 + … + g_m+n = r_1 + … + r_m+n = n.

We define the statistic  on a parking function PF of size n as follows.
	
	Let C_1 be the multiset containing the labels appearing in the first column of PF, and let w_1 max C_1. Then, at step i, let C_i be the multiset obtained from C_i-1 by removing w_i-1 and adding all the labels in the i-th column of the PF; let w_i max {a ∈ C_i | a ≤ w_i-1} if this last set is non-empty, and w_i max  C_i otherwise. Set w  w_1w_2⋯ w_n. Finally, we define (PF) 𝗆𝖺𝗃(w_nw_n-1⋯ w_1), where 𝗆𝖺𝗃 is the usual major index on words, i.e. 𝗆𝖺𝗃(a_1 a_2 ⋯ a_k) is the sum of the i such that a_i>a_i+1, for i=1,2,… k-1.

sentence:
Let D be a digraph. A function s:V(D)→ is a semi-Grundy function if
  satisfies:
  
  
  * s(x)=k implies that each y∈Γ^+(x) satisfies
    s(y)≠k; 
  
  * s(x)=k and y∈Γ^+(x) with s(y)>k implies that there exists
    z∈Γ^+(y) such that s(z)=k.

sentence:
Suppose  is the Pontryagin dual group to (V) for a set V.


  * For all finite sets E ∈_0(V), we have χ_E ∈,
with image in {± 1 }.


  *  is a discrete (locally compact) abelian group, which is
metrizable if V is countable.


  * (Plancherel's Theorem.) The Fourier transform, when
restricted to (L^1 ∩ L^2)((V)), is a linear isometry in the
L^2-metric, onto a dense subset of L^2(). Hence it has a unique
extension to a unitary operator from L^2((V)) onto L^2() (for
some Haar measure μ^∧ on ).


  * When V is countable,  is precisely the set of Walsh
functions, and the assignment χ_E ↦ E := { e ∈ K_V :
χ_E({ e }) = -1 } is a group isomorphism onto (_0(V), Δ).

sentence:
Given a fixed labelled set V, define the corresponding (labelled) graph
space (V) to be the set of all graphs with vertex set V. In other
words, (V) = { 0, 1 }^K_V = ( / 2 )^K_V, where K_V is the
complete graph on V.
Also define _0(V) to be the set of all graphs with finitely many
edges, and _1(V) to be the set of all co-finite graphs –
i.e., the complements in K_V of finite graphs.

sentence:
Given disjoint subsets I_0, I_1 ⊂ K_V, define

    (I_0, I_1) := { G ∈(V) : I_1 ⊂ G, I_0 ⊂ K_V
    ∖ G }.


Now define the following σ-algebras on (V):


  * _(V) is the Borel σ-algebra , generated by
all open sets.


  * Σ_0 is the σ-algebra generated by all compact sets.


  * Σ_ is the σ-algebra generated by all sets (I_0,
I_1) for disjoint I_0, I_1 ⊂ K_V.


  * Σ_,0 is the σ-algebra generated by all (I_0,
I_1) for finite (or countable) disjoint I_0, I_1 ⊂ K_V.

sentence:
A circular unit arc digraph is a directed graph with vertex set [n] and edges

    i → i+1,   i → i+2, …, i → i+a_i

for all i = 1,…,n, where vertex indices are taken modulo n, and the integers a_1,…,a_n satisfy

 
  * 0 ≤ a_i ≤ n-1 for 1 ≤ i ≤ n,
 
  * a_i -1 ≤ a_i+1 for 1 ≤ i ≤ n,

where the index is again taken mod n in the second condition. 
We denote this directed graph Γ_.

sentence:
Let  be a k-tuple of skew Young diagrams.
Given such a tuple, we let 
() = (^1) ×(^2)×…×(^k)
where (λ) is the set of skew semi-standard Young tableaux of shape λ.
Given T = (T^1,T^2,…,T^k) ∈(),
let ^T denote the product _T^1…_T^k where _T^i
is the usual weight of the semi-standard Young tableau T^i.
Entries T^i(u) > T^j(v) form an inversion if
either 

 
  * i<j and c(u) = c(v), or
 
  * i>j and c(u) = c(v)+1, 

where c(u) denotes the content of u. The content of a cell (i,j) in a skew diagram is i-j. 
Finally, we can define the LLT polynomial 

    _(;q) = ∑_T ∈()  q^(T)_T

where (T) is the total number of inversions appearing in T.

sentence:
Let G = (,φ, w) be a PD0L-system. We say that two interpretations (p,v,s) and (p',v',s') of a word u ∈ SL(G) are synchronized at position k if there exist nonnegative indices i and j such that

    φ(v_1⋯ v_i) = p u_1 ⋯ u_k    and   φ(v'_1⋯ v'_j) = p' u_1 ⋯ u_k

with v = v_1⋯ v_n, v' = v'_0 ⋯ v'_m and u = u_1 ⋯ u_ℓ  (see Figure <ref>).

We say that a word u ∈ S(L(G)) has a synchronizing point at position k with 0 ≤ k ≤ |u| if all its interpretations are pairwise synchronized at position k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

w^k ∈ S(L(G)) for all k and w contains at least one unbounded letter.

sentence:
definition]def:circular-system
	 Let G = (,φ, w) be a PD0L-system and let (p,v,s) and (p',v',s') be two interpretations of a non-empty word u ∈ S(L(G)) with v = v_1⋯ v_n, v' = v'_0 ⋯ v'_m and u = u_1 ⋯ u_ℓ.
	 
	 We say that G is circular with synchronization delay D > 0 if whenever we have 
	 
    |φ(v_1⋯ v_i)| - |p| > D   and   |φ(v_i+1⋯ v_n)| - |s| > D

	 for some 1 ≤ i ≤ n, then there is 1 ≤ j ≤ m such that
	 
    |φ(v_1⋯ v_i-1| - |p| = |φ(v'_1⋯ v'_j-1)| - |p'|

	 and v_i = v'_j (see Figure <ref>).

sentence:
Let T be a spanning edge-capacitated tree.  An edge
  e=ab ∈ E(T) is encoding if its fundamental cut G(A,B)
  is a minimum ab-cut and its capacity is c'(e), that is,
  c(G(A,B))=c'(e).

sentence:
For fixed n, let S= { s_1, …, s_k } with 1≤ s_1< … <s_k<n
  be given. Also, set s_0=0 and s_k+1=n. Define the Cartesian product
  
    _n(S) = [0,k]^s_k+1-s_k×…× [0,1]^s_2-s_1× [0,0]^s_1-s_0.

  We shall call an element of _n(S) a construction choice .

sentence:
Let G be a permutation group on Ω.


  (a) G is non-synchronizing if and only if there is a non-trivial
partition P of Ω and a subset A of Ω such that, for all
g∈ G, Ag is a transversal for P. (We will say that the pair (A,P)
witnesses non-synchronization.)

  (b) G is non-synchronizing if and only if there is a graph Γ
on the vertex set Ω, not complete or null, with clique number equal
to chromatic number, such that G≤(Γ).

sentence:
Let G be a simple graph which is _2-symmetric with respect to θ. 
Suppose there exists a graph H and distinct vertices v_1,v_2∈ V(H) with the following properties.


  * V(G)=V(H)∪{v,sv} where v,sv∉ V(H) and v≠sv.

  * H is _2-symmetric with respect to θ.

  * E(G)=E(H)∪{vv_1,vv_2,s(vv_1),s(vv_2)}.

Then  G is said to be obtained from H by applying a (_2,θ) 0-extension (on the vertices v_1,v_2).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a simple graph which is _2-symmetric with respect to θ. 
Suppose there exists a graph H, distinct vertices v_1,v_2,v_3∈ V(H) and an edge e=v_1v_2∈ E(H) with the following properties.


  * V(G)=V(H)∪{v,sv} where v,sv∉ V(H) and v≠sv.

  * H is _2-symmetric with respect to θ  and e≠se.

  * E(G)=(E(H)∖{e,se})∪{vv_i,s(vv_i) |   i=1,2,3}.

Then  G is said to be obtained from H by applying a (_2,θ) 1-extension (on the vertices v_1,v_2,v_3 and the edge e).

sentence:
The quasisymmetric composition poset , denoted by , is the poset consisting of all compositions with cover relation  such that for compositions  α, β

    ⋂_i=0^k-1(CA^i)={0}.

sentence: Let V be a vector space over a field F and W be a subspace of V. An F-linear transformation T:W→ V is defined to be simple if the only T-invariant subspace properly contained in V is the zero subspace.

sentence:
Let ξ, ζ be real random variables with mean zero.  We say W is a Wigner matrix of size n with atom variables 
ξ,ζ if W = (w_ij)_i,j=1^n is a random real symmetric n × n matrix that satisfies the following conditions.


  * (independence) {w_ij : 1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ n} is a collection of independent random variables.

  * (off-diagonal entries) {w_ij : 1 ≤ i < j ≤ n} is a collection of independent and identically distributed (iid) copies of ξ.

  * (diagonal entries) {w_ii : 1 ≤ i ≤ n} is a collection of iid copies of ζ.  

If ξ and ζ have the same distribution, we say W is a Wigner matrix with atom variable ξ.  In this case, W is a real symmetric matrix whose entries on and above the diagonal are iid copies of ξ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A random variable ξ is K-bounded if |ξ| ≤ K almost surely. For combinatorial applications, the entries usually take on values {0, ± 1} and are 
1-bounded.  In general, we allow K to depend on n.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A random variable ξ is called sub-exponential with exponent α > 0  if there exists  a constant β  > 0 such that 

    (|ξ| > t) ≤βexp(- t^α / β )   for all  t > 0.
  If α=2, then ξ is called sub-gaussian , and 1 / β is the sub-gaussian moment of ξ.

  * (independence) {w_ij : 1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ n} is a collection of independent random variables.

  * (off-diagonal entries) {w_ij : 1 ≤ i < j ≤ n} is a collection of independent and identically distributed (iid) copies of ξ.

sentence: Let a=(a_1,a_2,a_3) and b=(b_1,b_2,b_3) be two triples of integers. Say that a is 2-less than b, or a<_2b, if a_i<b_i for at least two coordinates i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A sequence (a^i) of integer triples is 2-increasing if for all i<j we have a^i<_2a^j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: Two triples t_1 and t_2 are 2-comparable if one of them is 2-less than the other. A set of triples is 2-comparable if any two of them are 2-comparable.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: An r-tuple a=(a_1,…,a_r) of integers is s-less than an r-tuple b=(b_1,…,b_r) if a_i<b_i for at least s values of i. In that case we write a<_sb. An s-increasing sequence of r-tuples is a sequence (a^1,…,a^m) such that a^i<_sa^j whenever i<j. Two r-tuples are s-comparable if one is s-less than the other, and an s-comparable set of r-tuples is a set {a^1,…,a^m} such that any two distinct elements of the set are s-comparable.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let H be a collection of integer triples entirely contained in one of the planes (x,*,*), (*,y,*) or (*,*,z). Suppose that when we project H onto the two free coordinates (obtaining a collection H_p of integer pairs) we have no two elements of H_p that are 2-comparable as pairs, in the obvious sense. Then we say that H is a collapsible collection of triples.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: Let I and J be two real intervals. Say that I<J if x<y for every x∈ I and y∈ J. If I_1,I_2,I_3 and J_1,J_2,J_3 are real intervals, then I_1× I_2× I_3<_2J_1× J_2× J_3 if I_h<J_h for at least two values of h. If C and C' are two cuboids, then they are 2-comparable if C<_2C' or C'<_2C. A sequence of cuboids C_i⊂ℝ^3 is 2-increasing if C_i<_2C_j whenever i<j. It is 2-comparable if any two distinct C_i are 2-comparable.

sentence: We denote by S(c) the collection of cells from G with label c. We call such sets label sets . We also write P(c) for the set of cells in [n]^2 that share both a row and a column with a cell from S(c). We call P(c) the completion of S(c).

sentence: Define the upper completion of a label set S(c) to be the set P_1(c) of cells from G that have points labelled c both directly below them and directly to the right, and the lower completion P_2(c) to be the set of cells from G that have points labelled c both directly above and directly to the left.

[Chains] 
A chain is a set C⊂^n such that  for every distinct  
𝐱,𝐲∈ C we either have  
𝐱≤𝐲, or 𝐲≤𝐱.

sentence:
An orientable surface-link in ℝ^4 is unknotted if it is equivalent to a surface embedded in ℝ^3×{0}⊂ℝ^4. A marked graph diagram for an unknotted standard sphere is shown in Fig. <ref>(a), an unknotted standard torus is in Fig. <ref>(d). An embedded projective plane ℙ^2 in ℝ^4 is unknotted if it is equivalent to a surface whose marked graph diagram is an unknotted standard projective plane , which looks like in Fig. <ref>(b) that is a positive ℙ^2_+ or looks like in Fig. <ref>(c) that is a negative ℙ^2_-. These are inequivalent surfaces and are mirror images to one another. A non-orientable surface embedded in ℝ^4 is unknotted if it is equivalent to some finite connected sum or split unions of unknotted projective planes.

By a standard surface-unlink marked diagram we mean the diagram obtained by taking connected sums or split unions (in the plane) of the standard sphere or the standard tori or the standard projective plane diagrams.

sentence:
<cit.>
Let U_1⊇ U_2⊇… be an infinite nested sequence of non-empty connected open subsets of X such that for each n∈ the boundary ∂ U of U_n is compact, ⋂_n∈U_n=∅ and for any compact  K⊂ X there exist m∈ℕ such that K∩ U_m =∅. We denote the sequence U_1⊇ U_2⊇… as (U_n)_n∈ℕ. Two such sequences (U_n)_n∈ℕ and (U'_n)_n∈ℕ are said to be equivalent if for every l∈ there exist k such that U_l⊇ U'_k and viceversa, that is, for every n∈ there exist m such that U'_n⊇ U_m. The corresponding equivalence classes are also called topological ends of X and we will denote it by Ends(S).

sentence:
For any graph G=(V,E) and proportion p ∈ [0,1], a set S⊆ V is a p-dominating set if 
    |N[S]|/|V|≥ p.
  The p-domination number γ_p(G) equals the minimum cardinality of a p-dominating set in G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒞 be a polyhedral complex in ^n.
A projection π:^n→^m+1 is called geometrically regular 
if the following two conditions hold.


  * For any k-face σ of 𝒞
  we have (π(σ))=k, 0 ≤ k ≤𝒞  .

  * If π(σ)⊆π(τ) then σ⊆τ for all σ,τ∈𝒞  .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: <cit.> A star edge coloring   of  a graph G is a proper edge coloring of G such that  no path or cycle of length four in G is bi-colored.    The smallest integer k   that G admits a k-star edge coloring is called star chromatic index  of G and is denoted by  χ^'_s(G).

sentence:
Let B be a crystal with index set I. Then B is called regular if
for any 2-subset J⊂ I, we have that the restriction of B to its J-arrows
is a classical rank two crystal.

sentence:
Let P be a finite poset and λ P^*→ be a real valued order-preserving map on an induced subposet P^*⊆ P.
    We say (P,λ) is a marked poset with marking λ, marked elements P^* and denote by P̃ = P∖ P^* the set of all unmarked elements .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let (P,λ) be a marked poset such that P^* contains at least all minimal elements of P.
    For t∈[0,1]^P̃ we define the marked poset polyhedron _t(P,λ) as the set of all x∈^P satisfying the following conditions:
    
        
  * for each a∈ P^* an equation
                x_a = λ(a),
        
  * for each saturated chain p_0≺ p_1 ≺ p_2 ≺⋯≺ p_r ≺ p with p_0∈ P^*, p_i∈P̃ for i≥ 1, p∈ P and r≥ 0 an inequality
            
    (1-t_p) ( 
                    t_p_1⋯ t_p_r x_p_0 + t_p_2⋯ t_p_r x_p_1 + ⋯ + t_p_rx_p_r-1+x_p_r) ≤ x_p,

            where t_p=0 if p∈ P^*. Note that the inequalities for p∈ P^* and r=0 may be omitted, since they are consequences of λ being order-preserving.
    
    Since the coordinates in P^* are fixed, we sometimes consider the projection of _t(P,λ) in ^P̃ instead and we keep the same notation for the projection.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a partition P̃=C⊔ O, an element q∈ O is called a chain-order star element if there are at least two different saturated chains s≺ q_1≺⋯≺ q_k ≺ q with s∈ P^*⊔ O and all q_i∈ C and there are at least two different saturated chains q ≺ q_1≺⋯≺ q_k ≺ s with s∈ P^*⊔ O and all q_i∈ C.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given two polyhedra Q_0 and Q_1 in ^n, a continuous deformation from Q_0 to Q_1 consists of the following data:
    
        
  * A continuous map ρ Q_0× [0,1]→^n, such that each ρ_t=ρ(-,t) is an embedding, ρ_0 is the identical embedding of Q_0 and the image of ρ_1 is Q_1.
        
  * Finitely many continuous functions f^1,f^2,…,f^k^n× [0,1]→ such that for all i and t the maps f^i_t = f^i(-,t)^n→ are affine linear forms and satisfy
            
    ρ_t(Q_0) = {  x∈^n  | 
                        f^i_t(x) ≥ 0  for all i }.

    
    Hence, the images ρ_t(Q_0) are all polyhedra and we write Q_t for ρ_t(Q_0) and say (Q_t)_t∈ [0,1] is a continuous deformation when the accompanying maps ρ and f^i are clear from the context.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A continuous deformation (Q_t)_t∈ [0,1] as in <Ref> is called a continuous degeneration if for all x∈ Q_0, t<1 and i=1,…,k we have f^i_t(ρ_t(x)) = 0 if and only if f^i_0(x) = 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let u∈[0,1]^P̃ and let I⊆P̃ be the set of indices p, such that u_p∈{0,1}.
    Any u'∈[0,1]^P̃ such that u'_p=u_p for p∈ I  is called a degeneration of u.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let ((P,λ)) be the polyhedral subdivision of ^P associated to the marked poset (P,λ).
    The tropical subdivision (P,λ) of (P,λ) is given by the intersection of faces of (P,λ) with the faces of ((P,λ)):
    
    (P,λ) = {  F∩ G  |  F∈((P,λ)), G∈((P,λ))  }.

    For t∈[0,1]^P̃ define the tropical subdivision of _t(P,λ) as
    
    _t(P,λ) = {φ_t(Q)  |  Q∈(P,λ) }.

sentence: A marked poset (P,λ) is called tame if the inequalities given in <Ref> correspond to the facets of _C,O(P,λ) for all partitions P̃=C⊔ O.

sentence:
A marked poset (P,λ) is called ranked if there exists a rank function P→ satisfying
    
           
  * p + 1 =  q for all p,q∈ P with p≺ q,
        
  * λ(a) < λ(b) for all a,b∈ P^* with a <  b.

sentence: Let L be an r× m integer matrix. We say the system of equations Lx=0 alternatively, the matrix L has complexity k if k is the smallest integer such that, for any ϵ>0, there exists δ>0 with the following property: let G= or _p for any large prime p>p_0(L); then for any f,g: G→ with f_L_∞(G),g_L_∞(G) both at most 1 and f-g_U^k+1(G)≤δ, we have |S_L,G(f)-S_L,G(g)|≤ϵ.

sentence: For a graph H and positive integer k≥χ (H), let the j-localized k-coloring graph of H, denoted G^j_k(H), be the graph whose vertices are the proper k-colorings of H, with edges joining two colorings if H contains a connected subgraph on at most j vertices containing all vertices where the colorings differ (see Figure <ref>).  Let the k-color mixing number of H, denoted g_k(H), be the least j such that G^j_k(H) is connected, and let the k-color Gray code number of H, denoted h_k(H), be the least j such that G^j_k(H) is Hamiltonian.

sentence:
Each well-founded poset P 
admits an ordinal valued rank function _P
defined inductively on its elements:
_P(a) = sup_x <_P a(_P(x) + 1)

sentence:
[Aboulker–Charbit–Trotignon–Vušković <cit.>]
  Let  be a set of graphs. An -elimination ordering
  of a graph G is an ordering v_1, …, v_n of the vertices of
  G such that for each i, the induced subgraph G[N(v_i) ∩{v_i+1, …, v_n}] has no induced subgraph isomorphic to a
  graph in .

sentence:
A graph G is semichordal if it admits a
  {P_3}-elimination ordering, where P_3 is the path on three
  vertices.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  A graph G is a wheel if there is a vertex v of degree
  at least 3 such that G-v is isomorphic to a cycle. The vertex
  v is the center of the wheel and the subgraph G-v is the
  rim of the wheel. A wheel is a 3-wheel if there are
  three consecutive vertices x,y,z on the rim such that the center
  is adjacent to x, y, and z.

sentence:
Given a graph G and an integer t ≥ 0, let (G) be the
  family of all cliques in G, and let _t(G) be the family of
  all t-cliques in G.  Let w : _t →_≥ 0 be a
  weight function on the t-cliques of G. A (w,K_t)-cover
  of G is a function f : (G) → such that
  ∑_k ⊂ Kf(K) ≥ w(k) for all k ∈_t(G), where the sum
  ranges over all K ∈(G) with k ⊂ K.  When f is a
  (w,K_t)-cover, we write (f) for the sum ∑_K ∈(G)f(K).  The (w,K_t)-cover number of G, written
  (G), is the minimum value of (f) over all
  (w,K_t)-covers of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The (w,K_t)-clique packing number
of G, written (G), is the optimum value of the following integer program:

    maximize∑_k ∈_t(G)w(k)y(k),    subject to
    ∑_k ⊂ Ky(k)    ≤ 1,  for all K ∈(G), 
    
      y(k)    ≥ 0, for all k ∈_t(G)
    
      y(k)    ∈.

A feasible solution to this integer program is called a
(w,K_t)-packing . When y is a (w,K_t)-packing write
(y) for ∑_k ∈_t(G)w(k)y(k). (In some circumstances
it may be ambiguous which weight function is used to calculate (y), in
which case we write _w(y) to specify the weight function being used.)

sentence:
[(2k+1)-tetrahedra]
Given k≥ 2 we denote by  the set of graphs T consisting of


  * one cycle C_T with three branch vertices a_T, b_T, and c_T∈ V(C_T),

  * a center vertex z_T, and 

  * internally vertex disjoint paths (called spokes ) 
P_az, P_bz, P_cz connecting the branch vertices with the center. 
Furthermore, we require that
each cycle in T containing z and exactly two of the branch vertices must have length 2k+1 and two of the spokes have length at least two.

sentence:
* In the (k,ℓ)-Weyl graph Γ_i,j;k,ℓ^n(Δ), a pair of vertices (I,J) ∈ C_1 × C_2 is adjacent precisely if 𝗍(I ∩ J)=k and 𝗍(I^J)=ℓ,

  * In the k-incidence graph Γ_i,j;k^n(Δ), a pair of vertices (I,J) ∈ C_1 × C_2 is adjacent precisely if t(I ∩ J)=k,

  * In the k_≥-incidence graph Γ_i,j;≥ k^n(Δ), a pair of vertices (I,J) ∈ C_1 × C_2 is adjacent precisely if (I∩ J) ≥ |k|.

sentence: A set {J_1,J_2,J_3,J_4} of four distinct elements of Ω_j is called  a round-up quadruple if every vertex that is adjacent to at least two of them is adjacent to at least three of them and the sets 𝖭(J_1,J_2,J_3,J_4) and 𝖭(J_1,J_2,J_3)∖𝖭(J_1,J_2,J_3,J_4) are nonempty for any permutation of the indices.

sentence: For t ∈𝖳, the t-Grassmann graph 𝖦_t(Δ) has Ω_t as vertex set, and two vertices U and V are adjacent if (U ∩ V) = max{T ∩ T' | T,T' ∈Ω_t, T ≠ T'} and (U^V)=(V^U)= min{|t|+1,n-1}.

sentence:
Let π be a permutation (or a classical pattern) of length n. We define
the up-shift of π, as π^↑, where

    π^↑_i = (π_i  n) + 1,   for 1 ≤ i ≤ n.

Let p = (τ, R) be a mesh pattern of length n. We define the
up-shift of p as the pattern p^↑ = (τ^↑,
R^↑), where

    R^↑ = {a(b+1)  (n+1)ab∈ R }.

sentence:
[Ulfarsson <cit.>]
Let π be a permutation (or a classical pattern) of length n. We define
the toric-shift of π as

    π^t = (π^0 ⊞ 1)_0.

Let p = (τ, R) be a mesh pattern of length n. We define the
toric-shift of p as the pattern p^t = (τ^t, R^t), where

    R^t = {a + (n+1-ℓ)  (n+1)b + 1  (n+1)ab∈ R }.

Here ℓ is the position of the letter n in the classical pattern τ.

sentence:
Two mesh patterns p and q are said to be coincident , denoted by
p ≍ q, if for any permutation π, π avoids p if and only if
π avoids q.

sentence:
A Wilf-subclass is a set containing patterns of the same length which
are Wilf-equivalent. A Wilf-class is a maximal Wilf-subclass.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
If a permutation sends letters 1,2,…,j to 1,2,…,j, where 0<j<n,
we say that {1,2,…,j} is an invariant set . Permutations that do
not contain an invariant set are called connected permutations.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
We define a set of operations called switch operations . Each operation
takes a pattern p and breaks it down into two parts by the largest letter n.
The first part contains the part of the pattern p that appears before n. The
second part contains the part of p that appears after n. Then one of the two
operations, 𝕀,r, is used on each part, where (τ, R)^𝕀 = (τ, R).
After that theses parts can be switched, i.e., part two will then appear before
n and part one after n. An operation will be denoted as S_a,b,d, Where
a is the operation used on part one and b the operation used on part two.
The letter d is 1 if part one and two are switched and 0 otherwise. These
switch operations can also be used on permutations.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A,B be σ-structures, a=(a_1,…,a_k)∈ V(A)^k, b=(b_1,…,b_k)∈
  V(B)^k and q∈. Let 0≤ℓ≤ q. The ℓ-round
    EF_q^+-game on (A,  a, B, b) is played by
  two players, called Spoiler and Duplicator . The game
  is played for ℓ rounds.  In round i, Spoiler picks an element
  a_k+i∈ V(A) or an element b_k+i∈ V(B). If Spoiler picks a_k+i∈
  V(A), then Duplicator must choose an element b_k+i∈ V(B) and if
  Spoiler picks b_k+i∈ V(B), then Duplicator must choose an element
  a_k+i∈ V(A). Duplicator wins
  the game if for 0≤ i≤ℓ, the mapping 
  a_j↦ b_j for 1≤ j≤ k+i is a partial
  f_q(ℓ-i)-isomorphism.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Nowhere dense classes]
  A class  of graphs is nowhere dense if for every r
  there is a graph H_r such that H_r _r G for all G
  ∈.

sentence:
[Uniformly quasi-wide classes]
  A class  of graphs is uniformly quasi-wide with margin
  s:→ and N:×→ if for all
  r,k∈, if G∈ and W⊆ V(G) with |W|>N(r,k),
  then there is a set S⊆ V(G) with |S|<s(r), such that W
  contains an r-scattered set of size at least k in G ∖ S.

sentence:
A coloured graph (G, C_1, …, C_t) is a graph G
  together with relations C_1,… C_t⊆ V(G), called
  colours ,  such that
  C_i∩ C_j =∅ for all i≠j.  A vertex v∉⋃_1≤ i ≤ t C_i is called 
  uncoloured .
  A set X⊆ V(G) is a rainbow set
  if all of its elements have distinct colours (and no vertex is uncoloured).

  The Rainbow Distance Independent Set problem on a class
   of graphs is the following problem.
  10.5cm
    Rainbow Distance Independent Set (Rainbow
    DIS)Graph G∈, C_1,…, 
    C_t⊆ V(G), k, r∈.k+rDetermine whether G
    contains a rainbow r-independent set of size k.

sentence:
For r∈, an r-neighbourhood cover  of a
  graph G is a set of connected subgraphs of G called
  clusters , such that for every vertex v∈ V(G) there is
  some X∈ with N_r(v)⊆ X. 

  The
  radius () of a cover  is the maximum radius
  of any of its clusters. The degree d^(v) of v
  in  is the number of clusters that contain v. The
  maximum degree Δ() of 
  is Δ()=max_v∈ V(G) d^(v).  The size of 
  is =∑_X∈|X|=∑_v∈ V(G)d^(v).

sentence:

  V(B)^k and q∈. Let 0≤ℓ≤ q. The ℓ-round
    EF_q^+-game on (A,  a, B, b) is played by
  two players, called Spoiler and Duplicator . The game
  is played for ℓ rounds.  In round i, Spoiler picks an element
  a_k+i∈ V(A) or an element b_k+i∈ V(B). If Spoiler picks a_k+i∈
  V(A), then Duplicator must choose an element b_k+i∈ V(B) and if
  Spoiler picks b_k+i∈ V(B), then Duplicator must choose an element
  a_k+i∈ V(A). Duplicator wins
  the game if for 0≤ i≤ℓ, the mapping 
  a_j↦ b_j for 1≤ j≤ k+i is a partial
  f_q(ℓ-i)-isomorphism.

sentence: We say that matrices π ' ,π”∈Π_n, where π ' =[ p'_ij]_n× n, π” =[ p”_ij]_n× n are disjoint , if p'_ijp”_ij for every pair of indices i,j∈[n].

sentence:
Let δ∈(1/4, 1].  A basis B=[b_1,…,b_n]
of a lattice
    (b_1,…,b_n) is called δ-LLL reduced if and only if it
satisfies the
    following two conditions:
    
      
  * ∀ 1≤ j<i≤ n: |μ_i,j| ≤1/2 (size-reduced).
      
  * 1≤ k <n : δ·π_k(b_k)^2 ≤π_k(b_k+1)^2 (Lovász-condition).

sentence:
The potential (B) of a lattice basis B=[b_1,…,b_n] is defined as

    (B):=∏^n_i=1((b_1,…,b_i))^2=∏^n_i=1b^*_i^2(n-i+1) .

sentence:
Let D_G=[R|S] be the incidence matrix of a directed graph G(V,E) minus an arbitrary row, where R is a basis of the 
column space of D_G. The matrix N_G=R^-1S is called a network matrix .

basis of it and D_Σ=[R|S]. The matrix B=R^-1S is called a binet matrix .

sentence: A phylogenetic tree on X is a tree with no degree-2 vertices in which the leaves (degree-1 vertices) are bijectively labelled by the elements of X.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A phylogenetic network on X is a connected graph N such that contracting each blob (one by one) into a single vertex gives a phylogenetic tree on X.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A pseudo-network on X is a multigraph with no degree-2 vertices in which the leaves (degree-1 vertices) are bijectively labelled by the elements of X.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A binary level-k generator , for k≥ 2, is a 2-connected 3-regular multigraph G=(V,E) with |E|-|V|+1=k. The underlying generator of a binary simple level-k network N is the generator obtained from N by deleting all leaves and suppressing resulting degree-2 vertices. ♌For an edge e of G, we say that a leaf x is on edge e in N if the neighbour of x is on a path that is suppressed into edge e. If x is on edge e then we also say that e contains x and we refer to e as the x-edge .

sentence:
Given a (t,r) broadcast  on G_∞, consider the vertex set V of the subgraph G_2n+1, 2n+1 with its central vertex located at (0, 0). Then the broadcast density of a (t,r) broadcast on G_∞ is defined as 
    lim_n →∞|∩ V|/|V|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The standard pattern is defined by the positive integers d and e as

    p(d,e) = {(dx+ey, y) : x,y ∈ℤ}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X be a path connected space, and let X^I be the path space of X consisting of continuous paths γ : I=[0,1] → X. The path fibration p : X^I→ X × X is defined by p(γ)=(γ(0),γ(1)).
The topological complexity (X) is the smallest non-negative integer n such that there exists an open cover {U_i}_i=1^n of X × X with a continuous section s_i : U_i→ X^I of the path fibration p for each i. If such n does not exist, then we define (X)=∞.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let P be a finite space. The order complex (P) is a simplicial complex whose n-simplexes are ordered sequences p_0 < … <p_n in P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be a finite space. A combinatorial path of P with length m ≥ 0 is a continuous map γ : J_m → P. Note that a map between finite spaces is continuous if and only if it is order-preserving (a poset map). From this reason, a combinatorial path is a zigzag sequence of P formed as follows:

    x_0 ≤ x_1 ≥ x_2 ≤⋯≥ (≤) x_m.

Let P^J_m denote the finite space of combinatorial paths of P with length m, equipped with the pointwise order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be a path connected finite space.
The combinatorial complexity (P) is the minimum of _m(P):

    (P) = min{_m(P)}_m=0^∞ = lim_m →∞_m(P).

sentence: Suppose Γ is a metric graph and r,d are natural numbers such that W^r_d (Γ) is nonempty. The Brill-Noether rank w^r_d (Γ) is the largest integer k such that for every effective divisor E of degree r+k, there exists D of rank at least r and degree d such that D-E is effective. sentence: The rank r(D) of a divisor D on a metric graph Γ is the largest nonnegative integer r such that for every effective divisor E of degree r on Γ, the divisor D-E is equivalent to an effective divisor. If D is not equivalent to an effective divisor, r(D) is defined to be -1.

sentence:
Let M be a matroid on a linearly ordered set E.
Let B be a basis of M. 
The active filtration of B is the unique (connected) filtration of M associated to B by Theorem <ref>.

ß

For what follows in the paper, we only need the above definition. 


Two other equivalent definitions are available, they are constructive and based on the fundamental graph of the basis only. The active filtration of B can be defined:



=0mm =0mm =0mm =0mm

  * by applying successively the active closure to the internal/external active elements, see <cit.>;

  * by a single pass algorithm over E, see <cit.>, which is used (and formally contained) in next Theorem <ref>.

The active partition of B is the partition of E induced by successive differences of subsets in the active filtration of B, given with the cyclic flat F_c of the filtration
(so that the active filtration of B is determined, as observed above).

The active minors of B are the minors induced by the active filtration of B.

sentence: For J, J' ∈[2k-1]k-1, we say that J' is a swap of J if J ∩ J' = ∅. Clearly the relation of being a swap is symmetric. If J and J' are swaps of one another, there is a unique element j^* ∈ [2k-1] ∖ (J ∪ J') and we call j^* their pivot . We say J' is a balanced swap of J if it is a swap of J and their pivot j^* is such that |J ∩ [j^*]| = |J' ∩ [j^*]|. We say that that J' is a end swap of J if it is a swap of J and their pivot j^* is either 1 or 2k-1. Observe that J' being an end swap of J implies it is a balanced swap of J. Define bswap(J) (resp. eswap(J)) to be the set of balanced swaps (resp. end swaps) of J.

sentence:
(The Flajolet–Soria formula for coefficients of algebraic series)

Let P(X,Y) be a polynomial over the complex field such that P(0,0)=0 and P'_Y(0,0)=0. 
The coefficients of the algebraic series f(X)=∑ f_n X^n, defined implicitly by f(X)=P(X,f(X)), 
have the form of an infinite sum 
    f_n = ∑ _m≥ 1 [X^n Y^m-1](1-P'_Y(X,Y))P^m(X,Y).

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a graph.




   
  

  * An incompatibility system ℱ defined over G is a family ℱ={F_v}_v∈ V such that for every v ∈ V, F_v is a family of unordered pairs F_v
⊆{{e,e'}: e e'∈ E, e∩ e'={v}}.


  * If {e,e'}∈ F_v for some edges e,e' and a vertex v, then we
say that e and e' are incompatible in ℱ.
Otherwise, they are compatible in ℱ. A subgraph H ⊆ G
is compatible with ℱ, if all its pairs of edges e and e' are compatible.

  * For a positive integer Δ, an incompatibility system ℱ
is Δ-bounded if for each vertex v ∈ V and an edge e incident to v, there are at most Δ other edges e' incident to v that are
incompatible with e.

sentence:
Let λ be a partition with ℓ(λ) ≤ r and a(λ) ≤ c.
Let (i,j) ∈ D. 


  (i) 
The hook on (i,j), denoted H_(i,j), is

    { (i,j) }∪{ (i',j) ∈ [λ] : i' > i }∪{ (i, j') ∈ [λ] : j' > j }
    if (i,j) ∈ [λ] and         { (i,j) }∪{ (i', j) ∈ D \ [λ] : i' < i}∪{ (i,j') ∈ D \
    [λ] : j' < j }

if (i,j) ∈ D\ [λ].
We define the
hook length of (i,j), denoted h_(i,j), to be |H_(i,j)(λ)|.

  (ii) The distance of (i,j), denoted d_(i,j), is the number of boxes
in any walk by steps south and west to (r,1) if (i,j) ∈ [λ],
or of any walk by steps north and east to (1,c) if (i,j) ∈\ [λ].

sentence: A permutation π∈ S_n has a descent at position i if π(i) > π(i+1), where i = 1, …, n-1. The descent number of π, denoted d(π), is defined as the number of all descents of π plus 1. The major index of π, denoted maj(π), is the sum of the positions at which π has a descent.

sentence:
Let t be a tree, and u and v be two nodes (internal nodes or leaves) of t. 
	The first common ancestor of u and v is the node furthest away from the root ∅ that appears 
	on both paths from ∅ to u and from ∅ to v in t.

sentence:
Let θ=θ(1)⋯θ(d) be a permutation of size d, and let π^(1),…,π^(d) be d other permutations. 
The substitution of π^(1),…,π^(d) in θ is the permutation of size |π^(1)|+ … +|π^(d)| 
obtained by replacing each θ(i) by a sequence of integers isomorphic to π^(i) while keeping the relative order induced by θ between these subsequences.

This permutation is denoted by θ[π^(1),…,π^(d)].

sentence:
A substitution tree of size n is a rooted plane tree with n leaves,
where any internal node with k ≥ 2 children is labeled by a permutation of size k.
Internal nodes with only one child are forbidden. 
The labels 12 (resp. 21) of internal nodes are often replaced by ⊕ (resp. ⊖).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A standard tree  is a substitution tree in which internal nodes satisfy the following constraints:


  * Internal nodes are labeled by ⊕ (representing 12), ⊖ (representing 21), or by a simple permutation.

  * Every node labeled  by ⊕,⊖ has degree[Throughout the paper, by degree of a node in a tree, we mean the number of its children (which is sometimes called arity or out-degree in other works). 
Note that it is different from the graph-degree: for us, the edge to the parent (if it exists) is not counted in the degree.] two.
The left-child of a node labeled by  ⊕ (resp. ⊖) cannot be labeled by  ⊕ (resp. ⊖).

  * A node labeled by a simple permutation α has degree |α|.

sentence:
[Tree-specifications] 

  
Let _0,…,_d be d+1 families of permutations.
A tree-specification of (_0,…,_d) is a system of combinatorial equations

    _i = _i{∙} ⊎ _π∈ __i⊎⊕,⊖ _(k_1,…,k_|π|)∈ K_π^iπ[_k_1,…,_k_|π|]
         (0≤ i≤ d)
    _

where the symbol ⊎ denotes disjoint union,
∙ is the permutation of size 1 and 
for every i≤ d, _i∈{0,1} (so that _i{∙} is either ∅ or {∙}) and K_π^i is a subset of {0,…,d}^|π|.

A permutation class  is substitution-closed if, for every θ, π^(1),…,π^(d) in , the substitution
θ[π^(1),…,π^(d)] also belongs to .

sentence:
For any set  of permutations (most often, a permutation class), 
for any sets of patterns {σ_1,… ,σ_k} and {τ_1,… ,τ_ℓ}, 
and, optionally, for any δ∈{⊕, ⊖}, 
we define ^notδ_⟨σ_1,… ,σ_k⟩,( τ_1,… ,τ_ℓ) to be the subset of  such that


  * the patterns  σ_1,… ,σ_k are excluded from every permutation,

  * the patterns τ_1,… ,τ_ℓ  have to occur in every permutation,

  * the superscript notδ (for δ = ⊕, ⊖) is optional and indicates that permutations in this family are δ-indecomposable permutations,
i.e. that the root of associated standard trees are not labeled with δ.

sentence:
[First common ancestor]
	Let t be a tree, and u and v be two nodes (internal nodes or leaves) of t. 
	The first common ancestor of u and v is the node furthest away from the root ∅ that appears 
	on both paths from ∅ to u and from ∅ to v in t.

[Bruggersser <cit.>] Let P be a
polytope and 𝐱 be a point outside P. If point

sentence:
Let G be a d-dimensional simplicial complex, and let L_G be its Laplacian matrix. Then, 

    ∑_(F,R,,') bi-directed rooted forest()(') x^|R|=(L_G+x·).


More generally, given indeterminates {w_r,f}_r∈ G_d-1,f∈ G_d, define the weighted Laplacian matrix as L_G,w=_d^G,w· (_d^G)^T, where ^G,w_d is the matrix obtained from ^G_d by multiplying by w_r,f the entry corresponding to the faces r and f. Then, for any indeterminates {x_r}_r∈ G_d-1,

    ∑_(F,R,,') bi-directed rooted forest()(')(∏_r∈w_r,(r)) (∏_r∈ Rx_r)=(L_G,w+X),

where X is the diagonal matrix whose rows and columns are indexed by G_d-1, and whose diagonal entry in the row indexed by r is x_r.

sentence:
Let G be a d-dimensional complex, and let F be a subset of the d-faces.
We say that F is a forest of G if the corresponding columns of _d^G are independent.
We say that F is a spanning subcomplex of G if the corresponding columns of _d^G are of maximal rank.

Accordingly, we say that F is a spanning forest of G if the corresponding columns of _d^G form a basis of the columns.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a d-dimensional complex. Let R be a subset of the (d-1)-faces, and let =G_d-1∖ R.
We say that R is relatively-free if the rows of _d^G corresponding to the faces in  are of maximal rank. 
We say that R is relatively-generating if the rows of _d^G corresponding to the faces in  are independent.
We say that R is a root of G if it is both relatively-free and relatively-generating, that is, the rows of _d^G corresponding to the faces in  form a basis of the rows.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a d-dimensional simplicial complex. A rooted forest of G is a pair (F,R), where F is a forest of G, and R is a root of F[Formally, R is a root of the simplicial complex generated by F: the subcomplex containing all the faces and subfaces of F.]. 

We call (F,R) a rooted spanning forest if moreover F is a spanning forest of G.

The relative homology groups for the pair (F,R) are given by:

    [                   H_d(F,R)                          =                     Ψ_F,R,;                 H_d-1(F,R)                          = Ψ_F,R:=
    ( G_d-1 R)(Ψ_F,R). ]

sentence: Let G be a simplicial complex of dimension d. A bi-directed rooted forest of G is a triple (F, R, ,') such that (F,R) is a rooted forest and ,' are fitting orientations.

sentence:
* A ((2k+1)-orthogonal ) vacillating tableau of length r is a sequence of partitions ∅=μ^0, μ^1,…,μ^r=μ each of at most k parts, such that:


  * μ^i and μ^i+1 differ in at most one position,

  * μ^i=μ^i+1 only occurs if the k^th part of both partitions is non-empty.

We call the final partition μ the shape of the tableau.

  * A ((2k+1)-orthogonal ) highest weight word is a word w with letters in {± 1, ± 2, …, ± k, 0} of length r such that for every initial segment s of w the following holds (we write #i for the number of i's in s):


  * #i - #(-i) ≥ 0,

  * #i-#(-i)≥#(i+1)-#(-i-1),

  * if the last letter is 0 then #k-#(-k)>0.

We call the partition (#1-#(-1),#2-#(-2),…, #k - #(-k)) the weight of a highest weight word. The vacillating tableau corresponding to a word w is the sequence of weights of the initial segments of w.


By abuse of terminology we refer to both objects as vacillating tableaux .

    (Q)=jj  is a descent of  Q.

sentence:
[Rubey, personal conversation]
We define descents for vacillating tableaux using highest weight words. We call a letter j of w a descent if there exists a directed path from w_j to w_j+1 in the crystal graph for the defining representation of 

    1→ 2→…→ k → 0 → -k →…→ -1

and w_jw_j+1≠ j(-j) if for the initial segment w_1,…,w_j-1 holds #j-#(-j)=0.

 For k=1 this means that j is a descent if the j^th position is a 1 followed by a 0, or a 0 followed by a -1, or a 1 followed by a -1 if the numbers of 1's and -1's before the j^th position are different.

We define the descent set of w as

    (w)= j j  is a descent of  w.

sentence:
The crystal graph B^𝔡(μ) where μ is a partition with at most k=1 part, is defined as follows.
The vertices are pairs of tableaux (T,C) where T is a two-column skew semistandard Young tableau and C is a column strict single column such that:


  * The tail of a two-column skew semistandard tableau is the part of the tableau where only the first column exists. We require that the tail of T have length μ_1.

  * The residuum of a two-column skew semistandard tableau is the number of positions we can shift the second column down such that the result is still a skew semistandard tableau. We require that the residuum of T be less than or equal to 1.

To obtain the edges, we consider this as a subgraph of the tensor product of 3=2k+1 one-column crystal graphs. Note that taking this point of view φ_i(b_ℓ)∈{1,0} for ℓ=1,2,3.

with ℓ(λ)≤ n=2k+1 and ℓ(μ)≤ k.

sentence:
We obtain the concatenation Q of two standard Young tableaux Q_1 and Q_2 in the following way. First we add the largest entry of Q_1 to each entry of Q_2 to obtain the tableau Q_2. Then we append the i^th row Q_2 to the i^th row of Q_1 to obtain Q.

The concatenation of two vacillating tableaux is obtained by concatenating the words.

sentence: The deficiency of a subset P of a finite group G is the minimum size δ_G(P) of a subset Q of G such that ⟨ P∪ Q⟩=G.   For a structure class X_I of G, we define δ_G(X_I) to be δ_G(I).

sentence:
Let G be a graph. The signed a-number of G, or sa(G), is defined recursively by:
        
            
  * sa(∅)=1.
            
  * sa(G)=∏_i=1^ℓ sa(G_i) if G_1,…, G_ℓ are components of G.
        
        If G is connected, then:
        
    sa(G) = {[     -∑_I⊊ V(G)sa(G|_I), if G has even vertices;;                      0,              otherwise, ].

        where G|_I is the full subgraph of G induced by I, i.e., V(G|_I) = I and E(G|_I) = {{v,w}∈ E(G) | v, w ∈ I}.











        The a-number or unsigned a-number of G, denoted by a(G), is the absolute value of sa(G). The i-th a-number of G or a_i(G) is defined by the sum
        
    a_i(G):=∑_I⊆ V(G)|I|=2ia(G|_I).

        Note that a_1(G) is the number of edges of G.

        The total a-number of G, or b(G), is the whole sum of signed a-numbers of all induced subgraphs, that is
        
    b(G):=∑_I⊆ V(G)sa(G|_I).

sentence:
Let {A_n} be the sequence given by
        
    x + tan x = ∑_n=0^∞ A_n x^n/n!.

        The numbers A_n are known as Euler zigzag numbers . The numbers A_2i with even indices are called secant numbers and A_2i+1 with odd ones are tangent numbers .

sentence:
A building set ℬ on a finite set S is a collection of nonempty subsets of S such that
        
            
  * ℬ contains all singletons {i}, i∈ S,
            
  * if I, J ∈ℬ and I∩ J≠∅, then I∪ J∈ℬ.
        
        If  contains the whole set S, then  is called connected .

sentence:
Let  be a building set on [n+1]={1,…,n+1}. For I⊂ [n+1], let Δ_I be the simplex given by the convex hull of points e_i, i∈ I, where e_i is the i-th coordinate vector. Then define the nestohedron P_ as the Minkowski sum of simplices
        
    P_ = ∑_I∈Δ_I.

        If =(G) is a graphical building set, P_(G) is called a graph associahedron .

sentence:
For a connected building set  on [n+1], a subset N⊆∖{[n+1]} is called a nested set if the following holds:
        
            
  * For any I, J∈ N one has either I⊆ J, J ⊆ I, or I and J are disjoint.
            
  * For any collection of k≥ 2 disjoint subsets J_1, …, J_k ∈ N, their union J_1∪⋯∪ J_k is not in .
        
        The nested set complex Δ_ is defined to be the set of all nested sets for .

sentence:
Let G be the planar map obtained by taking the union of all
  vertices and edges that either lie in the sequence from
  Lemma <ref> or on the boundary of a face in this
  sequence. We call this subgraph of T the girdle with
  respect to φ. Its cells from the cyclic sequence are called
  central cells of G, the other ones (which are only part of
  G because they lie on the boundary of a face from the sequence)
  are called outer cells of G. By construction, every face in
  the sequence is also a face of G (and hence a central cell); the
  other faces of G are called its sides . For every face in
  the sequence, precisely one of the edges on its boundary is a
  central cell and so is the other face incident with this edge. The
  union of such two faces and their boundaries is called a
  diamond . Note that every girdle has at least two central
  vertices; let j(G) be the smallest index for which c_j(G) is a
  vertex.

sentence:
Let F̃ be the union of
  
  
  * the levels F_0,…,F_k of T,
  
  * all  v_j^iw_j^i+1,
  
  * the north pole c_0 of T,
  
  * all edges from c_0 to F_0 (if c_0 is a vertex), and
  
  * the south pole c_1 and its boundary (if the last level F_k
    is pseudo-antarctic).
  
  The fyke net of T with respect to the group
  H⊆(c_0,T) is the maximal 2-connected subgraph F
  of F̃ that contains both poles c_0,c_1.

  
    [scale=.75]
      (-4.1,-4) rectangle (3.7,3.8);
      (myfirstpic) at (0,0) 
    < g r a p h i c s >
;
      (0,3.6) node c_0;
      (-.05,-2.85) node c_1;






    
    A triangulation its fyke net (bold) with respect to the
      group H=(c_0,T), in which
      the north pole c_0 is a vertex and the south pole c_1 is a
      face.
    
  

  The intersection of the fyke net with the level F_i is
  its ith layer and denoted by H_i. Note that every layer
  is a plane symmetric cactus of order m by the symmetry of the
  construction. The fyke net has up to five different types of faces:


  
  
  * faces at the north pole c_0: either c_0 itself (if it is
    a face) or all faces of T that are incident with c_0;
  
  * faces that are bounded by cycles in a branch of a layer; we
    call such faces leaves ;
  
  * faces bounded by two consecutive  and two
    subpaths of the two layers connecting their sources and their
    targets; we call such faces segments ;
  
  * if the last layer H_k is pseudo-antarctic, m faces that
    are bounded by a subpath of the centre of H_k and the south pole
    c_1 (if it is an edge) or one of its incident edges (if it is a
    face); we call such faces pseudo-antarctic ;
  
  * the south pole c_1 (if it is a face).

sentence:
The union S := ⋃_i=0^2n-1M_i is the skeleton of
  T. For every i=0,…,2n-1, we say that the meridians M_i
  and M_i+1 are adjacent . Every face of S that is
  not a central cell of at least one of the meridians (equivalently:
  of one of the girdles) is a segment of S.

sentence:
Let N be a near-triangulation and let D be a subset of its set
  of outer vertices. We call N chordless outside D if every
  chord of N has at least one end vertex in D.

  More generally, let a cycle
  C with a root vertex v_C and a root edge e_C incident with
  v_C be given and let D_C be a set of vertices in C. Suppose
  that the length of C is the same as the number of outer vertices
  of N and let α be the unique isomorphism from C to the
  boundary C_N of the outer face of N that maps v_C to the root
  vertex v_N of N and e_C to the root edge e_N of N. We call
  N chordless outside D_C if it is chordless outside
  α(D_C).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
The binary alphabet ={,} is called seed alphabet . Every finite word over this alphabet is a seed .
The weight of a seed Q is the number of occurrences of the letter  in Q.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let m and k be positive integers. Every set
	{i_1, …, i_k}⊆{0,…,m-1}
	is called error combination of k errors.
	
	Consider a seed Q such that |Q|<m and denote
	ℓ := m - |Q|, which is the so-called
	seed margin .
	Then Q
	detects an error combination
	{i_1, …, i_k}⊆{0,…,m-1} at position t∈{0,…,ℓ} if 
	for all
	j∈{0,…,|Q|-1}
	it holds
	(
		Q_j =  j+t ∉{i_1,…,i_k}).

	The seed Q is said to solve the (m,k)-problem if every error combination
	{i_1,…,i_k}⊆{0,…,m-1}	
	of k errors is detected by Q at some position t∈{0,…,ℓ}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A bi-infinite word  satisfying
	_k(,…,) ≤ℓ
	is called an (ℓ;k)-valid bi-infinite word .
	For fixed positive integers ℓ and k,
	we denote the set of all (ℓ;k)-valid words
	by ℓk.

sentence:
For given positive integers ℓ and k, we define the k-nary compatibility relation ℓk on ^ℓ+1 as
	
    ℓk(v^(1),…,v^(k))
    		    _k(v^(1),…,v^(k))≤ℓ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
For given positive integers ℓ and k, a subset G of ^ℓ+1 is called (ℓ,k)-generating set if the following conditions are satisfied:
	
		
  * for all v^(1),…,v^(k)∈ G, it holds
			ℓk(v^(1),…,v^(k));
		
  * it is maximal possible (i.e., it cannot contain any other word from ^ℓ+1).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider a seed Q and an (ℓ,k)-generating set G.
	By S(G), we denote
	the subshift S_X of finite type given by X = ^ℓ+1 G.	
	We say that a seed Q is generated by G if Q∈(S(G)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
A permutation tableau  is a Young diagram 
whose boxes are filled with 0's and 1's such that:


  * each column contains at least one 1, and 

  * there is no box containing a 0 which has both a 1 above it (in the 
same column) and a 1 to its left (in the same row).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say {P_k(x)}_k ≥ 0 is a family of orthogonal polynomials if 
there exists a linear functional f: K[x]→ K such that:


  * (P_k) = k for k ≥ 0,

  * f(P_k P_ℓ) = 0 if k ≠ℓ,

  * f(P_k^2) ≠ 0 for k ≥ 0.

The nth moment of {P_k(x)}_k  is defined 
to be μ_n=f(x^n).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.> 
A crossing in a permutation π is a pair (i,j)
such that


  * i< j≤π(i)<π(j) or

  * i>j>π(i)>π(j).
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A crossing of a signed permutation π=(π(1),… ,π(n)) is a pair (i,j) with i,j>0
such that


  * i<j≤π(i)<π(j) or

  * -i<j≤ -π(i)<π(j) or

  * i>j>π(i)>π(j).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let k be a positive integer, B be a graph, and (B,d_B) a k-partial distance graph of B. For an edge xy with d_B(xy)=p, we say that a k-good triple {p,q,r} is realized on xy if there are two vertices z_1 and z_2 of B with d_B(x,z_1)=q, d_B(y,z_1)=r, d_B(x,z_2)=r and d_B(y,z_2)=q.
We say that (B,d_B) has the all k-good triple property if E(B)≠∅, and for each edge xy and each k-good triple T = {p,q,r} with p=d_B(x,y), T is realized on xy.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Intersection graphs]
A feature system is a triple (V, Ω, f), where V is a set of vertices, Ω is a set of features , and f is a function mapping vertices in V to subsets of Ω. Given a vertex v∈ V, we call f(v)⊆Ω its feature set . We construct a graph G on the vertex-set V from a feature system (V, Ω, f) by placing an edge between u,v ∈ V if their feature sets f(u), f(v) have non-empty intersection. We call G the intersection graph of the feature system (V, Ω,f).
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
[Hypercubes and subcubes]
The d-dimensional hypercube is the set Q_d={0,1}^d. A k-dimensional subcube of Q_d is a subset obtained by fixing (d-k)-coordinates and letting the remaining k vary freely. We may regard subcubes of Q_d as elements of {0,1, ⋆}^d, where ⋆ coordinates are free and the 0,1 coordinates are fixed.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Binomial model]
Let V be a set of vertices. Fix d∈ℕ and p∈[0,1]. For each v∈ V independently select a subcube f(v)∈{0,1, ⋆}^d at random by setting (f(v))_i=⋆ with probability p and (f(v))_i=0,1 each with probability 1-p/2 independently for each coordinate i ∈{1,… d} (we refer to such a subcube as a binomial random subcube ). Denote the resulting random subcube intersection graph by G_V,d, p.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒫 be a property of subcube intersection graphs that is closed with respect to the addition of vertices. The hitting time N^b_𝒫 = N^b_𝒫(d,p) for 𝒫 for the binomial sequence (B_n)_n∈ℕ is 

    N^b_𝒫:=min{n ∈ℕ:    B_n ∈𝒫}.

Similarly, we define the hitting time N^u_𝒫 = N^u_𝒫(d,α) for 𝒫 for the uniform sequence (U_n)_n∈ℕ is 

    N^u_𝒫:=min{n ∈ℕ:    U_n ∈𝒫}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒫 be a property of subcube intersection graphs that is closed with respect to the addition of vertices. A real number t≥ 0 is a threshold for 𝒫 in the binomial model (with parameter p) if

    log(N^b_𝒫(d,p))/d→ t

in probability as d→∞. Similarly, we say that t≥ 0 is a threshold for 𝒫 in the uniform model (with parameter k=⌊α d⌋) if 

    log(N^u_𝒫(d,α))/d→ t

in probability as d→∞.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The Hamming distance dist(y,y') between two elements y,y' of Q_d is the number of coordinates in which they differ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Rainbow complex to prove that R(G;n)≤ N using m,
is a polyhedral subcomplex of the product

    ∏_i=1^m Δ_E(K_N).

The vertices of the simplex Δ_E(K_N) are indexed by the edges of K_N. Any vertex of the product
corresponds to a function

    η : {1,2,…, m}→ E(K_N).

The Rainbow complex is the induced subcomplex on the vertices η such that G is a subgraph of 
η( {1,2, …,  m} ).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Rainbow complex to prove that R(G;n)≤ N using m,

sentence:
Let Σ_1 and Σ_2 be two finite simplicial complexes. The Ramsey complex Ram(Σ_1,Σ_2) is
the induced subcomplex of

    ∏_v ∈Σ_1^0Δ_Σ_2^0

with vertex set

    {η:  Σ_1^0 →Σ_2^0 |η^-1(σ)∈Σ_1 for all σ∈Σ_2 }.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G_1 and G_2 be graphs. The Hom complex Hom(G_1,G_2) is the induced subcomplex of

    ∏_v ∈ V(G_1)Δ_V(G_2)

with vertex set

    {η: V(G_1)→ V(G_2) |η is a graph homomorphism G_1 → G_2 }.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Σ be a simplicial complex and V a set. The Partition complex Part(Σ,V) is the induced subcomplex of

    ∏_v ∈Σ^0Δ_V

with vertex set

    {η: Σ^0 → V |η^-1(v)∈Σ for all v∈ V }

sentence:
The Rainbow complex to prove that R(G;n)≤ N using m,
is a polyhedral subcomplex of the product

    ∏_i=1^m Δ_E(K_N).

The vertices of the simplex Δ_E(K_N) are indexed by the edges of K_N. Any vertex of the product
corresponds to a function

    η : {1,2,…, m}→ E(K_N).

The Rainbow complex is the induced subcomplex on the vertices η such that G is a subgraph of 
η( {1,2, …,  m} ).

    χ_c(G):= inf{p/q:  there is a  (p,q)-colouring of  G}.

sentence:
If w,r∈Γ and (v,z,t)=(w,r) then let
(w,r) be defined as follows:

It follows from Property <ref> of Definition <ref> that there is h∈(w) such that w=hz^R(v)zt. Note that (v)≠v since r∈(w) and thus r∉(w), see Corollary <ref>. It is clear that r∈((v))∩((v)). This implies that hz^Rr∈(w). We distinguish two cases:


  * r∈(hz^R(r)):

Let g be the complete return to r such that g∈(hz^Rr). Clearly rz∈(g) and z^Rr∈(g), since r∉((r)z); recall r∈(v) and (v,r)=(vzt,r). Let g̅ be such that g̅g=hz^Rr.
 We define (w,r)=g̅rz. Note that (w,r)∈(w).

  * r∉(hz^R(r)):

Let u̅=(hz^Rr,r).
Clearly (hz^Rr)=r and u̅≠r. Because z^R(r)∈(hz^R(r)), then obviously U≠∅ and r∉(U), where U={u| u∈((hz^R(r)))(r)z∈(u)}. We define (w,r)=(U). Note that r∉((w,r)).

We call (w,r) a reduced prefix of w by r.

sentence:
Let N be a finite ground set, and let m,d∈ℤ_>0. We say that a set system ℋ⊆ 2^N is an (m,d)-system (on N) if


  *  ℋ is closed under intersection, i.e., H_1∩ H_2∈ℋ  ∀ H_1,H_2∈ℋ,


  *  |H| ≢|N| m  ∀ H∈ℋ, and


  *  for any S⊆ N with |S|≤ d, there is a set H∈ℋ with S⊆ H.

sentence:
Let ℒ⊆ 2^N be a lattice, ℱ⊆ℒ, and let d∈ℤ_>0. A family ℋ⊆ℒ is called an (ℱ,d)-system if the following holds, where Q⋃_H∈ℋH:


  *  Q∈ℱ,

  *  ℋ is closed under intersection,

  *  H∉ℱ  ∀ H∈ℋ, and

  *  for any S⊆ Q with |S|≤ d, there is a set H∈ℋ with S⊆ H.

sentence:

  *  ℋ is closed under intersections,


  *  (|H∩ S_1|,…,|H∩ S_k|) ≢(|S_1|,…,|S_k|) m  ∀ H∈ℋ, and


  *  for any S⊆ N with |S|≤ d, there is a H∈ℋ with S⊆ H.
