sentence:
Let E represent a push step from the input to the first stack, let N represent pop/push from the first stack to the second stack, and let C represent the pop from the second stack to the output.
See Figure <ref>.
A sorting word of a permutation is a word representing steps that can be taken to sort that permutation using two stacks in series (without restriction).
We use L_i to denote the occurrence of the letter L in W which corresponds to the movement of symbol i.

sentence: A DI word of a permutation π is a sorting word representing steps that can be taken to sort π using the DI machine.

sentence: The algorithmic DI word (ADI word for short) of a permutation π is the unique word representing steps that will be taken when applying Algorithm <ref> to sort π by the DI machine.

sentence: A right-to-left minimum of a permutation is an element that is the least element seen thus far when reading the permutation from right to left.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An interval of a permutation π is a consecutive subsequence of π that contains consecutive values.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A permutation π is said to be plus-decomposable if π is the concatenation of two non-empty intervals ω and τ' where the values of ω are less than those of τ'.  Further, if we rescale the entries of τ' by subtracting the length of ω from each entry of τ' to get a permutation τ, we denote π = ω⊕τ.  If a permutation is not plus-decomposable, we say the permutation is plus-indecomposable .

sentence:
[Discrete Lichnerowicz, see <cit.>] 
  Let G=(V,E) be a finite connected D-regular graph. Then we have
  for the smallest positive solution λ_1 of
  Δ_G f + λ f = 0 with Δ_G given by
  (<ref>),
  
    inf_x ∼ yκ(x,y) ≤λ_1.

  We say that the graph G is
  Lichnerowicz sharp (with respect to
  Ollivier Ricci curvature) if (<ref>) holds with
  equality.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Kantorovich duality <cit.>] 
  Let G = (V,E) be a graph. Let μ_1,μ_2 be
  two probability measures on V. Then
  
    W_1(μ_1,μ_2) = 
      sup_ϕ∈1– Lip(V) ∩ ℓ_∞(V)∑_x∈ Vϕ(x)(μ_1(x)-μ_2(x)).

  If ϕ attains the supremum we
  call it an optimal Kantorovich potential transporting
  μ_1 to μ_2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
[see <cit.>]
  Let G=(V,E) be a connected graph and f: V → be a function
  on the vertices.  We define the gradient of f as
  
    ∇_xy f = f(x)-f(y)/d(x,y)  for all x,y ∈ V, x ≠ y.
 
  Let Δ_G be the normalized Laplacian of G defined in
  (<ref>). Then, for any pair x,y ∈ V of different
  vertices, we have
  
    κ_LLY(x,y) = 
      inf_ϕ∈1– Lip(V) ∩  C_c(V)
    ∇_yxϕ = 1∇_xy (Δ_G ϕ),

  where κ_LLY was defined in (<ref>).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A graph G = (V,E) is called antipodal if, for
  every vertex x ∈ V, there exists another vertex
  x∈ V satisfying [x,x]=V.
  
  A graph G = (V,E) is called strongly spherical if G and the induced subgraphs of all its intervals are antipodal. That is, the following two properties are necessary and sufficient conditions for strongly spherical graphs
  G = (V,E):
  
  
  * For every x ∈ V there exists x∈ V such
    that G = [x,x].
  
  * For every pair x,y ∈ V, x ≠ y, and every
    z ∈ [x,y] there exists z∈ [x,y] such that
    [x,y] = [z,z].
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G = (V,E) be a graph. Let μ_1,μ_2 be two probability
  measures on V. The Wasserstein distance
  W_1(μ_1,μ_2) between μ_1 and μ_2 is defined as
  
    W_1(μ_1,μ_2):=inf_π∈Π(μ_1,μ_2) cost(π),

  where π runs over all transport plans in
  
    Π(μ_1,μ_2) = {π: V × V → [0,1] :
          μ_1(x)=∑_y∈ Vπ(x,y),  μ_2(y)=∑_x∈
            Vπ(x,y) }.

  and the cost of π is defined as
  
    cost(π) := ∑_x ∈ V∑_y ∈ V d(x,y)
      π(x,y).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  Let p∈ [0,1]. The p-Ollivier Ricci curvature between two
  different vertices x,y ∈ V is
  
    κ_ p(x,y) = 1 - W_1(μ^ p_x,μ^ p_y)/d(x,y),

  where p is called the idleness.

  If G is D-regular then we define the curvature, κ, as
  
    κ(x,y) = D+1/Dκ_1/D+1(x,y).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a graph and ϕ: V →. We say that
  ϕ is 1-Lipschitz if
  
    |ϕ(x) - ϕ(y)| ≤ d(x,y)   for all x,y∈ V.

  We denote the set of all 1–Lipschitz functions by
  1– Lip(V).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a D-regular graph and let x ∈ V.
  
  
  (SSP) We say x satisfies the small sphere property
    (SSP) if
    
    |S_2(x)| ≤D  2.

  
  (NCP) We say x satisfies the non-clustering property
    (NCP) if, whenever d_x^-(z) = 2 holds for all z ∈ S_2(x),
    one has that for all distinct y_1,y_2∈ S_1(x) there is at most one
    z ∈ S_2(x) satisfying y_1∼ z ∼ y_2.

sentence:
[Bakry-Émery curvature]
  Let G=(V,E) be a finite simple graph. Let
  𝒦∈ℝ and
  𝒩∈ (0,∞)∪{∞}. We say that a vertex
  x∈ V satisfies the curvature-dimension inequality
  CD(𝒦,𝒩) if, for any f:V→ℝ, we
  have
  
    Γ_2(f)(x)≥1/𝒩
        (Δ f(x))^2+𝒦Γ(f)(x).

  We call 𝒦 a lower Ricci curvature bound of G at x,
  and 𝒩 a dimension parameter. The graph G=(V,E)
  satisfies CD(𝒦,𝒩) (globally), if all its
  vertices satisfy CD(𝒦,𝒩). Let
  𝒦_G,x(∞) be the largest real number such that the
  vertex x satisfies CD(𝒦_G,x(∞),∞).

sentence:

The glide product a _ b of a and b is the multiset of weak compositions 

    a _ b := { Comp( BumpRuns(C)) : C ∈ GSS(a,b) }.

sentence:
A set P of k disjoint ordered pairs from [n] is called a k-tuple. More concretely, P={(a_i, b_i)}_i ∈ [k] is called a k-tuple, if
	
    ∀ i≠ j ∈ [k]:    
    		a_i < b_i,    
    		a_i≠ a_j, a_i≠ b_j, b_i ≠ b_j,     
    		a_i∈ [n], b_i∈ [n].

	We say a k-tuple P is shifted if
	
    ∀ i:[a_i]⊆⋃ P.

	P is said to be sorted if
	
    a_i<a_j⟺ b_i<b_j.

We denote the set of all shifted sorted k-tuples by 𝒱_k = 𝒱_k(n,p).

sentence:
For a 1-tuple P={(i,j)}, we define the corresponding derivative operator D_ij by
	
    ∀ f ∈^np D_ijf 1/2 f - f^(ij),

	where (ij) is the transposition permutation i↔ j. (Notice two disjoint 1-tuples p, q satisfy D_pD_q=D_qD_p.)	
	We generalize the derivative operator D_ij to arbitrary k-tuples P={(i_1,j_1),…,(i_k,j_k)}, as
	
    D_Pf _T P (-1)^ T f^T = (D_i_k j_k∘ D_i_k-1 j_k-1∘⋯∘ D_i_1 j_1) f.

	Furthermore, we say that a derivative D_P is shifted, or sorted, if, correspondingly, P is shifted, or sorted. We denote the set of all derivatives that correspond to shifted sorted k-tuples by 𝒰_k = 𝒰_k(n,p).

sentence:
Let P⊆^d be a polytope and consider a linear system of the form:
	
    Ex + Ft = g,   Êx + F̂t ≤ĝ

	in  variables (x,t) ∈^d×^q, where E ∈^p × d, F ∈^p × q, Ê∈^r × d, F̂∈^r × q, g ∈^p and ĝ∈^r for some p,q,r ∈ℤ_+. The linear system (<ref>) is said to be  an extended formulation of P  if  the following equality holds:
	
	Let P⊆^d be a polytope. The linear system 
	
    Ex + Ft = g,   Êx + F̂t ≤ĝ,

	in the variables (x,t) ∈^d×^q, is called an extended formulation of P  if the following equality holds:
	
    P={x∈^d: ∃ t∈^q  s.t.  Ex + Ft = g,   Êx + F̂t ≤ĝ}.
	
Here, the matrices E, Ê have d columns, the matrices F, F̂ have q columns,	 the additional variable t is called the lifting variable, and the size of the extended formulation is defined as the number of inequalities in the system (<ref>) (i.e., the number of rows of the matrices Ê,F̂).
The extended formulation is said to be in slack form if the only inequalities are nonnegativity conditions on the lifting variable t, i.e., if it is of the form:
	
    Ex + Ft = g,   t ≥ 0

	and then its size is the dimension of the variable t.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P⊆^d be a polytope. A polytope Q ⊆^k is called an extension of P if there exists a linear mapping π: ^k→^d such that  P=π(Q). The size of the extension Q, denoted by size(Q), is defined as the number of facets of Q. Then the  extension complexity of P is the parameter (P) defined as 
	
    (P) =min{ size(Q) : Q  is an extension of  P  }.

sentence:
Let P ⊆^d be a polytope. Consider a linear system Ax≤ b describing P, i.e.,  P = { x ∈^d : Ax≤ b } with A∈^m × d and b ∈^m, and a set  V = { v_1, … ,v_n}⊆ P containing all the vertices of P, i.e., P=(V). Then the m × n   matrix S = (S_i,j) with entries 
	
    S_i,j = b_i - A_i^Tv_j   for  i∈ [m],  j∈ [n]
 
	is called a slack matrix of P, said to be   induced by V and the linear system Ax≤ b.

    (S) = min{ r : ∃  T ∈_+^m × r  ∃  U ∈_+^r × n such that  S= TU }.

	In what follows, a decomposition of the form S= TU as above  is called a nonnegative decomposition with intermediate dimension r.

sentence: For n≥ b≥ 1, an (n,b)-domino tower is a fixed polyomino created by sequentially stacking n-b dominoes horizontally on a convex, horizontal base composed of b dominoes, such that if a non-base domino is placed in position indexed by {(x,y),(x+1,y)}, then there must be a domino in position {(x-1,y-1), (x,y-1)}, {(x,y-1), (x+1,y-1)}, or {(x+1,y-1), (x+2,y-1)}.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For n≥ b≥ 1, an (n,b)-k-omino tower is a fixed polyomino created by sequentially placing (n-b) horizontal k-ominoes on a convex, horizontal base composed of b k-ominoes, such that if a non-base k-omino is placed in position {(x,y),(x+k-1,y)}, then there must be a k-omino in one of the 2k-1 positions between {(x-k+1,y-1), (x,y-1)} and {(x+k-1,y-1), (x+2k-2,y-1)}.

sentence:
[Spherical t-designs]
Let t∈ℕ_0.
A subset Y⊂^n-1 is called a spherical t-design on ^n-1, if and only if

    1/|^n-1|∫_𝐱∈^n-1f(𝐱)dσ(𝐱)=1/|Y|∑_𝐱∈ Yf(𝐱)

for any real polynomial f(x_1,… ,x_n) of degree at most t, where |^n-1| denotes the volume (namely the surface area) of the sphere ^n-1,
and the integral is the surface integral on ^n-1.

For a game G, suppose there are followers A∈ and
B∈ A^ℛ with B G.
 Then the Left option A is reversible , and sometimes, to be specific, A
 is said to be reversible  through its right option B. In addition, B is called a reversing option for A and,
 if B^ℒ is non-empty then B^ℒ
  is a replacement set for A. In this case, 
 A is said to be non-atomic-reversible .
 If the reversing option is left-atomic, that is, if B^ℒ=∅^ℓ, then A is
 said to be atomic-reversible .

[Game termination]
Let G be a left-atomic game. We write =∅^ℓ, ℓ∈
to indicate that, if Left to move, the game is over and the score is the real number ℓ.
Similarly, if G is right-atomic then =∅^r, and if
 it is Right's move then there are no Right options and
the score is r∈. Left wins if the score is positive, 
Right wins if the score is negative, and 
it is a tie if the score is zero.

  (†)_n For any full Fn(k,2), there is some  and D ⋃_g ∈dom(g) such that |D| ≥ n, and no two members of  disagree on D.

sentence: Suppose = a̅^ii ∈ is a collection of conditionally convergent series. For each A, let f_A denote the function represented by A; that is, define

    f_A(i)  =

    -1     if ∑(a̅^i,A) = -∞

and leave f_A(i) undefined otherwise.

sentence:
Consider m vectors _1,…,_m in ^n and their corresponding line segments [,_j].
The zonotope corresponding to _1,…,_m is defined to be the Minkowski sum of these line segments: 

    Z(_1,_2,…, _m):={λ_1_1+λ_2_2+⋯+λ_m_m: 0≤λ_j≤ 1}= [,_1]+⋯+[,_m]  .

We call any polytope that is translation-equivalent to an object of this type a zonotope .
When each _j∈^n, we say this is a lattice zonotope .

sentence:
The zonotope Z_0(_1,_2,…,_m):=Z(±_1,±_2,…,±_m) is symmetric about the origin, that is, it has the property that ∈ Z_0 if and only if -∈ Z_0; we call Z_0 a centrally symmetric zonotope defined by _1,…,_m.
Note that Z_0 can be obtained as Z(2_1,2_2,…,2_m)-(_1+⋯+_m).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider a collection A⊆^n of integer vectors. 
The arithmetic Tutte polynomial is 

    M_A(x,y):=∑_B⊆ Am(B)(x-1)^r(A)-r(B)(y-1)^|B|-r(B)  ,

where for each B⊆ A, the multiplicity m(B) is the index of B as a sublattice of span(B)∩^n and r(A) and r(B) are the size of the largest independent subset of A and B, respectively.
If we use the vectors in B as the columns of a matrix, then m(B) equals the greatest common divisor of the minors of full rank.

sentence:
For a graph G on the vertex set [n], the graphical zonotope Z_G is defined to be

    Z_G:=∑_(i,j)∈ G[e_i,e_j]=Newton(∏_(i,j)∈ G(t_i-t_j))   ,

where the Minkowski sum and the product are over edges (i,j), i<j, of the graph G, and e_1,…, e_n are the coordinate vectors in ^n.

sentence:
Let G be an undirected graph with vertex set V(G)={v_1,…, v_p}. 
The Laplacian matrix :=(G) is the p× p matrix

    _ij=
    -1,     if i≠ j and there is an edge between
            vertices v_i and v_j
    deg(v_i),     if i=j,

where deg(v_i) denotes the degree (number of incident edges) of v_i.

sentence:
Let σ∈𝔖_n.
The fixed subpolytope of the permutahedron relative to σ is

    𝒫^σ_n={∈𝒫_n: σ·=}  ,

the subpolytope of the permutahedron 𝒫_n fixed σ.

sentence: The cyclic zonotope Z(d,n) defined by t_1<t_2<⋯<t_d is the n-zonotope Z_0(_1,…,_d)=Z(±_1,…,±_d) generated by the d vectors _i=(1,t_i,…,t_i^n-1) in ^n.

sentence:
A zonotopal subdivision S of Z(d,n) is a set of subzonotopes of Z(d,n) with the following properties: 


  * if Z_C is a face of Z_X∈ S then Z_C∈ S,

  * any two elements of S intersect properly and 

  * ⋃_Z_X∈ S Z_X=Z(d,n).

sentence:
A zonotopal subdivision S of Z(d,n) is shellable if it is pure of dimension n, i.e., each subzonotope of Z(d,n) has dimension n, and there exists a linear ordering of the subzonotopes Z_X_1,…,Z_X_k, called a shelling , such that for 1<j≤ k, 

    Z_X_j∩(⋃_i≤ i<jZ_X_i)

is not empty and equals the union of the (n-1)-polytopes in an initial segment of a shelling of the boundary of Z_X_j.

sentence:
A share is a part of a chord diagram consisting
of two arcs of the outer circle possessing the following property:
each chord one of whose ends belongs to these arcs
has both ends on these arcs.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A mutation of a chord diagram is another chord diagram obtained by a rotation/reflection of a share.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The adjacency tensor of a hypergraph H with r(H)=k, denoted by 𝒜_H, is an order k dimension |V(H)| symmetric tensor with entries

    a_i_1i_2⋯ i_k=1/(k-1)!     {i_1,…,i_k}∈ E(H),
    (k-s+1)!/k!  {i_1,…,i_k}={j_1^(k-s+1),j_2,…,j_s}, {j_1,…,j_s}∈ E(H),
    
    0           ,

where s<k and j_1^(k-s+1) means that the multiplicity of j_1 is k-s+1. Let 𝒟_H denote the order k dimension |V(H)| diagonal tensor whose diagonal entries are vertex degrees of H. The tensors ℒ_H=𝒟_H-𝒜_H and 𝒬_H=𝒟_H+𝒜_H are the Laplacian tensor and the signless Laplacian tensor of H, respectively.

sentence:
(The m/n Pieri rule): For any coprime (m,n) ∈× and any positive integer k, we have:

    œ_k^m/n· s^m/n_μ = ∑ s^m/n_λ  (-1)^ht∏_i=1^k∏_j=1^n χ_j(B_i)^⌊mj/n⌋ - ⌊m(j-1)/n⌋

where the sum goes over all vertical k-strips of n-ribbons of shape . We write ht for the height [This notion is called spin in <cit.>] of such a k-strip, and:

    χ_j(B) = q^xt^-y

where (x,y) are the coordinates of the j-th box in the ribbon B, counted in northwest-southeast direction. These notions will be defined in Subsection <ref>. [By replacing the word “vertical" with the word “horizontal", we obtain formulas for operators of multiplication by complete symmetric functions]

sentence:
Let I be a finite set, let Δ = (I,∼) be a tree, and let (T_i)_i ∈ I be a family of pairwise disjoint sets. Also, let G be a group and let
(G^t,i)_t ∈ T_i, i ∈ I be a family of subgroups of G. Then the diagram coset pregeometry of G with respect to (G^t,i)_t ∈ T_i, i
∈ I equals the pregeometry

    ( {(C,t):t∈ T_ii∈ I, C∈ G/G^t,i},*,)
 over I with (C,t) = i if t∈ T_i, and


  (DCos) gG^t,i * hG^s,j if


  * i = j and t=s and gG^t,i∩ hG^s,j≠∅, 
  * i, j adjacent in Δ and
gG^t,i∩ hG^s,j≠∅, or 
  * i, j not adjacent in Δ and there exists a geodesic
i = x_0, …, x_k = j in Δ and cosets g_t_x_l,x_lG^t_x_l,x_l with gG^t,i =
g_t_x_0,x_0G^t_x_0,x_0, hG^s,j = g_t_x_k,x_kG^t_x_k,x_k and
g_t_x_l,x_lG^t_x_l,x_l*g_t_x_l+1,x_l+1G^t_x_l+1,x_l+1.


Since the type function is completely determined by the indices, we also denote the coset pregeometry
of G with respect to (G^t,i)_t ∈ T_i, i ∈ I by

    ((G/G^t,i×{t})_t ∈ T_i, i ∈ I, *).

If the diagram coset pregeometry happens to be a geometry, then Δ is its basic diagram if and only if at
least one of the residues corresponding to adjacent i, j is not a generalised digon.

sentence:
Let Γ = (X,*,) be a geometry over a finite set I whose basic diagram Δ is a tree, let G 
be a group of automorphisms of Γ, and let W ⊂ X be a set of G-orbit representatives of X. We 
write 
    W=⋃_i∈ IW_i
 with W_i⊆^-1(i). The sketch of Γ with respect to (G, W, Δ) is the diagram coset geometry 

    ((G/G_w×{w})_w∈ W_i, i∈ I,*).

sentence:
Let J = (J,≤) be a finite graded poset with grading function τ:J→ I = {1,2,...,n} such that every maximal chain has length n-1 (namely, it contains an element of every grade). 
 Then an amalgam of shape J is a pair A = ((G_j)_j∈ J, (ϕ_i,j)_i<j) such that G_j is a group for every j∈ J and, for any i, j ∈ J with i < j, the map ϕ_i,j:G_i→ G_j is a monomorphism satisfying ϕ_j,kϕ_i,j = ϕ_i,k for any choice of i, j, k∈ J with i < j < k.  

The fibers τ^-1(i) are denoted by J_i, for i ∈ I.

sentence:
Let A = ((G_j)_j∈ J, (ϕ_ij)_i<j) be an amalgam, with underlying graded poset J = (J, ≤) with grading function τ:J→ I = {1,2,...,n}.
A fusion of A, turning A into a fused amalgam, consists of three indices j_0, j_1, j_2∈ J_n = τ^-1(n), an element g ∈ G_j_0, a lower neighbor i_1 of j_0 and j_1, a lower neighbor i_2 of j_0 and j_2, and an isomorphism γ : G_j_1→ G_j_2 such

that the following properties hold:



  * ϕ_i_2,j_2(gxg^-1) = (γ∘ϕ_i_1,j_1)(x);

  * ϕ_i,j_2(x) =  (γ∘ϕ_i,j_1)(x) for each i < j_1, j_2.

sentence:
Let  be a fused amalgam. A pair (G,π) consisting of a group G and a map π: ⊔→ 
G is called an enveloping group of , if 
 

  * for all j ∈ J the restriction of π to G_j is a homomorphism of G_j to 
G; 

  * π_|G_j∘ϕ_i,j = π_|G_i for all i < j; 

  * π preserves fusion, i.e., π(γ(x)) = π(g) π(x) π(g)^-1 for every x ∈ G_j_1 and g, γ, j_1 as in Definition <ref>; and 

  * π(⊔) generates G.

 for

sentence:
<cit.>
There are one-to-one correspondence between combinatorial types 
 of d-polytopes with d+3 vertices and reduced Gale diagrams with the properties P1–P4.
Moreover,


  F The number of facets of a polytope is equal to the number of cofacets of the appropriate reduced Gale diagram.

  S An appropriate polytope is simplicial iff m(O) = 0 and m_i m_n+i = 0 ∀ i∈ [n]. 

  N An appropriate polytope is k-neigh­bor­ly iff 
         ∑_j=i+1^i+n-1 m_i≥ k+1 for every i∈[2n].
         (The sum of the labels in any open semicircle is at least k+1.)
         Such a diagram is called k-neigh­bor­ly .

sentence:
Given n,k,t, positive integers with n≥ t  ≥ 2, we define the k-uniform hypergraph ℱ_k(n,t)⊆[n]k:

    ℱ_k(n,t):= {A∈[n]k A∩ [t]≠∅}.
 
Furthermore,

    𝔉_k(n,t,r)={ℋ⊆[n]kℱ_k(n,t)⊆ℋ, e(ℋ)=e(ℱ_k(n,t))+r   }

is the family of  k-hypergraphs that contains ℱ_k(n,t) as a subhypergraph and has exactly r edges with no vertices in [t]. The graph ℱ_2(n,t) is also known as a split graph (see <cit.>).

sentence: The q-wise Kneser p-uniform hypergraph , denoted by K^p_q[n]k, is the p-uniform hypergraph with the vertex set V(K_q^p[n]k)=[n]k, and p sets form an edge if they are a q-wise disjoint family.

Let  be a rooted bipartite quadrangulation, and let ℓ : V() → be a coloring of its vertices. We say that a triple (,ℓ,≺) is properly labeled if every edge is labeled by (i,i+1) for some i ∈, at least 
one vertex of  is labeled by 0, and ≺ is a linear order on the set V_min() ⊂ V() of all local minima of  with respect to ℓ.

sentence:
Given a graph G, let K(G) be the complex given by 
    K(G)={A∈ V(G): G[A]  is complete}.
 This is called the clique complex .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A simplicial complex Δ is called pure of dimension d-1 if |F|=d for all facets F of Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A simplicial complex Δ is called shellable if there is an ordering of the facets F_1,…, F_s such that
F_i∩F_1,…,F_i-1 is pure of dimension |F_i|-1, for all i. Any such ordering of the facets is called a shelling order .
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Given a shelling order F_1,F_2,… F_l, F_i is called a vertex adding facet if |V(G_i)|-|V(G_i-1)|=1. Otherwise |V(G_i)|=|V(G_i-1)| and F_i is called a structural facet .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A circulant graph is a graph whose vertices are the elements of ℤ_n such that each vertex i is adjacent to vertex i+j and i-j mod n for each j ∈ J, for some J ⊆ [⌊ n/2 ⌋]. Denote by (n,J) the circulant graph on n vertices with associated set J.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let r=2k. Given a graph G with vertex set [n] and ω(G)=m whose clique complex has no structural facets and without loss of generality F_1∩ F_2={1,2,…,r/2}, we'll construct a directed tree T with root v in the following way:


  * Let v=F_1 ∩ F_2.

  * V(T)={F_i: i ∈ [l]}∪v

  * E(T)={v→ F_i: F_i ⊃ [r/2]}∪{F_i  F_j: i<j minimal such that
 (F_j∩⟨ F_1,F_2,…,F_j-1⟩ )⊆ F_i,[r/2]⊆ F_i,  where  x ∈ F_i∖ F_j} .

We call this a K_m tree . One can recover the original clique complex from the K_m tree.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A signed graph is a triple (V, E; σ  ) where G = (V, E)
is an undirected graph and σ is  a signature of the edge set E:

    σ : E     →{ -1, +1}
    
             e     ↦σ(e)

A signed graph is denoted by G_σ= (V, E;σ ).  Sometimes we write +,- for signs instead of +1,-1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A cycle of a signed graph is positive if the sign product of its edges is positive, or the number of its negative edges is even.  In the opposite case it is negative .  
A signed graph is balanced if all its cycles are positive; e.g., if it is cycle free (i.e., a forest).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Switching a signed graph means reversing the signs of all edges between a vertex subset W ⊆ V and its complement, V-W.  (The negated edge set may be void.)  We note that switching does not change the sign of a closed chain.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let W be the set of vertices that are switched in Lemma <ref>.  The pair { W, V-W } is called a Harary bipartition of G_σ.  It is unique if and only if G_σ is connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G_σ be a connected, unbalanced signed graph.  An edge e such that G_σ-e is balanced, is called a balancing edge of G_σ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
In a signed graph G_σ, a block is an inner block if it is unbalanced or it contains an edge of a path connecting two balanced blocks.  In the opposite case it is an outer block .

An unbalanced necklace of balanced blocks is a signed graph constructed from balanced signed blocks B_1σ_1, B_2σ_2, …, B_kσ_k (k≥2) and distinct vertices v_i, w_i ∈ B_iσ_i by identifying v_i with w_i-1 for i=2,…,k and v_1 with w_k.  The blocks B_iσ_i are called the constituents of the necklace.  Note that an unbalanced necklace of balanced blocks is an unbalanced block.

A core of G_σ is the union of inner blocks of an unbalanced connected component of G_σ.

sentence:
Let G_σ be a signed graph and let P be a chain (not necessarily elementary) connecting x and y in G_σ:

    P: x,e_1,x_1,e_2,x_2,…,y.

where x,x_1,…,y ∈ V and e_1,e_2,…∈ E.
We put 

    σ(P)=∏_e_i∈ Pσ(e_i)∈{-1,+1}
 
and we call P positive (resp., negative ) if σ(P)=+1 (resp., σ(P)=-1).  
(This sign rule generalizes the sign of a cycle.)

We may write P^ε instead of P when ε=σ(P) and we may write P^ε(x, y) when P is a chain connecting x and y.
P^ε is called an ε-chain of sign ε .

The graph of a chain P is G(P), the subgraph of G_σ that consists of all the vertices and edges of P.

An ε-chain P^ε(x,y) is elementary if it is minimal given its sign and its end vertices.  
Minimality means that no other ε-chain that connects x and y has a graph that is a proper subgraph of G(P^ε(x,y)).

sentence:
A hypercyclic chain P^ε connecting two vertices (not necessarily
distinct) in a signed graph G_σ is an elementary ε-chain which contains a negative cycle.
Note that the value of ε does not affect the definition of a hypercyclic chain, but it must be specified.

sentence:
Let G_σ= (V, E ;σ) be a signed graph. Let us consider the relation R in V defined by:

    x R y ⇔
       
            x = y ,  or
    there exist both a negative chain and a positive chain joining x and y.

Then R is an equivalence relation whose equivalence classes form a partition {V_1,…, V_q} of V. If xRy, we say x and y are sign connected .  The subgraphs of G_σ generated by the subsets V_i (i= 1, …, q) are  called the sign-connected components of G_σ.

A signed graph is called sign connected if it has just one sign-connected component; that is, for any pair of vertices x and y, there exist both a positive chain and a negative chain connecting them.

sentence:
A signed graph G_σ is called quasibalanced if for any two negative cycles C and Ć of G_σ we have

    |V(C) ∩  V(Ć)|≥ 2.

sentence: Let G_σ be a signed graph that is sign connected. An edge e ∈ E is called a sign isthmus if the graph G_σ - e is not sign connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G_σ be a sign-connected signed graph, and let x ∈ V. The vertex x is called a sign articulation vertex if the graph G_σ - x is not sign connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G_σ be a sign-connected signed graph. G_σ is called a sign block if G_σ has no sign articulation vertex.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
A signed graph G_σ=(V,E; σ) has associated two matroids, the frame matroid M(G_σ) and the lift matroid L(G_σ). A definition of M(G_σ) is that a subset F ⊆ E is a circuit of M(G_σ ) (a frame circuit of G_σ) if either


  * F is a positive cycle,

  * or F is the union of two negative cycles having exactly one common vertex,

  * or F is the union of two vertex-disjoint negative cycles and an elementary chain which connects the cycles and is internally disjoint from both cycles.



  

  
    < g r a p h i c s >

  

   We represent a positive (resp., negative) cycle by a quadrilateral (resp., triangle).
   


A definition of L(G_σ) is that a subset F ⊆ E is a circuit of L(G_σ ) (a lift circuit of G_σ) if it is of type (i), (ii), or 


  Type (iii'): F is the union of two vertex-disjoint negative cycles.

sentence:
A signed graph G_σ is called frame connected ( M-connected in <cit.>) if M(G_σ) is connected or if G_σ = K_1.
It is called lift connected if L(G_σ) is connected or if G_σ = K_1.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The connected components of M(G_σ) induce subgraphs of G_σ, which are called frame components of G_σ ( M-components in <cit.>). Thus, a frame component of G_σ is a maximal subgraph without isolated vertices whose frame matroid is connected, or it is an isolated vertex.

The connected components of L(G_σ) induce subgraphs of G_σ, which are called lift components of G_σ. Thus, a lift component of G_σ is a maximal subgraph without isolated vertices whose lift matroid is connected, or it is an isolated vertex.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
A signed graph without positive cycles is called contrabalanced .

sentence:
A cactus forest is a graph in which every block is a cycle, an isthmus, or K_1.  

A theta graph is a graph that consists of three elementary chains that are disjoint except that they all have the same two end vertices.

sentence:
A signed graph G_σ is called antibalanced if G_-σ is balanced.  Equivalently, 
G_σ switches to have all negative signs.  Also equivalently, all positive cycles have even length and all negative cycles have odd length.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: In an unsigned graph G, two vertices v and w are called parity connected if there exist both an odd-length and an even-length chain between them.  Equivalently, v and w are sign connected in G_-.  The graph G is called parity connected if every two vertices are parity connected in G; equivalently, G_- is sign connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A signed graph G_σ is positively connected if every pair of distinct vertices is joined by a chain of positive sign.  The positively connected components of G_σ are the maximal positively connected subgraphs of G_σ.

Vertices u,v in G_σ are negatively connected if they are joined by a negative chain.  The relation of being negatively connected is not transitive, in general.  Therefore, we define a negatively connected component of G_σ to be a maximal subgraph in which every pair of vertices, u and v, is negatively connected, or has a third vertex w such that u and v are negatively connected to w.

sentence:
[Asymptotics of a path]
theorem]theo:paths
Let T be a random infinite Young tableau distributed according to some Vershik-Kerov measure _α,β,γ. 

Then, almost surely, path (T)=( _1(T), _2(T),…) is an infinite sequence (i.e., the situation from <ref> is not possible).

Furthermore, almost surely, exactly one of the following three events holds true.

 
  * empty]enum:A
The path stabilizes in some row k ; in other words y(_i(T))=k holds true for almost all i. This event happens with probability α_k.
 
  * empty]enum:B
The path stabilizes in some column k ; in other words x(_i(T))=k holds true for almost all i. This event happens with probability β_k.
 
  * empty]enum:C
The path has some asymptotic slope ; 
in other words the limit 

    lim_i→∞_i(T)/‖_i(T) ‖

exists and thus is equal to (cosΘ(T), sinΘ(T) ) for some 0 < Θ(T) < π/2. 
This event happens with probability γ.

<cit.> Given a composition α n we define a standard reverse composition tableau (abbreviated to SRCT )  of shape α and size n to be a bijective filling 

    : α→{1, … , n}
of the cells (i,j) of the reverse composition diagram α such that


  * the entries in each row are decreasing when read from left to right

  * the entries in the first column are increasing when read from top to bottom

  * triple rule: If i<j and (i,k)>  (j, k+1), then (i,k+1) exists and (i,k+1)>  (j, k+1).

We denote the set of all SRCTs of shape α by (α).

sentence:
Let (N,+) be a group. A subgroup of automorphisms Φ, {1}≠Φ<N, is said to be regular if for any φ∈Φ∖{1}, φ is a fixed point free (f.p.f.) automorphism, i.e., φ(x)=x⇔ x=0. Moreover, if for any φ∈Φ∖{1}, -φ +1 is surjective, the pair (N,Φ) is called a Ferrero pair . Then an orbit of Φ is the set
Φ(a)={φ(a) |φ∈Φ},
for some a∈ N (Φ(0)={0} is the trivial orbit).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A planar nearring is said to be field-generated if it is generated from a Ferrero pair (N,Φ), where (N,+,· ) is a field and Φ is isomorphic to a subgroup of (N^0,· ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A planar nearring (N,+,· ), or the pair (N,Φ) from which is generated, or the incidence structure (N,ℬ^*,∈ ) yielded, is said circular if every three distinct points of N belong to at most one block of ℬ^*, and if every two distinct points belong to at least two distinct blocks. In this case the block N^*· a+b=Φ(a)+b is called circle with center b and radius a (see <cit.>,5.1).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
An algebraic structure  (N,+,∗, ∘ ) is a (left) double  planar nearring if each of (N,+,∗) and (N,+, ∘ ) is a
(left) planar nearring, and each of ∗ and ∘ is left distributive over the other.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let (X,ℬ,∈ ) be an incidence structure with |X|=v and |ℬ|=b. If there exist two integers k and r so that for any B∈ℬ, |B|=k, and every x∈ X belongs to exactly r distinct blocks B_1,...,B_r∈ℬ, then (X,ℬ,∈ ) is a tactical configuration with parameters v, b, k, r. Moreover if an integer λ exists so that every pair of points belongs to exactly λ distinct blocks, then (X,ℬ,∈ ) is a balanced incomplete block design (BIBD) with parameters v, b, k, r, λ. If a,b∈ X, we use the notation a,b to denote the number of blocks which the pair {a,b} belongs to.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (N,Φ) be a finite circular Ferrero pair, then for every r,c∈ N^0 define the family of circles E^r_c by
E^r_c={Φ(r)+b|b∈Φ(c)}.
Obviously |E^r_c|=|Φ(c)| (remember that E^r_c⊂𝒫(N)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (N,Φ) be a finite circular Ferrero pair and Φ(a)+b∈ℬ^*,


then we define 𝒟(a;b), the disk of center b and radius a , as
𝒟(a;b)={x∈Φ(r)+c|r≠0, b∈Φ(r)+c, |(Φ(r)+c)∩(Φ(a)+b)|=1} .
Now it is obvious to define the interior part of the circle Φ(a)+b, ℐ(Φ(a)+b), as
ℐ(Φ(a)+b)=𝒟(a;b)∖(Φ(a)+b).

plain_text_term: disk of center b and radius a;interior part of the circle

sentence: For k-bounded partitions λ and μ satisfying |λ| = |μ| + 1, we say that λ covers μ in the strong order with multiplicity d if c^(k)(μ) ⊆ c^(k)(λ), and c^(k)(λ)/ c^(k)(μ) has d ≥ 1 connected components (which are necessarily ribbons and translates of each other).

plain_text_term: λ covers μ in the strong order with multiplicity d

sentence:
Let R be a finite ring. A weight w:R⟶ is
   (left) homogeneous , if w(0)=0 and
    
  
  * If Rx=Ry then w(x)= w(y) for all x,y∈ R.
  
  * There exists a real number γ such that
    
    ∑_y∈ Rxw(y)   = γ  |Rx|    for all x∈
        R∖{0}.

sentence:
[Reluctant walk model]
  A walk model (Q, ) is said to be reluctant when
  ()=(δ_1, δ_2) with δ_1<0 and
  δ_2<0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: A (non-classical) polynomial factor ℬ of _2^n of complexity C is a partition of _2^n into finitely many pieces, called atoms , such that for some (non-classical) polynomials P_1,…,P_C, each atom is the solution set {x (P_1(x),P_2(x), …, P_C(x)) = (b_1, …, b_C)} for some b=(b_1,…,b_C)∈ (/)^C. The degree of ℬ is the highest degree among P_1, …, P_C.

sentence: Let  be a set of matroids and k = min_N ∈χ(N)-1. Note that (N) > k for all N ∈. The decomposition family () is the collection of (isomorphism classes of) restriction-minimal matroids D for which some N ∈ is contained in D^(N),k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
A t-bar visibility representation of a graph assigns to each vertex
at most t horizontal bars in the plane so that vertices are adjacent if and
only if some bar assigned to one sees some bar assigned to the other via
an unobstructed vertical channel of positive width.
The bar visibility number of a graph G, denoted by b(G), is the
least integer t such that G has a t-bar visibility representation.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let X be a digital image.   For each N ≥ 1, the digital path space (of paths of length N in X) P_NX = (I_N, X) consists of all paths of length N in X, together with the adjacency relation of def: adjacent functions.

sentence: The digital category of X , denoted by (X),  is the smallest n≥ 0 for which there is a covering of X by n+1 subsets that are subdivision-categorical in X.  Note that, since we consider only finite digital images, we always have a (finite) value for (X).

sentence:
[digital products]
The product of digital images X and Y is the Cartesian product of sets X × Y with the adjacency relation (x, y) ∼_X × Y (x', y') when x∼_X x'  and y ∼_Y y'.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that X is a digital image in ^n.  For each k ≥ 2, we have  a k-fold subdivision of X , which is an auxiliary (to X) digital image in ^n denoted by S(X, k), and also a canonical map or projection


    ρ_k  S(X, k) → X


that is continuous in the digital sense. This goes as follows.   For a real number x, denote by ⌊ x ⌋ the greatest integer less-than-or-equal-to x.  First, make
the [1/k]-lattice in ^n, namely, those points with coordinates each of which is z/k for some integer z, and then set


    S'(X, k) = { (x_1, …, x_n) ∈([1/k])^n  | ( ⌊ x_1 ⌋, …, ⌊ x_n ⌋) ∈ X }.


Then set


    S(X,k) = { (kx_1, …, kx_n) ∈^n  | (x_1, …, x_n) ∈ S'(X, k) }.


The map ρ_k is given by ρ_k( (y_1, …, y_n) ) = ( ⌊ y_1/k ⌋, …, ⌊ y_n/k ⌋), and one checks that this map is continuous.
For x ∈ X an individual point, we write S(x, k) ⊆ S(X, k) for the points y ∈ S(X, k) that satisfy ρ_k(y) = x.  If x = (x_1, …, x_n) is a point in an n-dimensional digital image, then we may describe this set in general as


    S(x, k) = { (kx_1 + r_1, …, kx_n + r_n) | 0 ≤ r_i ≤ k-1 }.


That is, for each x ∈ X, S(x, k) is an n-dimensional cubical lattice in ^n with each side of the cubical lattice containing k points.  Notice that  the result of subdivision therefore depends on the ambient space of the digital image.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Digital Path Space]
Let X be a digital image.   For each N ≥ 1, the digital path space (of paths of length N in X) P_NX = (I_N, X) consists of all paths of length N in X, together with the adjacency relation of def: adjacent functions.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Left and Right Homotopy]
Let X and Y be digital images, and f, g X → Y (continuous) digital maps.

(A) (Cylinder object definition.)
We say that f and g are left homotopic if, for some N≥ 1, there is a continuous map


    H  X × I_N → Y,


with H(x, 0) = f(x) and H(x, N) = g(x).  Then H is a left homotopy from f to g.

(B) (Path object definition.)  We say that f and g are right homotopic if, for some N≥ 1, there is a continuous map (in the sense of def:dig path space)


    H X  → P_NY,


for which f = ev_0∘H and g = ev_N∘H.  Then H is a right homotopy from f to g.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let f  X → Y be a map of digital  images.  If there is a map g  Y → X such that g∘ f ≈id_X and f ∘ g ≈id_Y, then f is a homotopy equivalence , and X and Y are said to be homotopy equivalent , or to have the same homotopy type.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM

sentence:
A digital image is contractible (to a point) if it is homotopy equivalent to a point.  Notice that this is equivalent to saying there is some x_0 ∈ X and some N,  for which we have a homotopy
H  X × I_N →  X  with H(x, 0) = x, and H(x, N) = x_0.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Digital cofibration]
An inclusion of digital images j  A → X ⊆^n is a cofibration if, given a commutative diagram


    A [r]^-H[d]_-j    P_NY [d]^-ev_0
    
    X [r]_-f    Y


(any N and any digital image Y),
there are subdivisions S( X, k) and S(I_N, l), and  a filler H S( X, k) →( S(I_N, l), Y) in the following commutative diagram:


    S(A, k) [d]_S(j,k)[r]^-ρ_k    A [r]^-H[d]_-j    P_NY [d]^-ev_0[r]^- (ρ_l)^*    ( S(I_N, l), Y) = P_lN + l-1 Y [ld]^ev_0
    
    S(X, k) [r]_-ρ_k@.>[rrru]^-H   X [r]_-f    Y
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any interval I_M, choose {0}∈ I_M as the basepoint.
For a based digital image Y, with basepoint y_0 ∈ Y,  let 𝒫_N Y denote the based path space (of paths of length N), so that


    𝒫_N Y = {γ∈ P_N Y |γ(0) = y_0}.


Also, let ev_N𝒫_N Y → Y denote  the evaluation map ev_N(γ) = γ(N).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that X is subdivision-contractible if, for some subdivision S(X, k) of X, and some x_0 ∈ X, and some N, we have a homotopy H  S(X, k) × I_N →  X  with H(x, 0) = ρ_k(x), and H(x, N) = x_0.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let i  U → X be an inclusion of digital images.

We say that U is categorical in X if, for some x_0 ∈ X, and some N,  we have a homotopy
H  U × I_N →  X  with H(u, 0) = x_0, and H(u, N) = i(u), for all u ∈ U.

We say that U is subdivision-categorical in X if, for some subdivision S(U, k) of U, some x_0 ∈ X, and some N,  we have a homotopy
H  S(U, k) × I_N →  X  with H(u', 0) = x_0, and H(u', N) = i∘ρ_k(u'), for all u' ∈ S(U, k).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Digital Category]
The digital category of X , denoted by (X),  is the smallest n≥ 0 for which there is a covering of X by n+1 subsets that are subdivision-categorical in X.  Note that, since we consider only finite digital images, we always have a (finite) value for (X).
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A divisor L on Γ is an anchor divisor if for each edge of Γ there is at most one its interior point x with L(x)>0. A cell C in |D| is an anchor cell if all representatives L of C are anchor divisors.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:

  * There are two distinct pairs (ℓ,m), (,∓)

such that λℓmμ and λ∓μ 
are prime plethystic equivalences 


if and only if either λ = μ
or (λ) = (λ)' and λ = μ'.

  * There are three distinct pairs
(ℓ,m), (,∓), (,) 
such that λℓmμ, λ∓μ 
and λμ 
if and only if either λ = μ
or (λ) = (λ)' and λ = μ'.

  * There exist distinct n, ∈ such that λ-1pt nn-0.5ptμ 
and λμ if and only if λ = μ.

sentence:
A plethystic equivalence λℓmμ is prime if 
ℓ≥ℓ(λ) and m ≥ℓ(μ).

sentence:
Let λ be a partition. Given a λ-tableau t with entries
from _0, let x^t = x_0^a_0(t)x_1^a_1(t)… where a_k(t) is the
number of entries of t equal to k ∈_0.
The Schur function s_λ is the symmetric function defined by

    s_λ(x_0,x_1,…, x_ℓ) = ∑_t ∈_≤ℓ(λ) x^t.

sentence:
Let λ be a partition. We define the minimum weight of λ, denoted (̱λ), by
(̱λ) = ∑_j=1^a(λ)λ'_j2.

sentence:
Let λ be a partition. The hook length of (i,j) ∈ [λ],
denoted h_(i,j)(λ), is (λ_i - i) + (λ'_j - j) + 1.
The content of (i,j) ∈ [λ] is j-i.  Let H(λ) = {h_(i,j)(λ) : (i,j)
∈ [λ]} and C(λ) = {j-i : (i,j) ∈ [λ]} be the corresponding
multisets.

sentence:
We define the differences δ(λ) of a partition λ
by δ(λ)_j =  λ_j - λ_j+1 + 1 for each j ∈.
For ℓ≥ℓ(λ) - 1,
let Δ_ℓ(λ) be the multiset whose elements are all 
δ(λ)_j + ⋯ + δ(λ)_k-1 for 1 ≤ j < k ≤ℓ+1.

sentence:
A difference multiset is a pair 
(X,Z) of finite multisubsets of , denoted X / Z.
If x ∈ has multiplicity a in X and b in Z, 
then the multiplicity of x in X/Z is a - b. Two difference
multisets are equal if their multiplicities agree for all x ∈.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let λ be a partition and let d = (λ).


  (i) The south-rank of λ, denoted (λ), 
is the maximum j ∈_0 such that λ_d+j = d.

  (ii) The south-partition of λ, denoted (λ) is
(λ_d + (λ) + 1, …, λ_ℓ(λ)).

  (iii) The east-rank of λ, denoted (λ), is (λ').

  (iv) The east-partition of λ, denoted (λ), is (λ')'.

sentence:
Let λ be a non-empty partition and 
let ≥ℓ(λ). Define λ̧ : _0 →_0 and λ : _0 →_0 by

    λ̧(k)    = | { (i,j) ∈ [λ] : j-i+ = k }|  
    λ(k)    = | { (i,j) ∈ [λ] : h_(i,j) = k }|

and the content-hook function λ : _0 → by 
λ = λ̧ - λ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let ℓ∈_0 and let λ /λ^⋆ be a skew-partition.
We say that s_λ / λ^⋆ is ℓ-irreducible if 
there exists b ∈_0 and m ∈_0 such that s_λ/λ^⋆(1,q,…, q^ℓ)
= q^b(1 + q + ⋯ + q^m).

sentence:
We say that a skew partition λ / λ^⋆ is proper if λ_1 > λ^⋆_1
and λ_1' > _1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a proper skew partition λ / λ^⋆ with a(λ) = p,
we define the column lengths c(λ / λ^⋆) ∈^p by c(λ / λ^⋆)_j = 
λ'_j - _j for 1 ≤ j ≤ p. 
We say that λ / λ^⋆ is


  (a) a skew ℓ-rectangle where ℓ∈_0 if 1 = … = p = ℓ+1;

  (b) a skew 1-near rectangle of width d ∈_0 if there exist y 
such that 

    y   = … = y+d-1 = 1, 
    λ'_y    = … = λ'_y+d-1,

 and j = 2 if 1 ≤ j < y
or y+d ≤ j ≤ p;

sentence:
Let G be a graph and k ≥ 3.
Let v be a vertex of G and 𝒟 be a {2k-1,2k,2k+1}-decomposition of G.
We say that 𝒟 is k-balanced (or simply balanced ) at v if 
the number of paths of 𝒟 of 
length at most 2k with end vertex v is at least 
the number of paths of 𝒟 of 
length at least 2k+1 with end vertex v.
Further, we say that 𝒟 is a k-balanced decomposition of G 
if it is k-balanced at every vertex of G
and the number of paths of length 2k-1 is equal to the number of paths of length 2k+1.

sentence:
Let G ∈𝒢_3.
	We say that a subgraph of G is exceptional
	if it isomorphic to an (M,𝒫)-alternating trail PeP'e'
	where P = x_0⋯ x_5, P' = y_0⋯ y_5,
	and e = x_5y_0 such that
	 e' =  y_5y_2,  y_0 = x_1, y_4 = x_5 and y_2 = x_3
	(see Figure <ref>).

sentence:
[Quasi-balanced decompositions]
        Let X be an extension of s(j,l). 
        We refer to a {2k-1,2k,2k+1}-decomposition 𝒟 of X 
        as quasi-k-balanced (or simply, quasi-balanced)
        if 𝒟 is k-balanced at all vertices of X,
	except possibly, at the vertices of odd degree of X
	incident to an edge of {e_j-1,e_j+l+1}.
	In addition, if 𝒟 is not k-balanced at 
	v ∈ e for  e ∈{e_j-1,e_j+l+1}, then 
	e ∈ X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[malicious paths, nice paths and trapped edges]
 Let PeP' be a path-edge-path (M,𝒫)-alternating trail.
 Suppose e=xx', where x is an end vertex of P and 
 x' is an end vertex of P'. 
 If x' is an internal vertex of P, then 
 we say that P is malicious for e; otherwise,
 we say P is nice for e. If P and P' are malicious for e,
 we say that edge e is trapped (in the sequence PeP').
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
[trapped sequences, nice and malicious extensions]
Let r ≥ 2 and W be the (M,𝒫)-alternating r-closed trail P_0 e_0 ⋯ P_r-1 e_r-1P_0.
If all matching edges e_j, e_j+1,… , e_j+l are trapped in s(j, l), 
then we say that s(j, l) is a trapped sequence .
Moreover, we say that an extension X of s(j, l) is nice , if the following holds:
if e_j-1∈ X (resp. e_j+l+1∈ X) and e_j-1≠ e_j+l+1, then P_j (resp. P_j+l+1) 
is nice for e_j-1 (resp. e_j+l+1). Otherwise, it is called malicious . 
In particular,  s(j, l) is nice as an extension of itself.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph in 𝒢_k,
and let ℒ be a {2k-1,2k,2k+1}-decomposition of G with cycles of length 2k
such that the number of paths of length 2k-1 equals the number of paths
of length 2k+1. 
We say that ℒ is complete if the following two conditions hold.

	
  (i)	the cycles in ℒ are vertex-disjoint; and
	
  (ii)	if v is a vertex of a cycle in ℒ,
			then ℒ is k-balanced at v.

sentence: Let k⩾ 2. A regular graph of valency 2k is said to have a Hamilton decomposition if its edge-set can be partitioned into k Hamilton cycles. A regular graph of valency 2k-1 is said to have a Hamilton decomposition if its edge-set can be partitioned into k-1 Hamilton cycles and a perfect matching.

sentence:
Let M be a positive affine monoid. An element x∈ M is irreducible if x≠ 0 and x=y+z with y,z∈ M implies
y=0 or z=0. A subset B
of M is a system of generators if
M=_+B. The unique minimal
system of generators of M given by its irreducible elements
is called the Hilbert basis and denoted by (M).

A (not necessarily pure) simplicial complex Δ is vertex-decomposable if either 


  * Δ is a simplex, or

  * Δ contains a vertex v such that _Δ(v) and _Δ(v) are vertex-decomposable, and such that every facet of _Δ(v) is a facet of Δ.

sentence:
[Affine syndeticity]
  Given an infinite field K, a set S⊂ K is called affinely syndetic if there exists a finite number of affine transformations g_1,…,g_k∈ such that for any x∈ K at least one of the images g_1(x),…,g_k(x) lies in S.

sentence:
Let K be a field, let E⊂ K and let (F_N) be a double Følner sequence in K.
  The upper density of E with respect to (F_N) is
  
    d̅_(F_N)(E):=lim sup_N→∞|E∩ F_N|/|F_N|

  and the lower density of E with respect to (F_N) is
  
    d_(F_N)(E):=lim inf_N→∞|E∩ F_N|/|F_N|

    _αβ=∑_δ |αβ|C_δβ^α_δ,

where the structure coefficients C_δβ^α, called noncommutative Littlewood-Richardson coefficients , are nonnegative integers described combinatorially by

    C_δβ^α=|{τ∈(αβ)(τ)=τ_δ}|.

sentence:
A semistandard reverse composition tableau (abbreviated to ) τ of shape αβ is a filling

    τ: αβ⟶ℤ^+

that satisfies the following conditions


  * the entries in each row decrease weakly from left to right,

  * the entries in the leftmost column increase strictly from top to bottom,

  * if i< j and (j,k+1) ∈αβ and either (i,k)∈β or τ(i,k) ≥τ(j,k+1) then either (i,k+1)∈β or both (i,k+1) ∈αβ and τ(i,k+1) > τ(j,k+1). (This condition will be referred to as the triple condition .)

that satisfies the following conditions

  * the entries in each column decrease strictly from top to bottom.

    i_1<⋯ <i_k
    x_i_1^α_1⋯ x_i_k^α_k.

Furthermore, we set M_∅=1.

sentence:
[Cluster complex of type A_n]
Identify the negative simple roots -α_i
with the diagonals on the snake of P_n+3 
illustrated in Figure <ref>. 
Each positive root is a consecutive sum

    α_ij=α_i+α_i+1+… + α_j,  1≤ i ≤ j ≤ n,

and thus can be identified with the unique diagonal of 
P_n+3 crossing the (consecutive) diagonals 
that correspond to -α_i, -α_i+1, …, -α_j, and no others.

Two roots α and β in 
Φ_≥ -1 are called compatible if 
their corresponding diagonals do not cross. 
The cluster complex Δ (Φ) of type A_n 
is the clique complex of the compatibility relation on Φ_≥ -1, 
i.e., the complex whose simplices correspond to 
the sets of almost positive roots that are pairwise compatible. 
Maximal simplices of Δ (Φ) are called clusters .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Two complete fans in real vector spaces V and V' of the same dimension are linearly isomorphic if there is a linear isomorphism V→ V' sending each cone of one to a cone of the other. Two polytopes P and P' are normally isomorphicÊ if they have linearly isomorphic normal fans.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[GKZ vector/secondary polytope] 
Let Q be a d-dimensional convex polytope with n+d+1 vertices. The GKZ vector 
v(t)∈^n+d+1 of a triangulation t of Q is 

    v(t) :=  ∑_i=1^n+d+1vol (star_t(i)) e_i 
      =  ∑_i=1^n+d+1∑_σ∈ t :  i∈σvol (σ) e_i
 
The secondary polytope of Q is defined as

    Σ (Q) := conv{ v(t) : t  is a triangulation of  Q }.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Gelfand–Kapranov–Zelevinsky associahedron (Q)⊂^n+3 is defined as
the (n-dimensional) secondary polytope of a convex (n+3)-gon Q⊂^2:

    (Q):=Σ (Q).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any vector 𝐚={a_ij>0: 
1≤ i≤ j ≤ n+1} of positive parameters we call 
Postnikov associahedron the polytope

    (𝐚):=∑_1≤ i≤ j≤ n+1a_ijΔ_[i,… ,j],

where Δ_[i,… ,j] denotes the simplex conv{e_i,e_i+1,… , e_j} in ^n+1. 
The special case where a_ij=1 for all i,j is the Loday associahedron .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The Rote–Santos–Streinu associahedron is the polytope

    (𝐠)={(y_0,y_1,… , y_n+1)∈^n+2 : 
    y_j-y_i ≥ g_i,j for  j>i, 
    y_0= 0, 
    y_n+1=g_0,n+1},

where 𝐠 =(g_i,j)_0 ≤ i < j ≤ n+1 
is any vector with real coordinates satisfying

    g_i,l + g_j,k  >   g_i,k + g_j,l    for all     i<j ≤ k < l, 
    
    
    g_i,l > g_i,k + g_k,l    for all     i < k < l.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Cluster complex of type A_n]
Identify the negative simple roots -α_i
with the diagonals on the snake of P_n+3 
illustrated in Figure <ref>. 
Each positive root is a consecutive sum

    α_ij=α_i+α_i+1+… + α_j,  1≤ i ≤ j ≤ n,

and thus can be identified with the unique diagonal of 
P_n+3 crossing the (consecutive) diagonals 
that correspond to -α_i, -α_i+1, …, -α_j, and no others.

Two roots α and β in 
Φ_≥ -1 are called compatible if 
their corresponding diagonals do not cross. 
The cluster complex Δ (Φ) of type A_n 
is the clique complex of the compatibility relation on Φ_≥ -1, 
i.e., the complex whose simplices correspond to 
the sets of almost positive roots that are pairwise compatible. 
Maximal simplices of Δ (Φ) are called clusters .

sentence: We call Chapoton–Fomin–Zelevinsky associahedron (A_n) any polytope whose normal fan is the fan with maximal cones _≥ 0 C generated by all clusters C of type A_n.

sentence:
For a diagonal ij (i<j) of P_n+3(σ), we denote by R_ij(σ) the 
	set of vertices strictly below it. We define the set S_ij(σ) as the 
	result of 
	replacing 0   by i in R_ij(σ) if 0∈ R_ij(σ), and 
	replacing n+2 by j if n+2∈ R_ij(σ).
	
The Hohlweg–Lange associahedron (σ) is the polytope

    [                                (σ) = 
    {  (x_1,… x_n+1) ∈^n+1 : ∑_i∈ S_δ (σ) x_i ≥12|S_δ(σ)|(|S_δ(σ)| +1) for all diagonals δ,;                                                                                                    x_1+⋯+x_n+1=(n+1)(n+2)2
    }. ]

sentence: [<cit.>] For a set of input sequences S, the partition intersection graph G(S) is obtained by associating a vertex for each character state and an edge between two vertices χ^i_j and χ^k_l if there exists a sequence s with state j in character χ^i ∈𝒞 and state l in character χ^k ∈𝒞.  We say s is a row that witnesses edge (χ^i_j, χ^k_l).  For a subset of characters Φ = {χ^i_1, χ^i_2, …χ^i_k}, let G(Φ) denote the partition intersection graph G(S) restricted to the characters in Φ.

sentence:
Suppose the endpoints of edge e have colors χ^i and χ^j.  Then any other edge whose endpoints also have colors χ^i and χ^j is called color equivalent to e.  
Two edges are called nonadjacent if they do not share a common endpoint.

sentence:
Let G and H be digraphs with roots g_0 and h_0.  A robust map
from G to H is a map ϕ V(G) → V(H) with ϕ(g_0) = h_0 such
that whenever there is an edge from ϕ(v) to w in H, there is also some
vertex z in G such that ϕ(z)=w and vz∈ E(G).

sentence:
Let G and H be digraphs with roots g_0 and h_0.  For k∈, a
k-robust map from G to H is a map ϕ V(G) → V(H) with
ϕ(g_0) = h_0 such that when there is an edge from ϕ(v) to w in H,
there are at least k vertices z in G with ϕ(z)=w and vz∈ E(G).

Let X,Y be two positive integer-valued random variables. We say that X stochastically dominates Y,
and write X ≻ Y, if [X≥ r] ≥ [Y≥ r] for all r∈.

sentence:
A percolating set in a double graph (V,E_1,E_2) is a set of vertices U⊂ V such that given the two edge sets
E_i'=E_i ∩U2 for i=1,2, the jigsaw process on the double graph (U,E_1',E_2') percolates.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A minimal percolating configuration , is a percolating double-graph (U,E_1,E_2),
where U⊂ [n] and E_i⊂ E(G_i) for i=1,2, and 
each E_i forms a spanning tree in U.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An optimal configuration in a double graph (V,E_1,E_2)
is a minimal percolating configuration (U,E_1',E_2'), where U⊂ V and E_i' ⊂ E_i for i=1,2,
together with a vertex v∈ U and a set of clusters partitioning U∖{v} such that an 
absorption process with this input will percolate, and
furthermore the following holds.
Let ℓ be the number of steps it takes for this absorption process to percolate,
and let v=v_1,…,v_|U| be the vertices of U in the order that they are added
to the percolating set in the absorption process.
Then no vertex in V∖ U has an edge to {v_1,…,v_ℓ-1}
in both E_1 and E_2.

sentence:
For 𝐢=(i_1,…, i_t)∈ℐ(t;k|ℓ), we say that 𝐢 is up-down
 if there exists a p such that  
    i_1<⋯<i_p≥ i_p+1≥⋯≥ i_t for some with 0≤ a<t.
We say that i_p+1 is the peak of the up-down sequence 𝐢 and write p(𝐢)=p.

For , ∈, we say that T∈std() is -SW-NE if it satisfies the property: if i, i+1, …, i+j is in a row of 𝔱^ then

 The number p here is called the peak of the row.

sentence:
Let B be the collection of equivalence classes of real valued
  functions a(x) defined on some half line (u,∞), where we
  identify two functions if they agree for all large x.[The
    equivalence classes just defined are often called germs of
      functions . We choose to use the word function when we refer to
    elements of B instead, with the understanding that all the
    operations defined and statements made for elements of B are
    considered only for sufficiently large values of x∈.]  A
  Hardy field is a subfield of the ring (B,+,·) that is
  closed under differentiation. By $̋ we denote the union of all
  Hardy fields .

A graph G=(V,E) is a Laman plus one graph if it is connected and simple,
with no degree 1 vertices and is  such that the graph
 G\ e=(V, E\ e) is a Laman graph for some edge e.

sentence:
A cyclic plane permutation on [n] is a pair 𝔭=(s,π) where
	s=(s_i)_i=0^n-1 is an n-cycle and π is an arbitrary permutation on [n].
	The permutation D_𝔭=s∘π^-1 is called the diagonal of 𝔭.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a cyclic plane permutation 𝔭=(s,π) on [n] and a 𝔭-vertex
	ν, the localization of 𝔭 at ν, loc_ν(𝔭)=
	(s_ν,π_ν) is the cyclic plane permutation
	
    (s_ν,π_ν)=
    	([        s_i1        s_i2           ⋯    s_i(k-1)        s_ik;     π(s_i1)     π(s_i2)           ⋯ π(s_i(k-1))     π(s_ik) ]),

	which is obtained by deleting all columns not containing half edges incident to ν
	in the two-line representation of 𝔭=(s,π).

sentence:
Let E be a finite set, and let  be a collection of subsets of
  E satisfying:
  
  
  (a) ∅∉,
  
  (b) if C_1,C_2 ∈ with C_1 ⊆ C_2, then
    C_1 = C_2, and
  
  (c) (Circuit elimination) if C_1,C_2 ∈ with C_1 ≠ C_2 and
    e ∈ C_1 ∩ C_2, then there exists C_3 ∈ with
    C_3 ⊆ (C_1 ∪ C_2) - e.

The pair M = (E,) is a matroid with ground set E and set
  of circuits .  A subset S⊆ E is dependent in M
when S contains some circuit of M.

For combinatorial structure 𝒳 we will use term motion to denote the minimal degree of the automorphism group (𝒳) of 𝒳; we use notation 

    (𝒳) = ((𝒳)).

sentence:
A configuration 𝒳 of rank r on the set V is a pair (V, c), where c is a map c:V× V →{0, 1,..., r-1} such that 


  * c(v,v) ≠ c(u,w) for any v,u,w∈ V with u≠ w,

  * for any i<r there is i^*<r such that c(u,v) = i implies c(v,u) = i^* for all u,v ∈ V.

sentence: For a graph X = (V, E) the configuration 𝒳 = (V, c), where colors c(u, v) = (u,v) are defined by distance metric in X, is called the distance configuration of X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
[Babai <cit.>]
A pair of vertices u and v is distinguished by vertex x in a configuration 𝒳 if the colors c(x,u) and c(x,v) are distinct.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a graph X = (V(X), E(X)) the line graph L(X) is defined as the graph on the vertex set E(X), for which e_1, e_2∈ E(X) are adjacent in L(X) if and only if they are incident to a common vertex in X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A transitive permutation group is called primitive if it does not admit any non-trivial system of imprimitivity.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A configuration 𝔛 of rank r on the set V is a pair (V, c), where c is a map c:V× V →{0, 1,..., r-1} such that 


  * c(v,v) ≠ c(u,w) for any v,u,w∈ V with u≠ w,

  * for any i<r there is i^*<r such that c(u,v) = i implies c(v,u) = i^* for all u,v ∈ V.

sentence:
A configuration 𝔛 is coherent if 


  (iii) for all i,j,t<r there is an intersection number p_i,j^t such that for all u,v∈ V if c(u,v) = t, then there exist exactly p_i,j^t vertices w∈ V with c(u,w) = i and c(w,v) = j.

sentence: A configuration 𝔛 is homogeneous if c(u,u) = c(v,v) for every u,v∈ V.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: A coherent configuration is called an association scheme if c(u,v) = c(v,u) for any u,v∈ V.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: A homogeneous coherent configuration is called primitive if every constituent is strongly connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence: We say that an association scheme has diameter d if any non-diagonal constituent has diameter at most d and there exists a non-diagonal constituent of diameter d.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A regular graph is called edge-regular if any pair of adjacent vertices has the same number of common neighbors. A graph is called co-edge-regular if its complement is edge-regular.

sentence:
[Babai <cit.>]
 The thickness θ(G) of a group G is the greatest t such that the alternating group A_t is involved in G. A group H is said to be involved in G if H ≅ L/N for some N◃ L ≤ G.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let t≥ 2 and Ω be a set of m≥ 2t+1 points. The Johnson graph J(m,t) is a graph on a set  of n = mt vertices  V(J(m,t)) = Ωt, i.e., vertices are the subsets of size t of Ω. Two vertices of J(m,t) are adjacent if and only if the corresponding subsets U_1, U_2⊆Ω differ by exactly one element, i.e., |U_1∖ U_2| = |U_2∖ U_1| = 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let t≥ 2 and Ω be a set of m≥ 2t+1 points. The Johnson scheme 𝔍(m,t) is an association scheme of rank t+1 on a set  of n = mt vertices  V = Ωt. Two vertices v_1 and v_2 of 𝔍(m,t) are connected by an edge of color i if and only if the corresponding subsets U_1, U_2⊆Ω differ by exactly i elements, i.e., |U_1∖ U_2| = |U_2∖ U_1| = i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The Johnson graph J(s,2) is also called the triangular graph and is denoted by T(s), where s≥ 5.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Ω be a set of m≥ 2 points. The Hamming graph H(s, m) is a graph on a set of n = m^s vertices V = Ω^s. Two vertices in H(s,m) are adjacent if and only if the corresponding s-tuples v_1, v_2 differ in precisely one position, or in other words, if the Hamming distance d_H(v_1, v_2) for the corresponding tuples is equal 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Ω be a set of m≥ 2 points. The Hamming scheme ℌ(s, m) is an association scheme of rank s+1 on a set of n = m^s vertices V = Ω^s. Two vertices in ℌ(s,m) are connected by an edge of color j if and only if the corresponding s-tuples v_1, v_2 differ in precisely i positions, or in other words, if the Hamming distance d_H(v_1, v_2) for the corresponding tuples is equal j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The Hamming graph H(2, m) is called the lattice graph and is denoted by L_2(m), where m≥ 2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: For G≤ Sym(Ω) with orbitals R_1, R_2, ..., R_k define orbital configuration as 𝔛(G) = (Ω, {R_1, R_2, ..., R_k}). A configuration is called Schurian if it is equal to 𝔛(G) for some permutation group G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Cameron groups]
Let G be a primitive group. Let m,k,d be positive integers and (A_m^(k))^d≤ G≤ S_m^(k)≀ S_d, where S_m^(k)≀ S_d has the product action on mk^d elements. Then group G is called a Cameron group .

 The corresponding orbital configuration 𝔛(G) is called a Cameron scheme .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let X be a finite graph with adjacency matrix A. Suppose that the set of vertices is partitioned into non-empty sets X_1, X_2, ..., X_m. The quotient matrix Q∈ M_m(ℝ) with respect to this partition is defined as (Q)_i,j = 1/|X_i|1_X_i^TA1_X_j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Graph X is called a cocktail-party graph if it is obtained from a regular complete bipartite graph by deletion of one perfect matching.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A distance-regular graph X is called geometric if there exists a collection 𝒞 of Delsarte cliques such that every edge of X lies in precisely one clique of 𝒞.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Graph X is called m× n-grid if it is the line graph of a complete bipartite graph K_m,n.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that a homogeneous coherent configuration 𝔛 of rank r has constituents ordered by degree , if color 0 corresponds to the diagonal constituent and the degrees of non-diagonal constituents satisfy k_1≤ k_2≤ ...≤ k_r-1.

sentence: For a homogeneous configuration 𝔛 and disjoint non-empty sets of edge colors I and J we say that vertices x, y_1, y_2, ..., y_t form a t-claw (claw of size t) in colors (I, J) if c(x,y_i)∈ I and c(y_i, y_j)∈ J for all distinct 1≤ i,  j≤ t.

sentence: A sorting sequence is a non-decreasing sequence of finite length of non-negative integers, beginning with 0, in which each entry is equal to the previous or is greater by 1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The binary representation of S_i of length p is a binary string of length p-1 constructed from S_i in which the jth digit is 0 if the (j+1)-st and jth entries of S_i are the same, and 1 if they are different.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A weighing strategy discreetly proves a certain property P if given an outcome for the weighing strategy and the information that P is true, the identity of no specific coin can be concluded. We say that such a strategy is discreet .
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let 𝒜 be a weighing strategy and P a property of coins. If the number of new possibilities is not zero, then the revealing factor is the ratio of the number of old to new possibilities: 
    X = # old possibilities/# new possibilities.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
In the context of a given graph G we call a set M crude if it satisfies M∩E=⋃_v∈ M∩ VE(v).
If a topological space X⊇ G has a basis consisting of the basic open sets of G and sets that are crude,
then we call both the basis and the space X crude .
